<p>Goodlettsville-based Dollar General is facing a lawsuit from a former employee who worked in its corporate headquarters who says he was fired after blowing the whistle about alleged fraud in the retail giant.</p><p></p><p>Nashville Post reports that Corey McNeley, a director of store operations, filed suit last month in Davidson County Circuit Court. The case has since been moved to federal court.</p><p></p><p>In his suit, Neley claims he was fired after raising concerns about the company's use of coupons that violated the redemption terms agreed to by vendors, according to the Post. The suit claims the value of the alleged fraud is in excess of $8 million, the Post reports.</p><p></p><p>In a statement to the Post, Dollar General said, "Mr. McNeleys discharge was wholly unrelated to any alleged whistleblowing, and Dollar General will vigorously defend against his baseless lawsuit."</p><p></p><p>Sign up for free email newsletters delivering exclusive news scoops and local business intelligence from the Memphis Business Journal.</p>
<p>Spotify, which is widely believed to be behind the antitrust&nbsp;allegations that led&nbsp;to both EC and DOJ investigations into Apple, has now added a fresh complaint. The Verge&nbsp;reports Spotify is complaining that&nbsp;the 30% cut Apple takes from in-app Premium subscriptions in the iOS app amounts to an Apple tax.</p><p></p><p>Apple charges a 30 percent fee toward any sales through its App Store, and that includes subscription services. That means if Spotify wants to sell its premium subscription service  which usually costs $9.99 a month &nbsp;through the App Store, it has to raise the price 30 percent higher to $12.99 to pull in the same revenue, while Apple can still offer Beats at a lower price. Spotify and many others in the music industry believe Apples App Store tax gives them an unfair advantage over the competition.</p><p></p><p>One unnamed music industry source said that Apple taking 30% was **cking bullsh** </p><p></p><p>Spotify Premium normally costs $9.99/month, and if you sign up via the web at that price, you can use your Premium subscription in the iOS app. But if you download the app, use the free tier and then buy a Premium subscription via an in-app purchase, it costs $12.99  and App Store guidelines mean the app cant point you to the web instead.</p><p></p><p>The allegations&nbsp;leading to the EC and DOJ investigations are that Apple has been engaging in anti-competitive behavior by pressuring music labels into&nbsp;dropping support for free, ad-supported streaming services like Spotify and YouTube. If true, this would suggest Apple is trying to reduce competition in the market from free services in order to make its rebranded Beats Music service more appealing.</p><p></p><p>Apple had reportedly hoped to offer its own service for&nbsp;$5/month, but was unable to secure the necessary deals from music labels. A revised attempt&nbsp;at hitting &nbsp;$7.99/month&nbsp;also&nbsp;reportedly failed&nbsp;for the same reason, even though Google Play offered initial All Access Signups for a $7.99 locked in.</p><p></p><p>Apple is expected to formally announce&nbsp;its streaming music at WWDC as part of an iOS 8.4 update that will see it integrated into the existing Music app, with access on Macs via an iTunes update. There is some doubt as to whether the&nbsp;service will actually launch&nbsp;at the point at which it is announced.</p>
<p>Microsoft quietly launched a set of new machine-learning APIs in beta under the Project Oxford moniker yesterday and today its How-Old.net demo for this service went viral.</p><p></p><p>This site lets you upload photos of faces and then it automatically figures out how old the person in that photo is.&nbsp;Its a cool&nbsp;demo  and works&nbsp;reasonably well (though as expected it makes its fair number of mistakes).&nbsp;Its best to take its results with a grain of salt, but while Microsofts demo is interesting, the use case for this is probably more along the lines of trying&nbsp;to figure out whether an images features a child or adult, for example.</p><p></p><p>How-Old uses some  but not all  of the new developer services that are part of Project Oxford.</p><p></p><p>The new APIs also allow developers to add face detection and recognition features to their apps. By default, the service will try to figure out what the users age is and give that information to developers.</p><p></p><p>As&nbsp;Ryan Galgon, a senior program manager&nbsp;on&nbsp;the Oxford project at&nbsp;Microsoft&nbsp;Technology and Research told me at Microsofts Build developer conference today, Oxford and the age-detection project was the result of a major collaboration between different groups inside of Microsoft. Much of whats available through the service today is based on modern deep learning techniques the company worked on over the last few years.</p><p></p><p>Right out of the box, this API also offers face detection in images, face verification to check whether&nbsp;two faces belong to the same person, and the ability to find similar-looking faces.</p><p></p><p>Other tools include&nbsp;speech recognition&nbsp;and over time, the service will be able to help developers understand their users intent. The project also features a vision API for automatically categorizing images and&nbsp;creating smart image crops&nbsp;that always put the subject into the center of the cropped images.</p><p></p><p>These three services are now available as a public beta. Theres also a fourth API that lets developers build custom language understanding into their applications.</p><p></p><p>Previously, Microsoft offered a set of somewhat similar APIs under the Bing brand. Bing offers a speech and translator API, for example, but for the most part, these Bing services are somewhat more basic&nbsp;and search-focused than the Project Oxford tools. These Bing APIs, Galgon told me, were more focused on the Windows desktop experience, though. The Project Oxford tools, on the other hand, are available as RESTful APIs (with a limit of 5,000 calls per month).</p><p></p><p>The Speech API, as the name implies, offers speech-recognition services for speech-to-text conversion, as well as a text-to-speech service that turns written text into audio. More interestingly, though, it also features intent recognition. The idea here is to allow application to understand the speakers intent (order a burrito, cancel a flight, etc.). This is driven by the projects Language Understanding&nbsp;Intelligent Service.</p><p></p><p>Using the image API, developers can categorize images to filter out adult content, for example, or to simply automatically apply tags to images or group them into clusters. The API also features optical character recognition capabilities and lets developers crop images automatically by recognizing whats important in an image and keeping that in the center of the photo as you crop it.</p><p></p><p>For now, the service is available for free. Its unclear when Microsoft plans to charge for access, but Galgon told me that the company is committed to evolving these services over time.</p><p></p><p>Even if youre not a developer, you can give some of these features a try here.</p>
  <p><b>iEntertainment Network Inc.</b>, (OTCBB:<b> IENT</b>) announces today that <b><i><u>BowHunter2015</u></i></b>, the Mobile Outdoors Action Simulation game, has been launched in the Google Play Store worldwide for android devices only (<a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.ient.bowhunter2015" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.ient.bowhunter2015</a> ).  The <b><u>iOS</u></b> version of <b><i><u>BowHunter2015 </u></i></b>is expected to be released for play at the end of&nbsp;May 2015. &nbsp; </p>  <p>The <b><i><u>BowHunter2015</u></i></b> game simulation allows players to hunt White Tail, Mule, and Black Tail deer in stalking and treestand hunts, in four regions of the United States, delivering the feel of real life bow hunting to outdoor enthusiasts and gamers. &nbsp;<b><i><u>BowHunter2015</u></i></b> contains over 120 hunts, with increasing difficulty, requiring better and better equipment, techniques, and hunting expertise.   See <a href="https://youtu.be/qoeyZh5Lxpg" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">BowHunter2015 Release Video</a>&nbsp; and <a href="http://www.bowhunter2015.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.BowHunter2015.com</a>. &nbsp; </p>  <p>With real ballistics and accurate FPS calculations, we have made the most accurate mobile simulation of Bow Hunting available for any mobile devices," said CEO John (Wild Bill)&nbsp;Stealey, Lt. Colonel, USAF Retired.&nbsp; "Players will have to use real bow hunting techniques to be good at <b><i><u>BowHunter2015. </u></i></b>Players can also qualify for monthly real prize tournament <b><u></u></b>where they can win gift cards to their favorite outdoors stores to buy real bows, arrows, and other hunting equipment!"</p>  <p><b><i><u>BowHunter2015</u></i></b> will be released also for iPhones and iPads (iOS) in May to add to the players who can compete in the monthly online Tournaments.   </p>  <p>IENT is also developing two more Mobile Outdoor Action Simulation Games for late 2015, a rifle hunting game and a fishing game. For more information about IENT and BowHunter2015:  <a href="http://www.ient.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">www.IENT.com</a><u>;</u> <a href="https://www.facebook.com/BowHunter2015" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Facebook</a>; <a href="http://bowhunter2015.freeforums.net/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">BowHunter2015 Forum</a><u>.</u></p>  <p><strong>Safe Harbor Notice</strong></p>  <p>Certain statements contained herein are "forward-looking statements" (as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995). iEntertainment, Inc. cautions that statements made in this news release constitute forward-looking statements and makes no guarantee of future performance. <p>HANGZHOU, China--(BUSINESS WIRE)-- Tmall Global, China's leading cross-border e-commerce platform, announced today the launch of a new "World Duty Free" service that allows Chinese tourists to prepay for their duty-free purchases before going on vacation.</p><p></p><p>Tmall Global, a platform under Alibaba Group Holding Limited (NYSE: BABA), also announced that Thailand's largest duty-free retail group, King Power, will open a duty-free storefront on the platform (<a href="http://kingpowerdutyfree.tmall.hk/">http://kingpowerdutyfree.tmall.hk/</a>) and become the first company to offer this service to Chinese consumers. By launching the "World Duty Free" service, Tmall Global hopes to enhance cross-border e-commerce opportunities for global companies looking to reach Chinese shoppers when they travel.</p><p></p><p>"We are excited that Thailand's King Power is launching its duty-free store on Tmall Global. Cross-border e-commerce has great potential in China and Tmall Global will continue to help brands and retailers sell into China through innovative solutions, at the same time providing Chinese consumers a wide variety of product choice," said Maggie WU, head of Tmall Global.</p><p></p><p>The King Power Duty Free store on Tmall Global allows consumers to purchase stored-value cards online before their vacation and when they visit Thailand, users can then spend the value on those cards in five King Power shops in the country, including the stores in Bangkok's Don Mueang International Airport and the Suvarnabhumi Airport. King Power's duty-free stores host over 600 global brands.</p><p></p><p>In the future, the "World Duty Free" service on Tmall Global will support online purchase of specific duty-free items and delivery of those items to the airport for customers to pick up. Tmall Global is also working with duty-free companies in South Korea, Japan and Europe to open stores on the platform.</p><p></p><p>Through Tmall Global's "World Duty Free" service, companies like King Power are able to tailor special promotional discounts for Chinese tourists and help them minimize the hassle of carrying cash and dealing with exchange rates. Although the King Power Duty Free store has been online for less than a month, the total order value from consumers has topped RMB 1 million(US$161,000), with an average order size of RMB 7135($1150).</p><p></p><p>According to tax rebate company, Global Blue, Chinese global shoppers accounted for nearly 30 percent of all tax-free shopping spending in the world last year.</p><p></p><p>Alibaba Group's mission is to make it easy to do business anywhere. The company is the largest online and mobile commerce company in the world in terms of gross merchandise volume. Founded in 1999, the company provides the fundamental technology infrastructure and marketing reach to help businesses leverage the power of the Internet to establish an online presence and conduct commerce with hundreds of millions of consumers and other businesses.</p>

<p><b>New York City, NY</b>  Union National Culture and Sports Foundation (UNCSF) announces its inaugural gala May 26th, 2015 at the United Nations. &nbsp;The foundation will host a Sports for Peace Forum and Awards Dinner Gala to forge relations between countries through sports as well as to provide resources to injured, disabled, retired and aspiring athletes alike of all ages. &nbsp;Top athletes from professional associations including the NBA and the NFL among many, will gather from over 50 Countries to break bread with New Yorks most influential tastemakers and dignitaries in attendance.</p> <p>The Union National Culture and Sports Foundation is a non-governmental and nonprofit organization founded in 2013. &nbsp;It's mission is to help retired and disabled athletes in all sports improve their quality of life through financial assistance and professional business training. &nbsp;"The UNCSF understands the difficulties of being a retired or disabled athlete facing financial hardship" says founder Amy Zhou. &nbsp;The UNCSF will provide monetary assistance from donations, as well as provide professional training to retired athletes looking for new career opportunities not only in the U.S., but throughout the world as well.</p><p>Guests Include: Wilfried Lemke (Special Advisor of Ban Ki-Moon UN Sport for Development and Peace), Billy Hunter (Former Executive Director of the Players' Union of the NBA), Davide Usai (UNICEF Italy), Richard Attias (Executive Chairman of Richard Attias &amp; Associates), Ato J. Boldon (NBC Journalist)&nbsp;and&nbsp;Lenny Green (Sports Radio Personality).<br></p> <p>The UNSCF dinner will provide opportunities of networking, sharing experiences and collaborating with other charities. Guests will enjoy cocktails surround by top athletes, celebrities and executives. Says Amy Zhou, the president of UNSCF.</p> <p>For more information on UNCSF, please visit <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.uncsf.org">www.uncsf.org</a></p><p>To purchase tickets, please visit: <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="https://uncsfoundation.eventbrite.com">https://uncsfoundation.eventbrite.com</a><br></p><p>For press &amp; media inquiries including press junket please call Jennifer DeCosta of Dash Public Relations at Jennifer DeCosta at 212-763-7743</p><p>or email info@dashpublicrelations.com<br></p>
<p>OKLAHOMA CITY,&nbsp;May 8, 2015&nbsp;/PRNewswire/ -- On the cusp of 2015's summer travel season,&nbsp;Orlando's&nbsp;Caribe Royale resort has now hit the 60 day mark of the hotel brand communicating with guests through SMS text messaging  part of the resort's new technology overhaul launched earlier this year for the Spring Break season. Sending out SMS Welcome Messages to incoming guests has prompted thousands of app downloads, but most notably, it has sparked hundreds of conversations back and forth between guests and the hotel staff.</p><p>Photo -&nbsp;<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnh/20150508/214731">http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnh/20150508/214731</a></p><div><div><div><div><div><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnfull/20150508/214731"><img alt="" src="http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnfull/20150508/214731" title="Image: http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnfull/20150508/214731"></a></div><div><ul><li><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/hospitality-leverages-contextual-messaging-to-increase-guest-satisfaction-and-mobile-adoption-300080220.html"></a></li>&nbsp;<li><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow"></a></li>&nbsp;<li><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow"></a></li>&nbsp;<li><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnfull/20150508/214731"></a></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div><p><i>"In 2015, we have user-friendly mobile applications that I can use to text my doctor, my bank... get updates on prescriptions or request a haircut appointment. As a hotel guest, I would be looking for a way to chat or text requests and questions to the front desk, at the very least. It's now easy for hotels to have and manage this functionality with the same content management system as many other on-site technologies."&nbsp;</i>&nbsp;<b>--&nbsp;Kacey Butcher, Business Development, Monscierge.</b></p><p>Last year, the brand partnered with hospitality technology partner Monscierge on a mobile app for iOS and Android, along with in-app guest requests functionality and digital concierge screens.  April kicked off the launch of 75 more concierge screens, SMS Welcome Messages and guest requests functionalities. Caribe Royale additionally implemented a Meetings and Events planning feature, static digital signage, and an in-room hotel events television channel. A web version for all of these pieces is also available, so that guests have access to information and the hotel staff via their laptops.</p><p><i>"Guests want to access information from multiple sources, depending on what they happen to be doing at that particular time. We've done our research, and this is the only technology in the hospitality industry that has the ability to connect all of our information to one source for updating, messaging and managing the information guests need."</i>&nbsp;--&nbsp;<b>Gerald Urquiola, General Manager, Caribe Royale</b></p><p>Hotels routinely used as venues for conferences and events now have the option for guests to communicate with staff via mobile app or native mobile texting functionality. The Monscierge events and meeting planning capabilities additionally lets hotels provide clients a tool that historically is a separate service and associated with another vendor's fee.</p><p><i>"One unique thing about Monscierge is that they listen to their customer. During our installations and training, we made several suggestions that they implemented into their product line immediately, before leaving our property. We look forward to seeing our guests' reactions to the technology."</i>&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>--&nbsp;Lori Schefstad, Director of Information Systems, Caribe Royale</b></p><p>Located in the shadows of&nbsp;Walt Disney World&nbsp;in&nbsp;Lake Buena Vista, Florida, Caribe Royale just completed a&nbsp;$3.5 million&nbsp;renovation project in April for the resort, that consists of 1,218 one-bedroom suites and 120 two-bedroom villas.</p><p><b>About Caribe Royale:</b></p><p>The Caribe Royale is an all-suite hotel in&nbsp;Orlando, Florida&nbsp;that features 1,218 one-bedroom suites and 120 two-bedroom villas and is located 1.5 miles from the Walt Disney World® Theme Parks. Each suite and villa is elegantly appointed and ideal for families or business travelers. Owned and operated by the Sierra Land Group in&nbsp;Glendale, CA, the Caribe Royale is located in the&nbsp;Lake Buena Vista&nbsp;area. More information about Caribe Royale is available by visiting&nbsp;<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.cariberoyale.com/">http://www.cariberoyale.com</a></p><p><b>About Monscierge</b></p><p>Monscierge is a global software company specializing in innovative hospitality solutions for properties, owners and brands. Since 2009, the Monscierge product line, Monscierge Connect, has been facilitating elegant connections between guests, hotel properties and their brands, through mobile, tablet, large-format touchscreen devices and a central web-based platform that manages property content. With installations in almost 80 countries and multilingual capabilities, Monscierge is dedicated to improving guest experiences and hotel staff efficiency around the world. Additional information is available at&nbsp;<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="https://www.monscierge.com/">https://www.monscierge.com/</a>.?</p>
<div><i>With all the technology available, why do agencies still struggle with digital ad transparency, reporting and analytics?</i></div><div><br></div><div>We all see advertising on TV, online, in stores, you name it. We intrinsically feel we know what works on us and what doesnt. Of course, were kidding ourselves.</div><div><br></div><div>&nbsp;The best marketers are using fMRI technology to pre-test campaigns. When it comes to reporting and analytics, getting correct and meaningful data is actually very complicated.</div><div><br></div><div>One simple example: a user sees 11 total ads and buys something on your website. &nbsp;So the frequency that helped convert that user was 11, right? Probably not. What if you had two targets, 18-34 year old males, and adults 25-54? Each target audience is shown a different message. This user fell into both, seeing the first message four times and the second message five times. Thats only nine ads. However, thats when the user bought the product. Then the user saw two more ads after buying as part of an upselling re-targeting campaign. So, is the number nine? 11? Or is it four or five? Which ad did the user see first? Last before buying? Does it matter? Now you see why so many buyers say, Ill put that money into TV. At least I know I cant know.</div><div><br></div><div>The transparency, reporting and analytics of digital advertisings effectiveness is also the subject of specific and current debate regarding ROI--fraud. </div><div><br></div><div>In the simplest terms with digital ads, there are two kinds of fraud  the stuff thats easy to detect and the stuff thats next-to-impossible to detect. The first kind is easy. Youre serving 20-30 impressions/day on site xyz.com and getting one click per month. All of a sudden youre serving 5,000 impressions/day on xyz.com and getting 2,000 clicks. Easy to detect and scrub. The second kind could be called the Office Space fraud problem. Youll remember in that movie, their idea was to take the fractions of a penny that remain from bank transactions and feed them into an account. Online fraudsters here are less greedy and run a variety of scams little bits at a time. </div><div><br></div><div>If you read the headlines, its there are billions of dollars being lost to digital ad fraud and everyone should panic. However, when you dig into it deeper, the fraud is pretty highly concentrated. This article, for instance, starts out pretty scary. Then you realize three sources are responsible for 77 percent of this problem. The same is true in display and video ads. Most exchanges and SSPs are really clean. There are a few where its concentrated, and while those names arent published anywhere, theyre well known in off-the-record conversations at industry conferences. Most of us just dont run any ads in that available inventory space.</div><div><br></div><div>Media buyers for digital advertising do know where their ads will run  if theyre working with the right programmatic partner. Our companys blacklist of sites is double the size of most in the industry. We can run on a whitelist model instead. We can run private marketplace deals where buyers are guaranteed a specific amount of inventory from a certain website. Five years ago this was not as easy. Today, any good programmatic partner will share with you every piece of data they have to make it a collaborate effort.</div><div><br></div><div>When it comes to the type of ad measurement tools providing factual, honest and correct levels of ROI, Id ask the same question for every other medium before answering it for digital. Who does this for TV, radio, newspaper, or outdoor? There is no black/white line of its not measurable/its perfectly measureable. Theres a lot of gray, and that gray is very good for marketers. Even within what marketers think should be in the black, such as my consumer saw an ad and then bought a product online, attribution among digital media and offline media sources is not perfect.</div><div><br></div><div>Heres my advice for determining ROI or assigning credit to your digital media channels:</div><div><br></div><div>1)	Expect digital to be more measurable than offline media, but not possess magical powers.</div><div>2)	Dont eschew a model because its not perfect. Did you ever tell your teacher youd rather have a 0 on a test instead of a 75 because neither was 100? Accept progress in the absence of perfection. </div><div>3)	Use some form of attribution that is anything other than last view or last click. While those are better than nothing, youre still getting a 25 on your test and I cant say I feel all that much better with a 25 than a 0.</div><div>4)	Instead of insisting on getting a dollar amount of ratio out of your ROI equation, insist on getting a weather vane that tells you where the wind is blowing. Youre going to spend money marketing your products because we all know it works. So, get tools that tell you this and not that, or this worked slightly better than that. Directional intelligence is still intelligence.</div><div><br></div><div>In summation, ROI is real, and every study weve ever run for a client shows lift in consumer behavior and purchases on exposed users compared to a control. Where I see most advertisers getting into trouble is when they insist on measurement being perfect, or holding different media channels to different standards. All advertising and each media channel contributes to product sales. Its likely impossible to control for all but one variable at any given time and so marketers get frustrated with their inability to know for sure and instead go with what they personally believe works the best. That focus group of one person (meaning the marketer) wastes more money than every other digital media problem combined.</div><div><br></div>

  <h4><b>Giant-Voice Installation at Hawthorne Army Depot Enables SOC Nevada to Meet Mandate<br></b></h4><p><b>Marietta, GA &nbsp; May 20, 2015  </b>SOC Nevada LLC estimates it avoided millions in infrastructure costs by installing a solar-powered, wireless mass notification system consisting of six <a title="Link: http://http://www.imlcorp.com/sc360.html" href="http://http://www.imlcorp.com/sc360.html" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">SoundCommander® SC360</a> speaker systems to cover approximately 212 square miles at the Hawthorne Army Depot, Hawthorne, NV. <br></p>  <p>The US Army mandated the new mass notification system (MNS) to upgrade security at the facility. It serves as a weapons storage and transportation site for branches of the US Armed Services on the West Coast. SOC, the contractor to manage operations and maintain the facility, chose the giant-voice SC360 systems from IMLCORP, Marietta, GA in three configurations because of their power and voice clarity and their manufacturers ability to deliver the solar system to back-up the batteries and the wireless system to communicate with each speaker from a central operations center. And the system fit the budget, too, with the system costing less than 10 percent of a wired installation. <br></p>  <p>Before we installed the new SoundCommander system, we had a single speaker on an industrial building on the base, said David Ellis, Planner/Estimator, SOC Nevada. That just didnt have the capability to provide warnings and instructions for the base in the event of an active shooter, a terrorist attack or any conditions where we need to warn personnel. <br></p>  <p>In addition to warning personnel on the base, the new MNS will be audible to people not connected with any other type of communication system. The base surrounds the city of Hawthorne, with its population of 3,300, and easements allow highways to pass through the area. <br></p>  <p>Installing wired power and communications infrastructure would have faced challenges beyond the estimated expense of as much as $5 million, Ellis noted. The high winds that buffet the area precluded any above-ground lines, and soil conditions for trenching and then housing the lines, plus the marking requirements, made solar and wireless the only viable option. The farthest speaker in the network is located eight miles from the bases operation center. <br></p>  <p>For IMLCORP, the system design and solar/wireless adaptation were straightforward, customized engineering solutions. <br></p>  <p>We used sound measurement equipment to determine how much speaker power was required to provide the required volume levels in all coverage areas, said Frank M. Myers, President and CEO, IMLCORP. That enabled us to configure each of the speaker arrays using our SC360 High Performance Speaker Array (HPSA) systems, all of which have 3600 coverage for optimum performance. For three locations, we installed SC360 Quad Hex systems (four stacked six-speaker arrays). For two locations, we installed SC360 Dual Hex units (two tiers  12 speakers), and one location needed a single SC360 (one tier  six speakers). <br></p>  <p>All of our systems come standard with battery backup, so we already have battery power for our SC360s, he continued. It was just a matter of integrating the solar panels and power controllers with the HPSAs and using wireless IP (internet protocol) to set up the communication system. That enables operators to activate any array at any time and receive full parametric status monitoring at the control center  100 percent of the time, 24/7. They know the status of each array at any time, including battery level, amplifier status, system temperature and whether the system amplifiers cabinet door is open or closed. &nbsp;This level of parametric monitoring not only insures real-time awareness of the systems readiness, but saves maintenance and repair costs by allowing system techs be more efficient and take preventative measures as needed to ensure the system is ready at all times.  We can design and install a mass notification system like this anywhere in the world. <br></p>  <p>The system gets a daily test with the playing of colors at the start of the day and lowering the flag at the end of each day. The music is prerecorded, and the scheduling is automated. <br></p>  <p>I like the way it works, Ellis said. It has simplicity of use and maintenance. We just need to check for the same things at every location. <br></p>  <p><b>About IMLCORP</b><br>Established in 1991 and based in Marietta (Atlanta), GA, IMLCORP develops, manufactures and distributes SoundCommander® loudspeaker systems for tactical operations and emergency mass notification systems, which are part of systems on college and university campuses, military bases and other public venues. Tactical systems have been used at events such as the 2010 earthquake in Haiti, the 2008 Democratic Party national convention in Denver and the 2002 G-8 Summit in Canada. SoundCommander loudspeaker systems have been proven in military operations in Iraq, Afghanistan, Somalia, Bosnia and East Timor. The company also markets the POWRENTRY® Fast Entry/Breaching Tool, Rhino Wheel Boots, Hoop Decon Wash Systems and Blue Water Rescue Ropes. IMLCORP products are sold through GSA, dealers and distributors worldwide. IMLCORP, 869 Pickens Industrial Drive, Suite 15 Marietta, GA 30062 USA. Phone (toll free in the US): 1-866-IML-CORP (465-2677), Worldwide: +1-678- 331-3190, Fax: +1-678-331-3170, <a href="http://www.imlcorp.com" title="Link: null" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">www.imlcorp.com</a>, <a rel="nofollow" target="_blank">sales@imlcorp.com</a>. </p>  <p><b># # # </b><b><br></b></p><p><b>Photo Caption</b><br>IMLCORP installed Sound Commander® SC360 HPSA units such as this at Hawthorne Army Depot as part of a six location mass notification system using all SoundCommander High Performance Speaker Arrays (HPSAs). IMLCORP configured the system to use solar power to maintain full batteries and wireless IP communications to activate any or all speakers to issue warnings and messages over an approximate 212-square-mile area.  </p><p><b></b></p>  <p><b><a title="Link: null" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Note to Editors: Click here for a high-resolution file of this image</a></b> or send an email to Stan Schnitzer (<a rel="nofollow" target="_blank">stan@theschnitz.com</a>) and write SC360 quad image in the subject line.</p>  <p><b>For Additional Information:</b><br>Frank Myers<br>IMLCORP<br>+1-678-331-3190<br><a rel="nofollow" target="_blank">fmyers@imlcorp.com</a> </p>  <p>Stan Schnitzer<br>Schnitzer Associates<br>+1-404-323-6451<br><a title="Link: null" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">stan@theschnitz.com</a><br>Skype: theschnitz<br></p><br><br><br><br>
<p>                                                    <b></b></p>  <p><b>&nbsp;</b></p>  <p><b>&nbsp;</b></p>  <p><b>&nbsp;</b></p>  <p><b>&nbsp;</b></p>  <p><b>&nbsp;</b></p>  <p><b>&nbsp;</b><b>Alliance Will Provide Unparalleled Accuracy for Mobile Ad Targeting</b></p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>PHILADELPHIA, PA - (April 30, 2015)  <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.goodwaygroup.com/">Goodway Group</a>, an industry-leading digital media company with offices across the United States, has forged a new partnership with Factual, the leading location data company in mobile, whose proprietary location platform is greatly improving the accuracy of mobile ad campaigns. Factual is collaborating with Goodways digital team on providing a more relevant and personalized ad delivery experience for mobile users worldwide.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Unlike the majority of digital service providers, who primarily license 3rd party location data, Factuals core expertise is in building high quality location data. These data sets are much more contextual in nature, providing a greater level of accuracy in the customization of ad delivery techniques. The highly targeted approach is achieved by utilizing demographic, audience history and location categorization  all layered with U.S. Census and data from Factuals wide network of partners. </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>The location based capabilities that Factual enables are fast becoming the recognized industry standard for the future of mobile ad targeting. According to the <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.gsmamobileeconomy.com/">Groupe Speciale Mobile Association (GSMA) Intelligence report, Mobile Economy 2015</a>, digital commerce continues to show rapid growth  from $1.7 trillion in 2014 to a projected $3 trillion in 2018. In addition, the report states that mobile commerce is forecast to account for over 20 percent of total digital commerce by 2018.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>By partnering with Factual, Goodway has taken its ad targeting capabilities to the next level of precision, said Jonathan Mellinger, Goodways vice-president of enterprise partnerships. The ad campaigns we intend to create together will significantly move the probability needle toward the ultimate goal  purchasing by mobile users. &nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>As an added bonus to the partnership, Goodways media buying arm will now have access to Factuals custom-built audience segments, all of which are based on location patterns of mobile users. These segments include information on geographic, demographic, and behavioral characteristics, affinities to specific retail brands, and the ability to create custom location based segments via Factuals Tailored Location Segments. This segmented audience access will allow for further fine-tuning of effective mobile ad campaigns.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Factual is excited to empower Goodway Group's 50+ person media trading team with access to our Proximity and Audience media planning tools utilizing our global location data, stated Jeff Dillman, agency &amp; strategic partnerships for Factual. This partnership allows us to provide Goodway Groups clients and agency partners the best in location based consumer insights for the most accurate data mobile ad targeting.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Goodway partners with regional ad agencies to provide clients with advertising solutions in the mobile, online, video and social media categories. Current clients include nationally recognized brands such as McDonalds, General Motors, Porsche and Subaru. For more information, please visit Goodway on the web at <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.goodwaygroup.com/">www.goodwaygroup.com</a>. </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p><b>About Goodway Group</b></p>  <p>Goodway Group is a leading managed-services programmatic partner to local, regional and Fortune 500 brand agencies. Bootstrapped and 100% privately owned since 1929, Goodway moved into the programmatic digital media space in 2006 to continue its rich history of tackling complex local and regional campaign executions with data science-driven targeting and support services to make achieving success easy for agency clients. Its proprietary algorithms pair with a technology-agnostic approach to enable agencies and marketers to achieve their ultimate goal  better results with fewer resources than ever.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p><b>About Factual</b></p>  <p>Factual is a data company that helps make sense of whats happening in the physical world, enabling developers, publishers, and advertisers to build more relevant and personalized mobile experiences using the context of location. Factuals real-time data stack builds and maintains data on a global scale, with Factual's core Global Places data covering over 65 million local businesses and points of interest in 50 countries. Factuals Geopulse products, built on top of its Global Places data, provide industry leading real-time location targeting and location-based audience capabilities. <p><i>Company Will Showcase Media Managers Efficient Suite of Insights, Tracking, and Collaboration at Tech Show</i></p><p>May 20, 2015 | Santa Barbara, Calif. -- Impact Radius,&nbsp;a leading global marketing technology platform, will unveil Media Manager at the Ad Tech San Francisco conference on May 20-21, 2015 at booth #1649. Impact Radius will showcase the newest Big Data solution that will streamline the way marketing experts and top brand names track and attribute their media buys.</p><p>Media Manager is a centralized data hub that gives global advertisers and brands actionable insight into the customer journey and the value provided by their media partners across all digital and offline marketing channels like search, email, affiliate, and mobile.</p><p>We are excited to showcase Media Manager at Ad Tech and demonstrate to industry leaders the necessity of data-driven marketing, said Per Pettersen, CEO of Impact Radius. Media Manager will offer automated data aggregation, configurable data visualization, flexible attribution modeling, and Big Data insights for optimizing marketing spend.</p><p>By combining sales and transaction data together with each consumer touch point in the customer journeys, marketers can use Media Manager to monitor and optimize media buys as well as gain deep, unbiased insights into all marketing channels. Armed with the comprehensive data they require, automated workflows, and complete conversion path tracking, marketing teams and their executives can make smarter decisions.</p><p>"With unbiased data, a customizable dashboard, and a drilled-down customer journey, Media Manager unveils a comprehensive picture of both media mix and advertising spend -- from performance marketing to mobile," said Steve Tazic, Director of Media for Rise Interactive.</p><p>Impact Radius is the only fully-integrated marketing suite to combine management of marketing partnerships, accurate and complete advertising tracking and attribution, mobile solutions, and a comprehensive centralized data hub for marketing teams.</p>
A test case, in software engineering, is a set of conditions under which a tester will determine whether an application, software system or one of its features is working as it was originally established for it to do. The mechanism for determining whether a software program or system has passed or failed such a test is known as a test oracle. In some settings, an oracle could be a requirement or use case, while in others it could be a heuristic. It may take many test cases to determine that a software program or system is considered sufficiently scrutinized to be released. Test cases are often referred to as test scripts, particularly when written - when they are usually collected into test suites.<br><br>In order to fully test that all the requirements of an application are met, there must be at least two test cases for each requirement: one positive test and one negative test. If a requirement has sub-requirements, each sub-requirement must have at least two test cases. Keeping track of the link between the requirement and the test is frequently done using a traceability matrix. Written test cases should include a description of the functionality to be tested, and the preparation required to ensure that the test can be conducted.<br><br>A formal written test-case is characterized by a known input and by an expected output, which is worked out before the test is executed. The known input should test a precondition and the expected output should test a postcondition.<br><br>For applications or systems without formal requirements, test cases can be written based on the accepted normal operation of programs of a similar class. In some schools of testing, test cases are not written at all but the activities and results are reported after the tests have been run.<br><br>In scenario testing, hypothetical stories are used to help the tester think through a complex problem or system. These scenarios are usually not written down in any detail. They can be as simple as a diagram for a testing environment or they could be a description written in prose. The ideal scenario test is a story that is motivating, credible, complex, and easy to evaluate. They are usually different from test cases in that test cases are single steps while scenarios cover a number of steps of the key.<br><br>A test case is usually a single step, or occasionally a sequence of steps, to test the correct behaviour/functionality, features of an application. An expected result or expected outcome is usually given.<br><br>Additional information that may be included:<br><br>Larger test cases may also contain prerequisite states or steps, and descriptions.<br><br>A written test case should also contain a place for the actual result.<br><br>These steps can be stored in a word processor document, spreadsheet, database or other common repository.<br><br>In a database system, you may also be able to see past test results and who generated the results and the system configuration used to generate those results. These past results would usually be stored in a separate table.<br><br>Test suites often also contain<br><br>Besides a description of the functionality to be tested, and the preparation required to ensure that the test can be conducted, the most time consuming part in the test case is creating the tests and modifying them when the system changes.<br><br>Under special circumstances, there could be a need to run the test, produce results, and then a team of experts would evaluate if the results can be considered as a pass. This happens often on new products' performance number determination. The first test is taken as the base line for subsequent test / product release cycles.<br><a href="http://www.soapui.org/testing-dojo/world-of-api-testing/what-makes-api-testing-special-.html">http://www.soapui.org/testing-dojo/world-of-api-testing/what-makes-api-testing-special-.html</a><br>Acceptance tests, which use a variation of a written test case, are commonly performed by a group of end-users or clients of the system to ensure the developed system meets the requirements specified or the contract. User acceptance tests are differentiated by the inclusion of happy path or positive test cases to the almost complete exclusion of negative test cases.
Fitesse is taking the world by storm.
MyPRGenie explains the five basic PR tactics any business can use to spur growth, from creating the right story to selecting the best tools.<br>?<br><br>New York -- Jul 07, 2014 / (<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.myprgenie.com">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Whether your business is a startup, an established small business, or a fast growing company, PR is a tool that can help you gain a competitive advantage.<br><br>Cutting through all of the noise in the marketplace to establish your brand and get the media to pay attention to your company isnt always easy, but its a lot easier if you pay attention to these five basic PR steps that have been proven to help create the buzz that becomes leads or sales.<br><br>In a new post on the companys blog, MyPRGenie shares and explains the five basic PR tactic that have been proven to spur growth for any business. It was launched in 2007 to provide a more effective, efficient tool for businesses to publicize themselves.<br><br>Thousands of companies across the globe have used MyPRGenie to build a comprehensive, PR strategy that increases visibility, and helps monitor and engage their audience.
