                 <p><u>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE</u></p>  <p>Contact: Kerri Steinberg, kstein919@gmail.com<br></p>  <p><b><br></b></p><p><b>University Press Bookstore </b>in <b>Berkeley, CA</b> presents:</p>  <p><i>JEWISH MAD MEN: ADVERTISING AND THE DESIGN OF THE AMERICAN JEWISH EXPERIENCE</i></p>  <p>In-store reading with Author and Art Historian Kerri Steinberg</p>  <p><b>May 27, 2015 @ 6:00 pm  7:30 pm</b></p><p><b><br></b></p><p>May 26th, BERKELEY, CA, Author and Art Historian Kerri Steinberg will be reading from her new book <i><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://universitypressbooks.com/event/jewish-mad-men/?instance_id=956">Jewish Mad Men: Advertising and the Design of the American Jewish Experience </a></i>on May 27th, 2015, 6pm at&nbsp;University Press Bookstore (2430 Bancroft Way Berkeley, CA 94704).&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>It is easy to dismiss advertising as simply the background chatter of modern life, often annoying, sometimes hilarious, and ultimately meaningless. But Kerri P. Steinberg argues that a careful study of the history of advertising can reveal a wealth of insight into a culture. In <i>Jewish Mad Men</i>, Steinberg looks specifically at how advertising helped shape the evolution of American Jewish life and culture over the past one hundred years.<br></p><p><br></p>  <p>Drawing on case studies of famous advertising campaignsfrom Levys Rye Bread (You dont have to be Jewish to love Levys) to Hebrew National hot dogs (We answer to a higher authority)Steinberg examines advertisements from the late nineteenth-century in New York, the center of advertising in the United States, to trace changes in Jewish life there and across the entire country. She looks at ads aimed at the immigrant population, at suburbanites in midcentury, and at hipster and post-denominational Jews today.</p><p><br></p>  <p>In addition to discussing campaigns for everything from Manischewitz wine to matzoh, <i>Jewish Mad Men</i>&nbsp;also portrays the legendary Jewish figures in advertisinglike Albert Lasker and Bill Bernbachand lesser known Mad Men like Joseph Jacobs, whose pioneering agency created the brilliantly successful Maxwell House Coffee Haggadah. Throughout, Steinberg uses the lens of advertising to illuminate the Jewish trajectory from outsider to insider, and the related arc of immigration, acculturation, upward mobility, and suburbanization.</p><p><br></p>  <p>Of <i>Mad Men</i>, acclaimed design critic Steven Heller says, Steinberg explains how Jewish Mad Men wrestled their way into mainstream firms,  and became influential in imagining and promoting the American Dream and the Jewish American version  and how certain brands were advertised to Jews as the staples of an American lifestyle, which helped consumers assimilate into commercial culture.Although there was plenty of anti-Semitism in the so-called white shoe ad world, this book is about the complexity of being Jewish and American in a field whose ultimate goal is to influence Americans daily behavior. Steinberg examines how, in the early 20th century, advertising was used by secular Jews to brand their own people, culture and religion for American public consumption by, among other things, [s]ituating Jewish difference within the spectrum of American pluralism.</p><p><br></p>  <p>Anchored in the illustrations, photographs, jingles, and taglines of advertising, <i>Jewish Mad Men</i>&nbsp;features a dozen color advertisements and many black-and-white images. Lively and insightful, this book offers a unique look at both advertising and Jewish life in the United States.</p>  <p><br></p><p><b>About The Author</b></p>  <p>Kerri Steinberg holds a Ph.D. in Art History from the University of California, Los Angeles, and is a professor at Otis College of Art and Design in Los Angeles. From fashion design through advertising, her work assigns prominence to the role of the visual in reinforcing and producing American Jewish identities, moving issues of visual representation from the sidelines to the center. Her publication record includes articles and reviews on visual culture and American Jewish self-representation. Her book, <i>Jewish Mad Men: Advertising and the Design of the American Jewish Experience </i>(2015)<i> </i>was published by Rutgers University Press.</p><p><br></p><p>SOURCE: Rutgers University Press</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>###</p>
                 <p>Lulutrip Secured Series A1 Financing From Lightspeed&nbsp;<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.reuters.com/places/china?lc=int_mb_1001" title="Link: http://www.reuters.com/places/china?lc=int_mb_1001">China</a>&nbsp;Partners</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Wed Dec 3, 2014 TraveDaily</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>San Jose, CA  December 2, 2014  Lulutrip, Inc., a leading online travel agency focusing on the Chinese outbound travel market, announced today that it has closed its Series A1 financing round from Lightspeed China Partners (LCP), a leading technology venture capital firm in China.&nbsp; Ron Cao, Managing Director of LCP has joined Lulutrips Board of Directors.</p>  <p>Founded in 2007 with offices in Silicon Valley and Shanghai, Lulutrip focuses on enabling Chinese customers worldwide to browse, search, and book destination-based travel products, including tours, activities, and tickets for North America and Europe.&nbsp; Lulutrips competitive advantages include its extensive partnerships with local travel providers, its intelligent tools that help travelers plan customized itineraries, and its market-leading customer services that help to remove obstacles faced by Chinese travelers prior to and during their trips.&nbsp; This unique combination of technology, products, and service have catapulted Lulutrip become a top player in the Chinese overseas travel category.</p>  <p>Lulutrip was co-founded by Jon Jiang, a former technology executive at VMware and EMC, and Faith Zhang, a travel industry veteran in US and China.&nbsp; As the CEO of the company, Jon said, We are extremely excited to have LCP, a top-notch VC, as our partner in capturing this fast growing multi-billion dollar Chinese outbound travel market.&nbsp; President Obamas recent decision to make the ten-year multi-entry visa available to Chinese citizens will further accelerate the growth of this market.&nbsp; The new round of financing will enable us to upgrade our customers experiences both via PC and mobile, as well as to enhance our product portfolio in both breadth and depth.&nbsp; Our goal is to introduce a new travel experience to Chinese travelers, who will enjoy the freedom of customized itineraries at the cost of group tours.</p>  <p>Lightspeed China Partners Managing Director and Co-founder, Ron Cao, commented, We are extremely excited to have formed this partnership with the Lulutrip team.&nbsp; Jon and Faiths vision for the future combined with their strong knowledge in technology and product/services will allow them to continue to make a significant impact in the Chinese overseas travel market.</p>  <p><b>About Lulutrip</b><b><br> </b>Founded in 2007 with offices in Silicon Valley and Shanghai, Lulutrip is a leading online travel agency (OTA) focusing on North American and European destinations for Chinese clients worldwide. Lulutrip.com offers more than 3000 local tour products and 2000 local activity products, and its 24x7 non-stop destination-based customer service is widely regarded in the industry as the best in its class. For more information, please visit <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://ctt.marketwire.com/?release=11G027795-001&amp;id=5080579&amp;type=0&amp;url=http%3a%2f%2fwww.lulutrip.com">http://www.lulutrip.com</a>.</p>  <p><b>About Lightspeed China Partners</b><b><br> </b>Lightspeed China Partners (LCP) is a leading Chinese venture capital firm focused on early-stage investments in Internet, mobile, services and enterprise solutions companies. With a strong background in company operations and entrepreneurship, the partners of LCP are committed to help a new generation of Chinese entrepreneurs become industry leaders, build world-class companies and create social impact. LCP offers international value-added capabilities through its relationship with Lightspeed Venture Partners (LSVP). LSVP is a global venture capital firm managing over $3 billion of committed capital with investment professionals and advisors located in Silicon Valley,&nbsp;<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://in.reuters.com/?lc=int_mb_1001">India</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.reuters.com/places/israel?lc=int_mb_1001">Israel</a>. Over the past two decades, the partners of LCP and LSVP have backed more than 200 companies globally, many of which have become leaders in their respective&nbsp;<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.reuters.com/finance/markets?lc=int_mb_1001">markets</a>. For more information about LCP, please visit&nbsp;<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://ctt.marketwire.com/?release=11G027795-001&amp;id=5080582&amp;type=0&amp;url=http%3a%2f%2fwww.lightspeedcp.com">http://www.lightspeedcp.com</a>. </p>  <p>&nbsp;?</p>
                  <p>Women who love to shop know all about the difficulties of keeping their frequent buyer and loyalty cards organized. It seems almost impossible to be able to locate the right one when you need it, let alone find anything in those oversized, bottomless handbags. Thats why one mom, Wendy Krepak, decided to create her own <a href="http://www.cardcubby.com">card organization system</a> called the Card Cubby. Chosen as a top pick by O Magazine, QVC, The Today Show, People Magazine, and more, Card Cubby is a perfect solution to store loyalty cards, business cards, coupons and more, in&nbsp;a&nbsp;compact and&nbsp;fashionable&nbsp;manner.</p>  <p>I invented the Card Cubby to help people organize all the cards they get while shopping and actually use them to save money. It is stressful when you go to the register and cant find the loyalty card or punch card you know you have. You stand there rooting through your purse while the line lengthens and people behind you get mad, or you forget about it and leave without the discount you know you had! Using the Rolodex style alphabetized filing system can help you easily locate what you need. It is empowering! shares creator Wendy Krepak.</p>  <p>The Card Cubby is a mini <a href="http://www.cardcubby.com">alphabetized card file wallet</a> for all of those gift, frequent buyer, loyalty, insurance, business cards and more! It fits right in your purse, briefcase, diaper bag or car console. The Card Cubby measures 5" wide by 3" high and holds approximately 40 plastic cards or 80 business cards. Card Cubby comes in a variety of colors and styles - function and style all in one. </p>  <p><img alt="" src="http://socialmedia22.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/cardcubby.png"><br></p>  <p><b>Card Cubby Features &amp; Benefits:</b></p>  <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Holds 40 plastic cards or 80 business cards</p>  <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Inside zippered pocket holds change</p>  <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Clear identification window on the back holds your ID</p>  <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Made of imitation leatherette</p>  <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Alphabetized cards inside are color coordinated</p>  <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Care: Wipe clean</p>  <p>The Card Cubby was an instant success, but Krepak didnt stop there. Next came the Coupon Cubby. This stylish, organizing purse has a removable, adjustable strap and 30 dividers with labels. The pre-printed labels have A-Z as well as specifics like makeup, receipts, dairy, and more. There are also blank labels for your own customization. &nbsp;</p>  <p>Now when you are at the store and you know you have that coupon you filed away under the letter J for juice, you can open your Coupon Cubby, find the letter J effortlessly, and voila! In seconds you have found your coupon  and the best part is youre saving money by actually using the coupons you save! shares Krepak.</p>  <p>The Coupon Cubby even has an inside zipper for money and room to hold a cell phone and keys.</p>  <p><img alt="" src="http://socialmedia22.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/couponcubby.png"><br></p>  <p>Card Cubby will soon be expanding its line to include a purse organizer and other stylish organizers for women.&nbsp;</p>  <p>Visit <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://cardcubby.com">http://cardcubby.com</a> to browse the collection and to make a purchase. Card Cubby starts at $23.50 and Coupon Cubby retails for $32.99.</p>  <p><b>To schedule an interview with Wendy Krepak or to request a sample for confirmed media features, contact Giselle Diaz at </b><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow"><b>Giselle@socialmedia22.com</b></a><b> or call Tasha Mayberry at 207.317.6099.</b>&nbsp;</p>  <p>###</p>
<div>LOS ANGELES, May 28, 2015 -- Shopping online for items or services you see in magazines, blogs, or other content websites is about to become much simpler and a lot more exciting. Bringhub (<a href="http://www.bringhub.com">www.bringhub.com</a>), a unique e-commerce platform, will launch at the end of April via a select and growing group of premier publishers and top tier retailers.</div><div><br></div><div>Bringhub enables online shoppers to instantly purchase the goods and services they discover in online content through a checkout that lives directly in the publisher's site. Whether shopping for apparel, consumer goods, tickets, or travel, now readers can purchase multiple products, from multiple stores, all through a single checkoutwithout ever leaving the site they were browsing.</div><div><br></div><div>Bringhub enables varied purchases to be grouped into a single cart, even if the items ordered are fulfilled by multiple retailers. If a consumer is reading an online fashion magazine, for example, and wants to shop for items on its pages, she will be able to purchase those items from one or more retailers in a single, simple, secure transaction. Once the purchases are completed, the consumer can continue to engage with the content she was previously enjoying, so that the publisher never loses its audience.</div><div><br></div><div>"Bringhub is the cutting edge of e-commerce," says co-founder and CEO Dominik Pantelides. &nbsp;"Now, every piece of the web's best content holds the potential to become a point of purchase. Bringhub improves the consumer's experience, while retaining viewers on the original editorial content and offering an exciting range of options to retailers. We see this as a win-win-win situation in a one-stop shopping environment  the era of e-commerce 3.0 is beginning."</div><div><br></div><div>Bringhub was co-founded by Dominik Pantelides, COO Brian Marvin, and CTO Albert Khasky in 2014, and its daily operations are headed by Pantelides, Marvin and Khasky. The company has successfully raised &nbsp;$2M in seed funding through US and international investors including Bill Budinger, Capital Union Investments Hong Kong, BAM Ventures, Canyon Creek Capital, Rachel Zoe Ventures, and many more.</div><div><br></div><div>"Bringhub is the shopping experience for the connected generation," explains Marvin. "It empowers readers to shop their favorite stores directly from their favorite content. It isn't just the ultimate streamlined checkoutit's an entirely reinvented e-commerce experience."</div><div>?<br></div>
<div>Just wanted to take a second to introduce my new start-up, Bringhub, to you. Ive included a short description below but definitely check out our site, <a href="http://www.bringhub.com">www.bringhub.com</a>, which has the functioning Bringhub SmartCart demo on it. (Scroll down about half-way and youll see Hubquire. Just click the Shop Now button.)</div><div><br></div><div>Also, have a look at what Womens Wear Daily wrote (<a href="http://wwd.com/media-news/fashion-memopad/rachel-zoe-ventures-invests-in-software-start-up-bringhub-10104015/">http://wwd.com/media-news/fashion-memopad/rachel-zoe-ventures-invests-in-software-start-up-bringhub-...</a> )</div><div><br></div><div>About Bringhub</div><div>Bringhub is the shopping experience for the connected generation. Now, every piece of the webs best content holds the potential to become a point of purchase. Quickly. Easily. Unobtrusively. Bringhub empowers readers to shop their favorite stores directly in their favorite content. It isnt just the ultimate streamlined checkoutits an entirely reinvented eCommerce experience. Apparel, consumer goods, tickets, or travel, now readers can purchase multiple products, from multiple stores, all through a single checkoutwithout ever leaving the site they were browsing. ?</div><div>Thanks for taking the time to check us out!?</div>
<p>When Vivat (from brands such as SNS Reaal and Zwitserleven) announced it has agreed with a takeover by Anbang, most people never heard of this illustrious and cash-rich Chinese company, let alone the founder Xiaohui Wu, who founded the company only 11 years ago. Telecom giant Huawei, car maker BYD, insurance software developer eBaotech, and diary producer Yili are among the many that have set foot in the Dutch market. Many of the overseas Chinese companies are not state-owned but privately owned, founded and run by star entrepreneurs, who gain celebrity status in China. Who are these entrepreneurs? Where do they come from? What is driving these private companies? </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Not long ago, private entrepreneurs were seen as the signs of unwanted capitalism. In the early phase of opening up, 1978-1992, private companies were merely seen as supplements and had a dubious semi-illegal status; it is the period where Guangqiu Lu's Wanxiang Group, Qinghou Zong 's Wahaha and Chuanzhi Liu's Lenovo were founded or transformed from government organizations to semi-privately run companies. Xiaoping Deng's famous speech in Shenzhen in 1992 endorsed private firms legal status and in the period 1992-2000, a lot of elite entrepreneurs, who previously worked for the government, saw the opportunities that private companies provided; companies such as Lun Feng' s Vantone Group and Dongshen Chen's Taikang Life. Since 2000 China fully endorsed and promoted private entrepreneurship, giving it equal status to the state sector. A group of entrepreneurs with international vision, strong education and high-tech mindset founded firms such as Jack Ma's Alibaba, Yanhong Li's Baidu and Huateng Ma's Tencent. Private entrepreneurs changed from the ugly duckling to the work horses of China; in only 35 years.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>The first generation of entrepreneurs, starting as OEM, can be illustrated by people like Guanqiu Lu, the founder of <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.wanxiang.com/">Wanxiang Group</a>, a Chinese multinational manufacturer of automotive components. Wanxiang was built from Guangqiu Lu's factory of agricultural machines (1969) and is now domestically stock-listed and acquired the leading transportation battery manufacturer <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.a123systems.com/">A123 Systems</a> from USA in 2013. Similarly entrepreneurial in a time of high political risk is Qinghou Zong, the founder of <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.wahaha.com.cn/">Wahaha</a>; Chinas largest beverage manufacturer, employing 30,000 people and internationalizing its brands across the world. </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>The so-called "92 pai" (a term invented by Taikang Life founder Dongshen Chen) is considered the second generation of entrepreneurs. With a clear legal status of private companies after Xiaoping Dengs public endorsement in Shenzhen, many former government officials jumped in to the private sector. People such as Lun Feng founded the Vantone Group in 1996, a company operating in real estate and asset management with total assets over 14 billion RMB (2 billion EURO). Lun Feng used to be a teacher at the Party School of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the breeding ground for top cadres and was senior advisor for the State Commission for Restructuring the Economic Systems, the think tank for China's economic reform. An outspoken person, with influential opinions in China, he has become a critic of China's government policy in the property sectors; a proponent of 'retreating the state and advancing the private sector'. </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>The third generation of entrepreneurs is driven by the IT revolution and is exemplified by the "BAT" entrepreneurs: Baidu, Alibaba and Tencent. Jack Ma founded <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.alibaba.com/">Alibaba</a>s ecommerce platform in 1999, not only operating the worlds largest online business-to-business platform, but also the worlds largest online consumer marketplace. Recently it broke records with the biggest IPO in US history. Alibaba is, together with <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.baidu.com/">Baidu</a> and Tencent, one of the largest investors in Chinas booming high-tech scene with over 15 acquisitions of domestic high-tech ventures last year, fuelling a new generation of entrepreneurs. This new generation may be not as record breaking large scale but does show the potential for radical technology breakthroughs, business models and innovations. </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>A possible fourth generation, sometimes referred to "After 1980s", includes entrepreneurs like Weixing Chen, the founder of Kuaidi Taxi app, and Ou Chen, the founder of <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://jumei.com/">Jumei.com</a> cosmetics. They utilize an emerging mobile internet society as well as showcasing radical business mindsets. While Weixing Chen started a revolution in the taxi world in 2012, Ou Chen transformed the Chinese cosmetics industry in 2010. Kuaidi Taxi app received large investments from the Alibaba Group, Softbank and Tiger Fund. Ou Chen became a Forbes top entrepreneur in 2012 and his company Jumei.com listed May 2014 on the New York Stock Exchange. In particular the very radical entrepreneurs that are often still in their early 20s get more and more attention; IDG, a global venture capital group, has even a special fund for so-called "After 1990s entrepreneurs". </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Concluding, it is not the resource rich large state-owned or foreign companies that transform industries, but generations of private entrepreneurs in a wide variety of traditional and newly emerging industries; domestically and abroad. We have seen only the top of the Chinese iceberg and China's international entrepreneurs are here to stay.?</p>
<p>Online Shopping in China</p>  <p>While many foreign companies are entering Chinas large domestic market via alliances, joint-ventures, franchises and other traditional ways of foreign market entry, some companies are cleverly utilizing the Chinese online shopping platforms, such as Alibabas Taobao. Companies such as Procter and Gamble (P&amp;G) in the United States, De Biasi in Italy, Björn Borg in Sweden or Uniqlo in Japan are cost-effectively tapping into one of the largest online shopper communities in the world. </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Online shopping in China has developed quickly in recent years, yet it is growing at a very fast rate. Nowadays, online shopping has already integrated into peoples daily life in China. China has more than 420 million Internet users and this number is still growing exponentially. More than one third of the Chinese Internet users is shopping online and also this adoption rate is rapidly increasing. For Chinese consumers, the Internet is already an increasingly important, and for some already a routine activity of making a purchase. Chinese Internet users explore the Internet to understand products they are thinking of buying and to hunt for bargains. Taobao is China's largest online shopping platform and was created by its parent group Alibaba in 2003. The online Taobao platform allows sellers and buyers to surf ranging from customer-to-customer (C2C) bazaars to business-to-customer (B2C) branded stores. Taobao reported in June 2012 that it has a staggering number of 500 million registered users and around 800 million product listings.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Market Entry Strategies for China</p>  <p>Meanwhile, the booming of the Chinese online shopping market is very attractive to foreign firms because of its growing consuming power and large consumer base. Due to the geographical diversity, the legal barriers, and lack of customer understanding, this enormous market is less accessible from the outside world. In order to enter this market, and to reduce the investment risks, both foreign-based multi-national corporations and small to medium enterprises have made their presences in the Chinese online shopping market by forming alliances with the Chinese online shopping platform provider. In our research we have seen four different market entry approaches that are very successful. These approaches have a different mixture of onsite and online dimensions; see Figure 1 and Table 1.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Onsite </p>  <p>Advanced&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  </p>  <p>Servicing Strategy&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; (2)</p>  <p>Example: De Biasi</p>  <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  </p>  <p>Integrating Strategy&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  (3)</p>  <p>Example: Uniqlo</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Onsite</p>  <p>Elementary&nbsp; &nbsp;  </p>  <p>Market Testing Strategy&nbsp; &nbsp;  (1)</p>  <p>Example: Procter &amp; Gamble&nbsp; </p>  <p>Enabling Strategy&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  (4)</p>  <p>Example: Björn Borg</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  </p>  <p>Online </p>  <p>Elementary&nbsp; &nbsp;  </p>  <p>Online </p>  <p>Advanced</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Figure 1: Different Market Entry Strategies for China.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>The Market Testing Entry</p>  <p>The first strategy is having distinct but elementary onsite and online dimensions. Take, for example, the entry strategy of Procter &amp; Gamble (P&amp;G)  the American multinational corporation that manufactures a wide range of consumer goods. In 1988, P&amp;G entered into a joint venture with Hutchison Whampoa China Limited (HWCL), one of the largest companies listed on the main board of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, to manufacture products in China and launched its Head &amp; Shoulders shampoo in China. The introduction of this product witnessed huge consumer demand. P&amp;G soon expanded its brand portfolio, entering the skin care market with Oil of Olay. China emerged as P&amp;Gs fifth largest market for Head &amp; Shoulders by 1991, although sales were concentrated almost entirely in Guangzhou and the surrounding region. In 2007, P&amp;G opened its first online store on Taobao  the Gillette Braun brand store and in the same year its second brand store  Oral B Professional Oral Care Center, was opened selling electric toothbrushes, dental films, and oral care products. In April2009, P&amp;G also opened its flagship store on Taobao under the name of eLiving at Home. The P&amp;Gs approach can be described as very low key. Not only does the word P&amp;G not appear in the name of the store, at the top of the front page it is titled P&amp;G official distributor P&amp;G brands flagship store. The company behind this store is Yi Shang Yu Jie Beijing Trading Company. Founded in January 3 2008, Yi Shang Yu Jie is one of the core distributors of P&amp;G (Guangzhou) Limited. The company is the main agent of nine P&amp;G product lines: cosmetic make-up brands, hair brands, personal care and cleaning brands, feminine hygiene products, baby products, oral care products, mens care products, detergent, and packaged food. The prices are much lower than those of the supermarkets. Some special promotional efforts resulted in nearly 50% percent discount. The alliance between P&amp;G and Taobao did not only consider the direct benefits on the sales, moreover it was considered that Taobao could provide its innovative marketing model for P&amp;G. P&amp;G has benefited greatly from a series of online sample distribution of fast moving consumer goods (FMCG) launched by Taobao. P&amp;G accessed the database of the online store on Taobao, effectively targeted consumer groups based on region, occupation, and income. And through distributing samples to the identified targeted groups via Taobao, P&amp;G surveyed market conditions of a variety of products. The results can be used as references for the future product research and development. Within the two months of the opening of the Gillette Braun brand store, more than 2,000 electrical shavers were sold on Taobao. P&amp;G tested the water of online shopping market through the alliance with Taobao. Taobao's large consumer database can be used for sampling and testing of the P&amp;G products, the gathered results can be used in the future product development and product market entry strategy.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>The Servicing Market Entry </p>  <p>In the second type of entry strategy servicing customers is done with a combination of onsite licensing and online service. An excellent example is De Biasis entry strategy in China. De Biasi was founded in 1974 in Murano, an archipelago nearby Venice, when Virgilio De Biasi started his own business, having learnt everything concerning glass bead workmanship from his father. In the 1980s the company exhibited the collections of artifacts decorated with gold and precious enamels in all the well known salesrooms in Murano. The De Biasi artistic pieces can be seen both at the MACEF Fair in Milan, Paris, Madrid, New   York and many other locations. These works are guaranteed as genuine artifacts, made in Murano, as the company is a member of the Promovetro Association, which has the exclusive right to oversee the awarding of the Murano Artistic Merit Trademark. In October 2007, Cristiano De Biasi signed a contract with Beijing SeDuLiuLi Commercial Center, which gave the exclusive rights to Beijing SeDuLiuLi Commercial Center to sell De Biasi jewelry (pendants, rings, earrings and necklace) and clocks in Greater China, Hong Kong and Taiwan. The Italian guests paid Taobao a visit in 2010. Prior to the visit, they still had doubts about the market potential, but when they had seen whats happening at Taobao with their own eyes, they were fully convinced about the potential of the online shopping market in China. However, they still had some concerns about the distribution of counterfeit goods and copycats online. Due to language barriers, they needed to entrust their Chinese partner in the operational details of the online store. Beijing SeDuLiuLi Commercial Center opened their first flagship store on Taobao selling Murano handmade jewelries on 12th October, 2010. De Biasi reached Taobao through its Chinese distributor. The Italian SME sees China as its potential market and via its Chinese distributor, De Biasi jewelry were already been sold through the offline channels in some parts of China. The strategic alliance with Taobao allows the company to sell nationwide with low investment.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>The Integrating Market Entry</p>  <p>The third strategy that could be distinguished is a full integration of the onsite and online dimensions of the market entry in China. The best example is Uniqlo or 'Unique Clothing' that emerged out of Japan's Fast Retailing Company and is a household name in Japan for reasonably priced casual clothing. In 2002 Uniqlo decided to enter the Chinese market. At the time e-commerce just started to emerge and considering the aftermath of the dotcom bubble, Uniqlo concentrated all its resources on the traditional marketing channels, delivering good quality clothes to all for a low price. However, Chinese competition was fierce and in 2005 they had in total only 9 stores, low brand awareness and poor sales revenues and in 2006 Uniqlo withdrew from the market. At the end of 2006 Uniqlo switched its strategic direction and directly targeted the urban middle class and by April 2008, Uniqlo had 11 shops. Then, in 2009, Uniqlo decided to add online channels to stimulate its growth and formed a strategic alliance with Taobao. A flagship store was opened on Taobao's B2C platform (Taobao Mall) in April while at the same time opening an independent e-commerce website. Although the product representation and style differ between these two sites, the data storage, search, transaction, payment were maintained in the same way, using Taobao's architecture and technical support. In contrast to Chinese domestic brands that used the Taobao Mall to sell discounted products to attract buyers, Uniqlo maintained the same pricing strategy for its offline and online products. On the first day, transactions already reached 3,000 with a total transaction volume of 300,000 RMB and within 11 days, 4.1 million RMB was consumed, a number equal to the summed turnover of all the physical stores. At present the annual online turnover is at least 150 million RMB, without affecting the sales in the physical stores which reached 34 stores after the opening of 26 in 2009. The strategic alliance between Uniqlo and Taobao allows Uniqlo to raise its brand awareness among the online shopping customers in a short period of time. Not only have the online sales of Uniqlo increased after the opening of the online flagship store in Taobao mall, the number of offline Uniqlo stores were increased as well.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>The Enabling Market Entry</p>  <p>The fourth strategy that could be distinguished is the Enabling Strategy; distinct but elementary onsite presence and advanced online dimensions. In 2011, Björn Borg decided to enter China and started with setting up a joint venture to handle its distribution in the country. The investing partner, Penny York, has held senior positions since 2004 for the Chinese garment manufacturing and brand company, Dragon Crowd. In August 2012, Björn Borg launched the first shop-in-shop in&nbsp; the&nbsp; Sogo Department store on Shanghais West Nanjing Road, a luxury-shopping street that houses flagship stores of many global brands. It is a safe and easy way to enter China as most brands try to place their flagship stores there, but the whole department store is relatively empty, and their exposure inside this giant mall of brands is not enough to generate big sales. </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>The&nbsp; physical shop is only part of the plan. The company introduces their range throughout the whole of China by opening up an online store on Taobao directly at first entry. Every page on Björn Borgs Taobao store and product pages feature bright branding which signals to consumers that the store is an official, premium flagship store. Björn Borg offered a grand opening launch promotion, with time-limited discounts up to 50% off merchandise exclusive to their Taobao store. In addition, the promotion news was posted on Weibo - a Chinese Twitter - with an external link to the Taobao store. As a matter of fact, Björn Borg began promoting their brand months earlier on Weibo, building their brand story and connecting to the fans that were already talking about their brand. Just like the Weibo account referenced their Taobao store, the Taobao product listings also demonstrate their good reputation on Weibo. Björn Borgs product pages include screenshots from Weibo of people talking about Björn Borg and their affinity for the product line. The combination of Taobao and Weibo is making the brand much more visible and the products more approachable to customers. There will be a number of new stores in Shanghai and the rest of China, aiming for growth through the two channels.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Company Country&nbsp;  First entry&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Online entry&nbsp;  Size Customer</p>  <p>Segmentation&nbsp; Onsite </p>  <p>Dimension&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Online </p>  <p>Dimension</p>  <p>Procter &amp; Gamble&nbsp; USA&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  1988&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  2007&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  MNC&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Lower and middle customer segment&nbsp; &nbsp; Joint-venture (Hutchison Whampoa)&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Partnership with core distributor for online shop (Yi Shang Yu Jie); Online activities for market testing and targeting.</p>  <p>De Biasi&nbsp; Italy 2007&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  2010&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  SME&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  High end customer segment&nbsp;  Licensing (Beijing SeDuLiuLi Commercial Center)&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  Licensing to online shop of licensee (Beijing SeDuLiuLi Commercial Center); Online activities for market entry.</p>  <p>Uniqlo&nbsp; &nbsp; Japan&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 2002&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  2009&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  MNC&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Middle customer segment&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Greenfield investment with own flagship stores&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  Independent e-commerce site; Online activities for brand awareness.</p>  <p>Björn Borg&nbsp; &nbsp;  Sweden&nbsp;  2011&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  2011&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  MNC&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Middle customer segment&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Joint venture for distribution with&nbsp; Dragon Crowd&nbsp; &nbsp;  Online store Taobao; social media Weibo</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Table 1: Characteristics of the Different Market Entry Strategies for China.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Five Lessons Learned</p>  <p>Foreign companies, both MNC and SME, are able to create value through exchange processes of the electronic market and by obtaining strategic resources, aggregated online shopping consumer base and tailored e-commerce services from the Chinese online shopping platform provider. It is important to note that all companies kept and increased their onsite presence in the Chinese market after they moved online. However, the online dimensions are important given the fact that more and more consumers in China are able and are willing to purchase online. </p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>We identified five lessons learned for firms that will enter China. The first lesson is that you need to consider your specific goal: market testing, providing online services, providing integrated online/onsite customer experiences or enabling onsite with advanced online brand promotion. Specifying your goal will enable you to design the right mix of onsite and online dimensions of your market entry strategy. The second lesson is that you need to consider partnering with a local Chinese agent. Following our four cases we then see that a strategy for going alone with your own online flagship store (as in the case of Uniqlo) will utilize the power of the online platform to create brand awareness. In contrast, having a low profile online presence by either not using your brand name or let your local sales agent manage the online store, you are in the position to test the market for new products without running the risk of cannibalizing your brand name (as in the case of P&amp;G) or enter the market as an unknown company with no brand recognition via a well-known local sales agent (as in the case of De Biasi). Lastly, as in the case of Björn Borg, partnering to very quickly build up brand awareness and social media presence are crucial for a successful market entry. The third lesson deals with timing. Conventional wisdom has it that early market entry is better. Indeed, the P&amp;G case show how they reap the benefits from their long presence in China since 1988. However, also for latecomers there is enough space due to the exponential growth of the markets, as the Björn Borg case reveals. The fourth lesson is that for all firms business and IT capabilities were well aligned. Therefore one was capable of discussing and designing the onsite and online dimensions of the market entry strategy in a balanced way. The fifth lesson is that need to be focused and eager to learn from direct Chinese customer experienc or via customer experiences with their Chinese business partners. This open and learning oriented business approach is a critical success factor for developing and implementing a successful market entry strategy.</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p>Although the discussed companies are very diverse in background and experience, they have in common that they follow a strategy combining and balancing online and onsite presence. It is the careful balancing act between the online and onsite presence in China that will create the next generation winners.?</p>
                 <p><strong>FORT LAUDERDALE  </strong>Stellar Homes Group and S&amp;N International are inviting future homeowners, real estate agents and investors to attend this weekends grand opening of <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Piazza Navona</a>, an ultra-luxury townhouse residence in the heart of downtown Fort Lauderdales charming Victoria Park district.</p>  <p>The milestone grand opening starts Saturday, May 30th at 11am. Future residents should call <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow">954-368-1383</a> to schedule an exclusive tour, <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/grand-opening-piazza-navona-townhomes-tickets-17136409462?utm_source=PiazzaNavona&amp;utm_medium=eBlast&amp;utm_campaign=Eventbrite&amp;utm_term=RSVP">RSVP online</a> or simply visit the sales center at <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="https://www.google.com/maps/place/814+NE+7th+St,+Fort+Lauderdale,+FL+33304/@26.1317595,-80.1347293,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x88d901ac4baf26bf:0x4ac33d593f027f24">814 Northeast 7th Street in Fort Lauderdale</a>.</p>  <p>Each of the nine expansive 3-story residences offers private rooftop terraces with spectacular skyline views of downtown Fort Lauderdale and adjacent Holiday Park. Located in a quiet residential neighborhood, Piazza Navona is the epitome of Live, Work and Play. Residents are within walking distance to the acclaimed restaurants, shopping and nightlife of the Las Olas strip, as well as minutes away from the downtown business district, Intracoastal Waterway and pristine South Florida beaches.</p>  <p>There is an increasing demand for luxury living in urban areas throughout South Florida, said Larry Baum, managing partner of Stellar Homes Group. The East Fort Lauderdale and coastal districts are in high demand due to its proximity to the nations finest residential neighborhoods, exciting nightlife, world-class restaurants and shops, depth of culture and accessibility to downtown employment centers. This is the quintessential urban walking neighborhood that is truly unique to Fort Lauderdale.</p>  <p>According to Baum, Piazza Navona offers a lifestyle that appeals to a broad demographic, catering to residents who desire a cosmopolitan South Florida living experience that combines luxury and quality with the benefits of an urban and coastal lifestyle.</p>  <p>Piazza Navona offers nine spacious <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://piazzanavonahomes.com/features/">two- to three-bedroom floor plans</a> from approximately 1,700  2,500 square feet. Designed with high ceilings and hurricane impact windows, the Mediterranean-style units provide abundant views of both cityscape and adjacent park views. Each residence features a private entrance, elevator, high-end finishes including chic European-style kitchen cabinets and stainless steel appliances, in-unit washer and dryer and a private two-car garage.</p>  <p><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Stellar Homes Group</a>, the exclusive sales agent for Piazza Navona, is one of South Floridas top residential developers and real estate agents. Stellar Homes Group maintains an intimate knowledge of South Florida with several years of experience developing luxury residential communities in Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties. Stellar Homes Group is proud to represent a landmark residential project like Piazza Navona.</p>  <p>Learn more about Piazza Navona by visiting <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="http://www.piazzanavonahomes.com">www.piazzanavonahomes.com</a> or by calling Stellar Homes Group at <a target="_blank" rel="nofollow">954-368-1383</a>.&nbsp;</p>  <p>&nbsp;</p>  <p><b>Media Inquiries:</b></p>  <p>Melissa Urrego</p>  <p>954-671-1400 x 105</p>  <p><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow">murrego@shgre.com</a></p>
Movies, music and metadata will be mixed up during the South By Southwest Festival, which kicks off Friday in Austin.<br><br>The 10-day South By Southwest Festival has always been a mashup of movies, music and technology. This year, there's a growing focus on the rise of entertainment apps to help you better enjoy those and other pursuits.<br><br>Movie news and ticketing site Fandango is showing a new movie buzz indicator "Fanticipation" at the Austin festival. By tracking moviegoer interest in new movies on its mobile and Web platform  and early ticket sales  Fandango hopes to provide an early take on weekend box-office performance with the new ranking.<br><br>"There is some degree of excitement that people generate from looking at the results of the box office after the weekend," says Fandango president Paul Yanover. "This allows people to get that same kind of interest without waiting for the box office."<br><br>The new feature will appear on Fandango.com and in a new weekly video series, "Weekend Ticket," in which host Dave Karger will use the Fanticipation data to inform moviegoers of the weekend's most anticipated movies and, subsequently, help pair viewers with the best choice among the new releases. The first episode, to be filmed at SXSW, will include interviews with the cast of The Incredible Burt Wonderstone (including Jim Carrey, Steve Carell and Olivia Wilde). The film has its U.S. premiere Friday night at the festival.<br><br>An upcoming update to Fandango's mobile app will allow the video to play on mobile devices.<br><br>AMC Networks, which owns several cable networks including AMC and Sundance Channel, is announcing Yeah!, a new video streaming service, at the festival. The small start-up-style venture within the company launches with a library of 14 pay-per-rental films ($4.99 for a rental that lasts 30 days, though once you start watching you must finish within 48 hours), each enhanced with cast and filmmaker interviews, trivia and quizzes.<br><br>Initially, the offerings target young male audiences with films such as Natural Born Killers and Reservoir Dogs, but the library will expand with a movie each week. On the way: Caddyshack and Ocean's Eleven.<br><br>Movie lovers can watch now on www.yeahtv.com; the iPad app is due this summer. Additions to Natural Born Killers include new hour-plus interviews with cast members Juliette Lewis and Tom Sizemore. Viewers can go back and forth between the interviews and movie.<br><br>New facts about the movie pop up constantly below the film video. (One Killers example: Some actors and crew ate hallucinogenic mushrooms on the set where the characters do in the film.) Users can share their activity on social networks as well. "We look at this as being an innovative new way to experience the movies that you love and already have a relationship with," says Lisa Judson, general manager of Yeah TV!<br><br>SXSW is "an intersection of entertainment and interactive, but more importantly it's a statement of innovation," Judson says. "It is the perfect place for us."<br><br>Web-based movie company Tugg.com, which bowed last year at SXSW, will be touting new features to help film lovers attract smaller independent and older event-type movies to their local theaters  and assist promoters in connecting with moviegoers; a mobile app is being considered. "Much like South by Southwest, Tugg is working to bridge the divide between tech and film," says co-founder Nicolas Gonda. "Using the Tugg platform enables filmmakers to directly engage with their communities and audiences to better support a film's release in theaters."<br><br>Thousands of musicians, from Macklemore &amp; Ryan Lewis, the alt-rap duo behind sleeper hit Thrift Shop, to Green Day, will be packing venues from corner music bars to Austin City Limits Live. Music app purveyors such as streaming service Spotify will set up residence for four days in downtown Austin inviting festivalgoers to listen to live acts and a DJ. Also on the scene: music sharing site Soundcloud will host a party and announce updates to its service.<br><br>And start-up EvntLivewill reveal its plans to integrate mobile devices into live concerts and stream sold-out gigs to smartphones, tablets and computers, creating "a new type of experience for music fans that simulates the experience of actually being there," says co-founder David Carrico. "At a physical concert, you would chat with your friends, purchase merchandise, and see different angles of the show. We are able to bring those experiences to you wherever you are."<br><br>The mix of technology and entertainment at SXSW means "a higher concentration of the pacemakers of technology are there," says Brian Blau, research director in consumer services for research firm Gartner. "In today's world, where we are all hyper-connected through our smart devices and we are trying new things all the time, South By Southwest embodies all of that."<br><br>In the past, apps such as Twitter and Foursquare gained momentum at SXSW. Twitter's recently launched video app Vine is expected to be used my many festival attendees to share experiences  and gain viral traction. New calendar and contact apps such as Evernote Hello (evernote.com) and Tempo (Tempo.ai) might earn followers who test them out to juggle the busy conference, which drew 300,000 attendees across all the festivals last year, according to Austin-based app company Rocksauce Studios.<br><br>Silicon Valley start-up 1World aims for something completely different. Its new app, launching at SXSW, helps users make up their minds about hot-button topics of the day in news, politics and ethics. The new app and website (www.1worldonline.com) lets you read opinions on various sides of an issue and vote in polls.<br><br>When you vote, you see how the group of 1World users came down on an issue, with breakdowns by sex, marital status and political alignment (Republican, Democrat, Moderate, etc.). "You can see our society is getting polarized. It's becoming a real problem," says 1World Online CEO Alex Fedosseev. "One of the things we are trying to do is reduce this polarization and help people find some common ground. At least people will be able separate opinions from facts."<br><br>Just as many employees are working on top-notch commentary as on the technology needed to crunch user opinions, he says. At SXSW, Fedosseev says, "we aspire to be like Twitter.  We are confident our technology is going to make a big splash."
SAN JOSE, Calif., Jul 01, 2013 (BUSINESS WIRE) -- 1World Online, a new social opinion polling and data analytics company, today announced the first closing of its Series A round and unveiled its monetization strategy, which will leverage the company's proprietary polling and research technologies to provide market trends and analysis and Big Data insights into the customers of its customers. The funding, which was for $1 million, was completed on April 28, 2013 and all money previously collected via convertible debt were converted into equity. The money is being used to go to market, including launching the 1World service, hiring key staff and conducting initial sales.<br><br>Through the newly launch B2B subscription service, 1World customers will now be able to glean unique and valuable insight on consumer opinion in order to identify and respond to key market trends earlier than was previously possible. 1World's timely polls provide businesses with the ability to perform fast and effective consumer market research, in near real-time, and keep their finger on the pulse of target markets.<br><br>1World presents consumers with a multitude of issues as single-question polls in the form of a fun, informative and easy-to-use social media application. Results of the crowd-sourced voting provide insights into public opinion, consumer sentiment, trends and behavioral intentions. Responses are broken down by gender, marital status, age, education level, political affiliation and income level - immediately providing businesses with a wealth of culturally relevant information that would have previously taken weeks, months, or even longer to acquire.<br><br>"1World offers a unique view of the world - a view through the consumer's eyes. The quality of the data we gather is unparalleled by legacy polling companies," said Alex Fedosseev, co-founder and chief executive officer of 1World Online. "1World is responding to an unmet demand from businesses to obtain accurate, quantifiable and comprehensive data on what people really think. Furthermore, we're fast and completely current. We've got specialists dedicated to identifying the latest and most engaging topics and immediately analyzing public opinion, both as of the moment and trending over time. We're applying the quick and innovative startup approach to polling and it's paying off."<br><br>1World has over a dozen firms in beta or deployment stages of the service and first revenue from the service has been booked. For more partnership information or to inquire about using a 1World Poller on your site, please contact brad@1worldonline.com.<br><br>1World Online is based in Silicon Valley with offices in San Jose, Calif. The 1World Online service is available now on the Web at 1Worldonline.com, for iPhone in the App Store and for Android devices in Google Play. Please visit us at <a href="http://www.1WorldOnline.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.1WorldOnline.com</a>.
1World Online is a Silicon Valley-based start-up providing an innovative social research service to help understanding what people really think on a variety of issues. Inside Investor spoke to CEO&nbsp;Alex Fedosseev about his idea.<br><br>Q: How did you come about 1World Online, and how was it formed?<br><br>A: There are two parts of the story. We were looking for the real opinion gap, problems people cannot solve. And we saw that there is no central platform to find out what people really think about various things or topics. We wanted to find out. Usually, people end up in Google or Wikipedia with their questions and try to make sense of links, but there is still a lack of quantifiable data to see how people react to the news. The second part was pretty simple. I already have been involved&nbsp; in three start-ups which all exited, and then I decided to come up with a content platform. I saw that there was no existing way of expressing what one thinks on the Internet, only surveys or posts out there. What we did was to collect questions and posts and then provide people with choices , supported by data points and expert opinions to get quality answers. Thats how the service was born.<br><br>Q: Who benefits from this?<br><br>A: There is a consumer benefit by learning, but companies like to know what people think and want to break down and process the data. What we see from our studies is that consumer behaviour is not so much determined by age or gender or other statistical factors, but by personality. We are opening a two-way street between consumers and companies.<br><br>Q: Should market researchers like Nielsen be worried?<br><br>A: Yes they should, and in a whole new way. There is a new world of social media, and people provide feedback instantly. There needs to be new instruments to measure this, and additional and multiple sources of data on top of the usual data collected. Results need to be made comparable to understand what people want.<br><br>Q: What have been your accomplishments so far?<br><br>A: We became partners of IBM and Microsoft in big data. Weve got a really good traction here, and there are quite a few programmes running at the moment. We also have corporate customers that are using our services, for example Netg ear and Greenwave, and content providers and multimedia magazines that want to maximise social traffic. We provide a dialogue, which is good for both consumers and for companies, and they like it because they can interact with their customers. Facebook and these things are today used by everybody, but the form of interaction is not always what companies want.<br><br>Q: Are there any plans to go out to other markets such as Asia?<br><br>A: We built out platform so that everyone can participate and thus we also want to provide languages other than English  we already started with Spanish. However, to expand to Asian countries, for example, we need to have a vocal team there that understands the interest and the certain topics of a region. But yes, we want to go there, its only a matter of timing and execution. I did similar things with my previous companies.<br><br>A: Where do you see your company in 2014?<br><br>Q: We are really growing, and I see more and more expert discussions from different countries happening on 1World Online. My ultimate vision, which might take up to three years to realise, would be that we become a fixed part of a popular and international social media platform and provide detailed data on countries and people.
SAN JOSE, Calif., July 28, 2014 /PRNewswire/ --&nbsp;1World Online, an engagement applications, content, and analytics platform company, today announced the official launch of its international market expansions, and also that the firm received an industry-wide award as a top global company. 1World is launching today 1World Europe and 1World Asia. &nbsp;In related news, 1World has been chosen by AlwaysOn as one of the Global 100 Companies to Watch.&nbsp; <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  "It's an honor to be selected as a top global company as just a three-year old enterprise," said Alex Fedosseev, CEO and co-founder of 1World, "it shows I think the tremendous value we have created for our partners, and for social research and engagement on the Internet around the world. Our name '1World' illustrates that we always had the vision to be a global company. And since we've launched our 2.0 Platform earlier this year, our service usage, overall traffic, and membership count have been in a hockey stick growth mode. We have achieved a working model providing high-value to web publishers trying to better engage their users and learn more about them, as well as to end-users trying to determine, on almost any particular topic, what do people really think?"<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  Some recent milestones for 1World including having passed 300 partners and customers using its Software-as-a-Service web publisher system, over one-million votes in its popular 1World Poller engagement application, and exceeding 400,000 end-user memberships to its opinion and social research service. The 1World service is also being used in over 200 countries today. <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  To facilitate its growing list of customers and soon-to-be announced partnerships, 1World is expanding internationally.&nbsp; The 1World Development Center, staffed already in Europe with part of the company's technical team, is being expanded and a new office has been opened in Setubal, Portugal, which will also be the regional business development and sales office for 1World. The 1World EU Office will handle the entire EMEA (Europe-Middle East-Africa) region for sales and business activities.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  In Asia, 1World is working with Defta Partners, a recent investor in 1World, to enter the Japanese market.&nbsp; In China, 1World recently became a portfolio company of Hanhai Investment, and will be leveraging this new relationship to enter the Chinese market later this year. 1World will have offices and operations within and among the respective eco-systems of these partners to serve the Asian region.&nbsp; <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  Defta Partners and Hanhai Investment are joining 1World's previous financial backers; this includes, beyond the founders, a dozen prominent Silicon Valley early stage investors, such as Keiretsu Forum and Fifth Era.&nbsp; 1World was started in 2011 in San Jose, CA, began east coast USA operations last year, and is now formally expanding throughout Europe and Asia with local presences.&nbsp; <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  1World also today announced that it was named a Global 100 Companies to Watch. This is an annual landscape survey by AlwaysOn, winners considered top among its peers and with game-changing approaches that are likely to disrupt existing markets and entrenched players. 1World was specifically selected by the AlwaysOn editorial team and industry experts spanning the globe based on a set of five criteria: innovation, market potential, commercialization, stakeholder value, and media buzz.&nbsp; The winners were selected from among many hundreds of other technology companies nominated by investors, bankers, journalists, and industry insiders.&nbsp; The AlwaysOn editorial team conducted a rigorous three-month selection process to finalize the 2014 list.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  1World and the AlwaysOn Global 100 Companies to Watch will be honored at AlwaysOn's tenth annual Innovation Summit at the Computer History Museum on July 29th and 30th, 2014.&nbsp; 1World will be at the event demonstrating its solution on July 29th and Mr. Fedosseev will address the entire audience that day as well.&nbsp; <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  Please contact sales@1worldonline.com with interest in value-added reselling the 1World Consumer Intelligence Platform solution to web publishers in Europe or Asia, or info@1worldonline.com if you are a company or end-user wanting to adopt the web-site engagement applications, hyper-sharable content, market research, or customer analytics tools that 1World offers.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  About 1World Online 1World Online has developed and maintains a Consumer Intelligence Platform providing simple but effective engagement applications, unique-engaging content, ongoing market research, and insightful end-user analytics of their customers tapping into the Platform. 1World is headquartered in Silicon Valley and has offices in San Jose, CA, on the USA East coast, and now in Europe and soon Asia as well. SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 15, 2014 /PRNewswire/ --&nbsp;1World continues its momentum with three related announcements as it has 1) become the leader in its sector as according to the independent Alexa rankings, 2) is announcing today the acquisition of Flipter, the leading opinion gathering and online polling vendor in Latin America, and 3) has won 2014 OnMedia 50 Companies to Watch honors from AlwaysOn.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  By combining attractive and engaging online polling and debating solutions with expert opinions and data points, 1World's service allows companies to engage their audience through attractive "native polls", increase site traffic, accurately discover customer opinions, and collect valuable data.&nbsp; Already present on over 400 sites such as the San Francisco Examiner, Blog Catalog (largest blogging network in the world with over 400,000 member blogs), and Project Syndicate (a site which features editorial opinions from world-famous experts from around the world) the user-friendly platform offers an expansive suite of features and online product modules. <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  "By being at the forefront of the web engagement and social research spheres, publishers can use our 1World model to compliment their content via native polling and related solutions. Our platform builds 'smart profiles' of readers and site users, giving publications a much richer data set that includes not only demographic information, but invaluable behavioural, psychographic, and brand-preference information," explained Damien Leostic, CPO, 1World co-founder, and former Product Line Director at Motorola Mobility and Google. <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  1World has been in "hockey stick" growth mode for its service over 2014 and has recently surpassed its 750,000th member-user and is regularly logging now over 10M user sessions on a monthly basis.&nbsp; Thus, it is no surprise that starting in August 1World became the highest ranked engagement application and polling vendor on the Internet, according to Alexa rankings, an independent web site popularity measurement service.&nbsp; <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  1World also is announcing today its first MA of its short, three year history.&nbsp; 1World has come to terms on the acquisition of Flipter, the leading opinion gathering polling tool in Latin America.&nbsp; Flipter will become 1World's Latin America division, serving both Central and South America.&nbsp; Terms of the deal are not being made public, but Flipter will now begin to operate as 1World Latin America and over time Flipter customers will be transitioned to the 1World multi-lingual publisher platform.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  1World has been winning awards and accolades of late, and the recent selection to the OnMedia 50 list of the leading digital media market entrants is a direct reflection of the success the company has achieved throughout 2014.&nbsp; The OnMedia 50 winners were selected from among hundreds of other technology companies nominated by investors, bankers, journalists, and industry insiders.&nbsp; The AlwaysOn editorial team conducted a rigorous three-month selection process to finalize the 2014 list.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  About 1World Online1World Online has developed and maintains a Consumer Intelligence Platform providing simple but effective engagement applications, unique-engaging content, ongoing market research, and insightful end-user analytics of their customers tapping into the Platform. 1World is headquartered in Silicon Valley and has offices in San Jose, CA and on the USA East coast. Internationally, 1World has operations in Europe, India, now Latin America, and soon Asia as well. The 1World service is available on the Web at 1Worldonline.com, for iPhone in the App Store and for Android devices in Google Play and for Windows 8 in Windows Store. February 10, 2015  San Jose, CA - continues its momentum and international growth for 2015 via the announcement of seven new equity-holding advisors to its advisory board and the opening of new international offices.<br><br>The new advisors to the prestigious 1World World Advisory Board include:<br><br>Mr. George Hara and his firm, DEFTA Partners, are the lead investors in the companys latest financing and is advising and leading initiatives for 1World in the Japanese market.<br><br>Mr. David Schlesinger&nbsp;is intellectually leading 1Worlds entry into Asia, in particular into China.&nbsp; Mr. Schlesinger was the Chairman of Thomson Reuters China until August 2012, and was previously the global Editor-in-Chief of Reuters news.&nbsp;He holds a Lifetime Achievement Emmy Award for Business and Financial Reporting.<br><br>Mr. Sean Koh has taken a leading stake in 1World to facilitate partnership initiatives in Korea and entertainment industry in general. Mr. Koh is a third-generation Korean family industrialist and successful modern-day capitalist, bridging Korea and the USA.<br><br>Mr. Gregory Mark Hill and Mr. Peter Saulnier, principals of Merchant Banker GCH Partners, are advising 1World on Social Impact implications of the 1World platform, coordinating select strategic partnerships, and advising on pre-IPO and mid-market considerations.<br><br>Mr. Richard Hecker, a New York City digital media technology veteran and founder of Traction &amp; Scale, LLC, is helping 1World on business development and strategy.<br><br>Mr. Dan Reich is a New York City entrepreneur,&nbsp;a writer for Forbes, and a successful entrepreneur having co-founded Spinback which was acquired by Buddy Media which in turn was acquired by Salesforce.com<br><br>Mr. Gene DeRose, a Research and Online service industry veteran, ex-CEO and President of Jupiter and now Managing Partner of NYC-based 1World Ventures.<br><br>The new members join the current 1World advisor board that started in 2012 and includes Matthew Le Merle (General Partner, Keiretsu Capital), Rob Enderle (famous tech analyst and writer), John Ricci (head of US Angels), Kira Makagon (CTO of RingCentral, Scopus, Octane Software), Greg Kahn (media and technology consultant), Michael Minkevich (VP, Technology Services at Luxoft), Nate Williams (former Google executive), Ted Sanford (founder and CEO Flashsoft), and Dr. Augie Grant (renowned researcher and writer).<br><br>1Worlds engagement applicationssupporting eight languages today, growing to over a dozen in 2015- include content, and analytics tools allows web-based operations to better engage their audiences, conduct customer analytics and market research, and enjoy various monetization programs. The benefits of using the 1World solution are an increase in user session times and page views, an ability to attract returning visitors, methods to accurately discover visitor opinions, and the power to effortlessly collect valuable data for advertisers, sponsors, and partners. Already present on over 500 web sites around the world such as Reuters in multiple countries, The Huffington Post, San Francisco Examiner, The Blaze, Peru.com, Mexico2014.com, Liga.net, Global Editors Network (GEN), the Reuters Foundation, Blog Catalog (largest blogging network in the world with over 400,000 member blogs), and Project Syndicate (a site which features editorial opinions from world-famous experts from around the world), Le Tribune (France), and El Universal (South Americas leading publisher). The 1World user-friendly platform offers an expansive suite of features and online product modules for publishing-focused or high-traffic web sites.<br><br>1World, headquartered in San Jose, CA, in early 2014 opened regional offices on the USA East coast with presences in Boston and New York. Internationally in the second half of 2014, 1World set-up its second European office in UK (adding to the two-year old office in Ukraine), established an office in Mexico recently covering all of Latin America via its acquisition of Flipter.com, began operating an India country office with locations centered in Gujarat and Mumbai, is able to cover Japan now through its affiliation with Defta Partners and new advisor George Hara, and is able to cover China and establishing new clients and partnerships which will be announced in 2015 via its new advisors David Schlesinger, Donald Yu, and Gregory Mark Hill.<br><br>1World, to its namesake, has always had an international ambition and focus, and it has now emerged as one of the differentiators the company enjoys helping to propel 1World to #1 status among all its competitors, as measured by the independent Alexa rankings. 1Worlds Global Exchange network uniquely allow for syndication of online opinion gathering apps-- polls, debates, quizzes, surveys, or info-graphical interactive appsso as to enjoy user/visitor engagement while conducting market research and audience analytics. Please contact 1World if you want to increase engagement on your web site, increase audience insights, and add new revenue models to your business and we welcome international or multi-lingual web site partners.<br><br>1World Online has developed and maintains a Web Engagement and Analytics Platform providing simple but effective engagement applications, unique-engaging content, ongoing market research, and insightful end-user analytics of their customers. 1World is headquartered in Silicon Valley and has offices in San Jose, CA and on the USA East coast.
