Billy Dorsey, who was homeless just over ten years ago, is now a Grammy, Dove and Stellar award-winning producer and credits every success to God. His personal example of hope, service and commitment to God caught the eye of Joel Osteen, Americas most famous pastor.<br><br>I believe in Billy because of what he came through, what he stands for, his heart to help other people, and his desire to not get stuck where he was, Pastor Osteen said to Rick Rowe (ABC News  KTBS 3). But he continues to rise higher and bless others. And thats what our ministry is about. Thats what Billy is about.<div><br></div><div><div><iframe frameborder="0" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/6HeJfY1vPA4" width="560" height="315"></iframe></div>Dorsey, who is an Outreach Worship Leader at Lakewood, spends much of his free time serving people in Houstons 5th ward. When he is not serving, he pursues his passioncreating compelling, uplifting music that brings people closer to Christ. Billy debuted Give You Jesus the first single from his sophomore album Masterpiece in a live performance at the church back in May. <br><br>He remembered me when I was lost. He remembered me when I was homeless. He remembered me when I didnt have anything and I cried out to him. He answered me and hes kept every promise, Dorsey said in an exclusive interview with Rowe (KTBS 3). I want everybody that knows my name to know his name. I want them to see him when they see me. I want them to understand that hes faithful. And that if hes done these things for me hell do it for them too.</div><h3>About Billy Dorsey</h3><div>Grammy, Dove and Stellar award winning producer Billy Dorsey is more than a musicianhe is a minister. Dorsey has worked with notable artists including Andy Mineo, 2 Chainz, 10th Avenue North, Day 26 Tedashii, August Alsina, and Lecrae. In additional to professional success Billy is active in ministry as an outreach pastor at Lakewood Church (Joel Osteen), has spoken on a panel at The Potters House (Bishop TD Jakes), and has appeared on Bobby Jones Gospel (Centric) and Praise the Lord (TBN-Houston). Learn more at <a href="http://www.BillyDorsey.com">www.BillyDorsey.com</a>.<br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Media Contact:</b> Makasha Dorsey | makasha@DGPRwire.com&nbsp;| <a target="_blank">334.246.1170</a>&nbsp;| Twitter: @Makasha<br></div>
WASHINGTON, July 2, 2015 /PRNewswire-USNewswire/ -- As Americans are into their summer travel, nearly 89 million (57 percent) who plan to vacation in a U.S. city say they will use&nbsp;public transportation for at least one activity this summer.&nbsp; More than 156 million Americans in total plan to travel to a top U.S. city this summer (24 percent increase). This continues a trend from recent years. The American Public Transportation Association's (APTA) annual&nbsp;"Travel Like a Local" Summer Travel Survey&nbsp;reports that public transportation will be highly utilized by these travelers looking for the most cost-effective and worry-free form of transportation.&nbsp; <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  Millennials and adults under 45 continue to embrace use of public transit during vacations.&nbsp; Among millennials (18-34) and adults under 45, 68 percent confirmed that they plan to use public transportation during their trip to a major U.S. city or metropolitan area this summer. According to the travel survey, public transportation options make travel more cost effective and stress free for all ages. <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  "As the number of city visitors and tourists continue to increase, public transit systems not only serve as a reliable and affordable way to get around but provide a great way for visitors to experience the local flavor of a community and all that it has to offer," said APTA President  CEO Michael Melaniphy. "In addition, our industry's use of smart phone apps and other tools help visitors easily navigate a city that is new to them."&nbsp; <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  The data show that a city traveler's strongest reason for choosing public transportation is eliminating the need for a parking space with 71 percent of respondents noting this while 67 percent say that it is more affordable than taxis or rental cars. Other reasons included cutting down on the cost of gas (51 percent) and minimizing the stress of driving in an unfamiliar city (55 percent). <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  Forty-eight million vacationers will use public transportation to experience restaurant dining and local nightlife, while 53 million say they will use it while sightseeing. An equal 45 percent of travelers expect to utilize public transit for travel to and from their place of lodging and to and from airports. <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  These travelers are flocking to destinations all across the country. The hottest urban travel destination for 2015 was once again New York City followed by the 14 additional cities:&nbsp;&nbsp;<br><br><br><br><br>1. New York&nbsp;<br><br><br>9. Seattle&nbsp;<br><br><br><br>2. Chicago<br><br><br>10. Washington, DC&nbsp;<br><br><br><br>3. Los Angeles<br><br><br>11. Boston&nbsp;<br><br><br><br>4. Atlanta&nbsp;<br><br><br>12. Miami&nbsp;<br><br><br><br>5. Las Vegas&nbsp;<br><br><br>13. Houston&nbsp;<br><br><br><br>6. Dallas&nbsp;<br><br><br>14. San Diego&nbsp;<br><br><br><br>7. Orlando&nbsp;&nbsp;<br><br><br>15. Portland<br><br><br><br>8. San Francisco&nbsp;<br><br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  &nbsp;<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  As Americans embrace city vacations, APTA is issuing a series of insider guides for some of the top city destinations. These tips provide insight into a local public transit system's unique characteristics, unspoken protocols and general advice to help vacationers "travel like a local" and avoid public transit faux paux. This information shows how easy it is to navigate a city by using the local public transit system.&nbsp;<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  For more details on how you can "Travel Like a Local" this summer, visit&nbsp;<a href="http://www.publictransportation.org">www.publictransportation.org</a>.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  The APTA 2015 "Travel like a Local" Summer Travel Survey was conducted by TechnoMetrica Market Intelligence and includes 1,005 interviews using a Random Digit Dial sample of both landline and cell phone numbers. At the 95 percent confidence level, the margin of error is +/-3.2 percentage points.<br><br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  The American Public Transportation Association (APTA) is a nonprofit international association of 1,500 public and private sector organizations, engaged in the areas of bus, paratransit, light rail, commuter rail, subways, waterborne services, and intercity and high-speed passenger rail.&nbsp; This includes: transit systems; planning, design, construction, and finance firms; product and service providers; academic institutions; transit associations and state departments of transportation.&nbsp; APTA is the only association in North America that represents all modes of public transportation. APTA members serve the public interest by providing safe, efficient and economical transit services and products. More than 90 percent of the people using public transportation in the United States and Canada ride APTA member systems.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  Contact: Chad Chitwood(202) 496-4841cchitwood@apta.com<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  &nbsp;<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									 			   		  	 		  			   										<br>										 										SOURCE  American Public Transportation Association (APTA) 			   		  	 	 RELATED LINKS<br>	 		  		  		  <a href="http://www.publictransportation.org">http://www.publictransportation.org</a>
<p>Beavers, along with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geomyidae">pocket gophers</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heteromyidae">kangaroo rats</a>, are <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castorimorpha">castorimorph</a>  rodents, a suborder of rodents mostly restricted to North America.  Although just two closely related species exist today, beavers have a  long fossil history in the Northern Hemisphere beginning in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eocene">Eocene</a>, and many species of giant beaver existed until quite recently, such as <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trogontherium">Trogontherium</a></i> in Europe, and <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castoroides">Castoroides</a></i> in North America.</p> <p>Beavers are known for their natural trait of building dams on rivers  and streams, and building their homes (known as "lodges") in the  resulting pond. Beavers also build canals to float building materials  that are difficult to haul over land.<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaver#cite_note-Salvesen-3">[3]</a><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaver#cite_note-4">[4]</a>  They use powerful front teeth to cut trees and other plants that they  use both for building and for food. In the absence of existing ponds,  beavers must construct dams before building their lodges. First they  place vertical poles, then fill between the poles with a crisscross of  horizontally placed branches. They fill in the gaps between the branches  with a combination of weeds and mud until the dam impounds sufficient  water to surround the lodge.</p> <div> <div><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Beaverbones.jpg"><img src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Beaverbones.jpg/300px-Beaverbones.jpg" alt="" height="186" width="300"></a> <div> </div></div></div><div><div><div> A beaver skeleton</div> </div> </div> <div> <div><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Beaver_skeleton.jpg"><img src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Beaver_skeleton.jpg/300px-Beaver_skeleton.jpg" alt="" height="190" width="300"></a> <div> </div></div></div><div><div><div> A beaver skeleton</div> </div> </div> <p>They are known for their alarm signal: when startled or frightened, a  swimming beaver will rapidly dive while forcefully slapping the water  with its broad tail, audible over great distances above and below water.  This serves as a warning to beavers in the area. Once a beaver has  sounded the alarm, nearby beavers will dive and may not reemerge for  some time. Beavers are slow on land, but are good swimmers, and can stay  under water for as long as 15 minutes.</p> <p>Beavers are herbivores, and prefer the wood of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quaking_aspen">quaking aspen</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populus_sect._Aegiros">cottonwood</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willow">willow</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alder">alder</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birch">birch</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maple">maple</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cherry">cherry</a> trees. They also eat <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedges">sedges</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pondweed">pondweed</a>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nymphaeaceae">water lilies</a>.<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaver#cite_note-5">[5]</a></p> <p>Beavers do not hibernate, but store sticks and logs in a pile in  their ponds, eating the underbark. Some of the pile is generally above  water and accumulates snow in the winter. This insulation of snow often  keeps the water from freezing in and around the food pile, providing a  location where beavers can breathe when outside their lodge.</p> <p>Beavers have webbed hind-feet, and a broad, scaly tail. They have  poor eyesight, but keen senses of hearing, smell, and touch. A beaver's  teeth grow continuously so that they will not be worn down by chewing on  wood.<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaver#cite_note-6">[6]</a> Their four incisors are composed of hard orange enamel on the front and a softer <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dentin">dentin</a>  on the back. The chisel-like ends of incisors are maintained by their  self-sharpening wear pattern. The enamel in a beaver's incisors contains  iron and is more resistant to acid than enamel in the teeth of other  mammals.<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaver#cite_note-NW-7">[7]</a></p> <p>Beavers continue to grow throughout their lives. Adult specimens  weighing over 25 kg (55 lb) are not uncommon. Females are as large as or  larger than males of the same age, which is uncommon among <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammal">mammals</a>. Beavers live up to 24 years of age in the wild.</p><br>
<p>This summer, researchers from NASA's Transformational Aeronautics  Concepts Program, Convergent Aeronautics Solutions Project, are entering  the third and final phase of the Vehicle Integrated Propulsion Research  (VIPR) effort to test and evaluate new engine health management  technologies. This research incorporates smart sensors and advanced  diagnostic techniques designed to improve safety and reduce costs.</p>  <p>Improved sensors could identify changes in vibration, speed,  temperature and emissions that are symptomatic of engine problems before  they become serious safety concerns. Displays would then notify ground  crews of potential problems that could be fixed by preventive  maintenance or alert pilots to changes in engine health thereby allowing  time to prevent engine damage in flight.</p>  <p>Over the past several years VIPR researchers have conducted  experiments that introduced foreign material  liquids and particulates   into a high-bypass turbofan engine and simulated engine faults to test  the effectiveness of the new sensors. To reduce risk, all such testing  is conducted on the ground under controlled conditions.</p>  <div>   <div> <div>Oil smoke billows from the right inboard engine of  the C-17 while a probe collects emissions data, one of numerous tests  conducted during Phase I of VIPR engine health monitoring tests.</div>  <div>Credits: NASA Photo / Tony Landis</div>   </div> </div>  <p>NASA is partnering with Air Force Research Laboratory, Federal  Aviation Administration, Boeing Research &amp; Technology, Pratt and  Whitney, General Electric Aviation and Rolls-Royce Liberty Works, with  assistance from the U.S. Geological Survey. Researchers from four NASA  centers  Armstrong, Glenn, Langley, and Ames  are involved in various  aspects of research and testing. The Air Force provided a C-17 cargo  transport plane and two F117 engines  military versions of the  commercial PW2037 used on the Boeing 757.</p>    <p>In December 2011, during a baseline test to lay the groundwork for  more complex experiments, the engine detected simulated faults,  including an oil leak. A second test in early 2013 verified that sensors  could detect actuator faults over a range of operating conditions. In  July, researchers will introduce increasing amounts of simulated  volcanic ash into the engine to assess how early the health monitoring  sensors and their associated software can detect and report a problem.</p><br>
NASHVILLE, Tenn.  The all-new 2015 Nissan Murano, which was introduced to near universal acclaim in December 2014, has added another prestigious award to its trophy case  a "Best Crossover" in the Parents magazine and Edmunds.com annual listing of the "10 Best Family Cars."<br><br>As in previous years, the top vehicles for 2015 were selected by the Parents and Edmunds.com editors based on safety, convenience and high-tech performance features at all price levels. In choosing the Murano, they stated:<br><br>"The all-new Murano pulls off a neat trick, mimicking the creamy ride and luxe features of models costing $10,000 more. It provides stretch-your-legs space for five, easy car-seat access, and storage for a weekend getaway (portacrib and stroller included). The fatigue-fighting 'Zero Gravity' front seats are a blessing for long drives. The monitor beams 360-degree camera views, detecting and alerting you to moving objects in the parking lot, from bicycles to shopping carts to little kids."<br><br> Parents, June 2015 issue<br><br>Murano was also recently awarded an IIHS "Top Safety Pick Plus" ranking as one of the latest Nissan vehicles to offer the innovative Predictive Forward Collision Warning (PFCW) and Forward Emergency Braking (FEB) systems specifically designed to alert drivers of potential risks ahead  along with available Driver's Attention Alert* (DAA) system. The DAA system analyzes driver steering behavior to provide an alert if signs of drowsiness or inattention are detected.<br><br>Sales of the all-new 2015 Murano increased 58.3 percent in May and 33.4 percent through May 2015 (compared to the same periods in calendar year 2014).<br><br>"The 2015 Murano has found a sweet spot in the competitive crossover SUV segment, offering standout styling, a highly versatile premium interior, advanced safety and driver aid technologies and, of course, Nissan's legendary driving excitement," said Fred Diaz, senior vice president, Sales &amp; Marketing, Parts &amp; Service, U.S.A, Nissan North America, Inc. "Now, on top of record sales in May, we're honored to add the highly sought-after Parents / Edmunds.com 'Best Family Car' acknowledgment to a great first year of the new Murano design."<br><br>As the halo vehicle for Nissan's expanding range of bold crossovers, the all-new Murano carries forward the new Nissan design direction with its V-Motion front end, boomerang lights, floating roof treatment and efficient aerodynamics. Inside, the new Murano offers an engaging "social lounge" feel through features such as the refined lower-height instrument panel, wide center console, advanced Zero Gravity seating, and the airy atmosphere created by the large windows and oversized Power Panoramic Moonroof.<br><br>Murano's long list of available features include NissanConnectSM with Navigation and Mobile Apps, 8-inch color display with multi-touch control, 8-way power driver's seat with power lumbar support, SiriusXM® Satellite Radio and Travel Link® (SiriusXM subscription required, sold separately), Nissan Intelligent Key® with Push Button Ignition, Remote Engine Start system, iPod® and other compatible devices interface, 11-speaker Bose® (including dual subwoofers) premium audio system and Bluetooth® Hands-free Phone System.<br><br>Responsive driving is provided by a standard 3.5-liter DOHC V6 connected to an advanced Xtronic transmission. Murano is available in front-wheel drive or Intuitive All-Wheel Drive. Fuel economy is rated at 28 mpg highway for both front-wheel and all-wheel drive models.<br><br>Available technologies include Around View® Monitor (AVM) with Moving Object Detection (MOD), Blind Spot Warning (BSW), Intelligent Cruise Control (ICC), Predictive Forward Collision Warning (PFCW) and Forward Emergency Braking (FEB). The Rear Cross Traffic Alert (RCTA) system utilizes radar to detect a moving vehicle behind the Murano approaching from either side of a parking space.<br><br>The 2015 Murano is offered in four trim levels  S, SV, SL and Platinum  and in a choice of front-wheel or all-wheel drive. The starting MSRP** for the Murano S FWD is $29,560 USD, while the top-of-the-line Murano Platinum AWD is priced at $40,600 USD (full pricing is available at NissanNews.com). The new Murano is assembled in Canton, Mississippi.<br><br>For photography and additional information about the 2015 Nissan Murano along with the complete lineup of Nissan vehicles, please visit <a href="http://www.NissanNews.com">www.NissanNews.com</a>.<br><br>The complete 2015 Parents and Edmunds.com "10 Best Family Cars" list will be published in the July 2015 issue of Parents magazine and is available online at Parents.com/best-family-cars.<br><br>About Nissan North America <br><br>In North America, Nissan's operations include automotive styling, engineering, consumer and corporate financing, sales and marketing, distribution and manufacturing. Nissan is dedicated to improving the environment under the Nissan Green Program and has been recognized annually by the U.S Environmental Protection Agency as an ENERGY STAR® Partner of the Year since 2010. More information on Nissan in North America and the complete line of Nissan and Infiniti vehicles can be found online at <a href="http://www.NissanUSA.com">www.NissanUSA.com</a> and <a href="http://www.InfinitiUSA.com">www.InfinitiUSA.com</a>, or visit the U.S. media sites NissanNews.com and InfinitiNews.com.<br><br>About Nissan Motor Co.<br><br>Nissan Motor Co., Ltd., Japan's second-largest automotive company, is headquartered in Yokohama, Japan, and is part of the Renault-Nissan Alliance. Operating with more than 247,500 employees globally, Nissan sold 5.32 million vehicles and generated revenue of 11.38 trillion yen (USD 103.6 billion) in fiscal year 2014. The cost of developing Web 2.0 and SaaS solutions can be hefty  for IT start-ups and product vendors in terms of pulling resources away  from the business side of the company. For several time, cost and  resource-saving reasons, more and more businesses find it beneficial to  outsource parts of or the entire development process from A to Z. Having  built and deployed more complex systems than our <a href="http://redwerk.com/services/dedicated-team">development team</a> can count, weve learned exactly what it takes to develop and launch powerful, ever-changing software solutions.<div><div><div><div><div>  						</div> 					 					 				</div>  				 			</div>  		</div> 	</div>      	<div> 		<div>  			<div> 				<div>  					 						<h4>How to start</h4>  					 					 						<div>  							<p>Perhaps out of all the development stages, the concept phase  has the widest parameters. Redwerks developers have moved quickly into  development based on a vague idea scribbled on a napkin. Weve also  brought to life multiple pages of highly specific end user objectives.  Either way, our team leans toward quick prototyping, saving you time and  money. However, the projects concept must have a basic foundation on  which to build: function requirements, budget and a timeline for  milestones and final execution.</p> <p>Functionality is key. Though it can change throughout the software  development life cycle and well beyond initial deployment, the basics  and a map for future evolution must be established as a guideline early  on. If you dont have a clear blueprint to follow, our development  experts can help you outline design preferences, wants versus needs, and  the requirements for the user interface.</p>  						</div> 					 					 				</div>  				 			</div>  		</div> 	</div>      	<div> 		<div>  			<div> 				<div>  					 						<h4>Engagement model</h4>  					 					 						<div>  							<p>Staying on budget right from the start is important to companies of all sizes, especially <a title="Link: http://redwerk.com/startups-innovation" href="http://redwerk.com/startups-innovation">start-ups and innovative product development</a>  and in this economy. Having flexible project models ranging from fixed  quote to dedicated teams help you keep costs under control. Dragging out  a SaaS or Web 2.0 project or a mobile app isnt acceptable in a fast  paced environment. From the beginning, your deadlines must be met by  doing things the right way the first time, avoiding expensive delays  later and ensuring your solution remains a contender in a competitive  market.<br></p></div></div></div></div></div>
  	<div> 		<div>  			<div> 				<div>  					 					 						<div>  							<p>Media and entertainment companies have to keep up with ongoing  transformations in the realm of digital media technology, striving to  provide the best web-based and mobile experiences.</p> <p>We understand the specific requirements of online media platforms,  challenges of streaming video and roadblocks faced by online media  companies that have complex digital media ecosystem in place. <a target="_blank" href="http://redwerk.com">Redwerk</a>  helped <a target="_blank">clients</a> to deal with complex issues with live video streaming and  formats, to overcome limitations of media servers and implement  conversion tools for major data sources.</p> <p>As the digital audience today is migrating to mobile very quickly, we  assist broadcasters, ad agencies, Internet companies to embrace the  dynamic change in this area implementing cutting-edge <a target="_blank" href="http://redwerk.com">mobile apps</a>, advanced mobile ad servers and banner exchange systems, custom mobile and responsive design solutions.</p> <p>Embracing innovation in the field of multi-platform development and  social media integration, we can enhance user experience and overall  response. There are currently 1.3 billion people on Facebook, Redwerk  technical team helped to reach out to them through engaging Facebook  apps, also handling the Google Analytics set up and the configuration of  the server on which the application had to be deployed.</p> <p>We invite you to move along with shifts in trends and technology: our  technical teams can certainly add an extra edge to the overall online  media and mobile product experience.</p>  						</div> 					 					 				</div>  				 			</div>  		</div> 	</div>  <br>
<p>Dallas, Texas -- April 24, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank" title="Link: http://www.myprgenie.com/">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Massage therapist at Massage Envy, Zane King's change of careers was not forced by the struggling economy. After he lost his sight several years ago, he attended massage therapy school and today works as a licensed massage therapist. Mr. King and three other therapists who are blind -- Diana Alvarez, Bill Thayer and Paul Hughes -- work at the Massage Envy clinic in this Dallas suburb. Many of their clients aren't even aware they are blind. Mr. King argues that he benefits from not seeing well. "Most of the therapy rooms are dimly lit, so sight is not particularly an advantage," he said. "Massage therapists who are blind really rely on touch alone, and of course the right touch is the key element in massage therapy."&nbsp;</p><p>Blind massage therapists are part of a growing trend that makes sense. "Once the client is on the massage table, everyone's body is put together the same way, so you know where all the limbs and muscles are," says Mr. Thayer. "Blindness isn't a drawback." Some massage schools are even teaching blind technique. The owner of the Massage Envy clinic in Addison, Bruce McGovern, says he's open to hiring more blind therapists. "These are talented professionals who know what they are doing, and our clients appreciate their skills," he said. Client Lee Fuqua says he doesn't notice that his therapist, Paul Hughes, is blind. "When people lose one of their senses, their other senses are sometimes amplified," he said. "Paul's sense of touch is incredible." To view the Associated Press video go to: <a href="http://video.ap.org/?f=KSTOP&amp;pid=5Icq5ZvE_VkYYLaHs0ulSkNfaPwFlWEP" title="Link: http://video.ap.org/?f=KSTOP&amp;pid=5Icq5ZvE_VkYYLaHs0ulSkNfaPwFlWEP">http://video.ap.org/?f=KSTOP&amp;pid=5Icq5ZvE_VkYYLaHs0ulSkNfaPwFlWEP</a>. "More Americans are turning to therapeutic massage treatment to relax, relieve tension and pain and ease the daily stresses of their busy lives," said Lance O'Pry, Dallas/Fort Worth regional developer for Massage Envy clinics, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. Massage therapy is an easy way to help maintain good health and achieve a balanced lifestyle. Regular massage improves posture and circulation, lowers blood pressure and helps manage pain, relaxes muscles, strengthens the immune system, enhances post-operative rehabilitation, and improves rehabilitation after injury&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. Memberships are available for $49 per month and include a one-hour massage session. Members may also enjoy unlimited additional one-hour massage sessions at the $39 member rate. Log on to <a href="http://www.massageenvy.com">www.massageenvy.com</a> to find the nearest Massage Envy clinic. There are 25 Massage Envy locations throughout the Metroplex and another 3 are scheduled to open soon. All are open seven days per week. ### Massage Envy Limited, LLC is a national franchise of massage therapy clinics dedicated to providing professional and affordable therapeutic massage services to consumers with busy lifestyles at convenient times and locations.&nbsp;</p><p>Founded in 2002, Massage Envy has opened 500 clinics in 38 states in just over five years, with 300 more franchises currently under development from coast to coast and 25 locations in the Dallas/Fort Worth Metroplex. <p>Dallas, Texas -- May 12, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Scientists studying music's effects on the brain and body are seeing health-boosting potential, both from listening to and making music. A spokesman for the American Music Therapy Association (AMTA) has said that "passive listening" to music can reduce heart rate and blood pressure, induce a relaxed state and change your mood. Babies in neonatal intensive care units have had improved lung development and nursing ability when exposed to music.&nbsp;</p><p>A 2003 study in Heart &amp; Lung Magazine suggests that listening to music while you work out does more than pass the time and make it enjoyable- it may increase your cognitive function, giving your verbal "muscles" a boost. "At Massage Envy, you'll hear relaxing music during your massage, unless you request otherwise," said C.G. Funk, clinician for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "If your impulse is to ask for perfect silence, consider giving the music a try. It just might amplify the soothing effects of the massage." A 2005 European study looked at the heart-bolstering, stress-busting effects of music and found that listening to music slowed breathing patterns in everyone studied. But the change was most drastic in those who had studied music, because they had learned to regulate their breathing with musical phrases.&nbsp;</p><p>According to the AMTA website, drumming is one example of active music making that healthy individuals can use for stress reduction. Active music making involves areas of the brain that guard against dementia and decline. It's frequently listed as an activity you can undertake to help prevent Alzheimer's disease.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. <p>Dallas, Texas -- May 15, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Don't let daily pain keep you from the life you want to live. "A professional massage therapist can help reduce the pain that comes with chronic conditions -- arthritis, fibromyalgia, migraines, and lower back problems," said CG Funk, vice president of industry relations and product development for Massage Envy Limited, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. A study published by the Annals of Behavioral Medicine found that those receiving massages had better-quality sleep and fewer migraine headaches than participants who didn't. Effects lasted up to three weeks after therapy ended. The same study reported that massage therapy was more effective in relieving back pain than acupuncture and spinal modification. It even appeared to reduce the use of painkillers by 36 percent.&nbsp;</p><p>Massage Envy says that massage therapy is a natural and effective pain management solution. Massage therapy can provide all the relief necessary without the need for pain killing drugs. Massage plays an important role in achieving a pain free lifestyle by utilizing various types of massage, such as Swedish, deep tissue, or trigger point therapy. By receiving one of the many massage techniques and modalities, one can rejuvenate and refresh the mind while improving joint movement, and increasing the flow of blood and nutrients to muscles and other tissue.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. <p>Dallas, Texas -- May 19, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Nothing says "I love you, Dad" quite like a homemade gift for Father's Day.&nbsp;</p><p>Here are some easy projects you can do with your kids.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p>Take an empty soup or vegetable can, remove the label and clean it well. Tear little pieces of masking tape and place them horizontally around the can, leaving the rough edges. Use a rag to wipe brown shoe polish over the tape, use another rag to wipe off the excess polish. The finished product has the look of leathery bark and makes a great pencil holder.&nbsp;</p><p>Make Father's Day a noteworthy event with a nifty notebook. Help your child cut out construction paper covers and blank inside pages using a cardboard template of something Dad likes, such as a car or a fish. Punch holes in one end and fasten with string.&nbsp;</p><p>Handprints are another favorite. Use water-based paint to place your child's handprint on a piece of paper or card stock. Once the paint is dry, your child can use a marker to write five reasons he or she loves Dad, such as "He takes me to the park." Use the image to create a card or a piece of wall art.&nbsp;</p><p>Not crafty? No worries. Dads love massage too. "So pick up a Massage Envy gift card for Father's Day this year," said Lance O'Pry, Dallas/Fort Worth regional developer for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "A massage gift card will surely be a surprise and a hit with Dad! Most men think of their wives when they give massages as a gift. Treat him to an hour or two just for him and enjoy the surprise on his face when he realizes the gift is for him."&nbsp;</p><p>An introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. <p>Dallas, Texas -- May 26, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Whether you're a serious athlete or a weekend warrior, you can add some rejuvenation to your workout routine. "A soothing massage can perk you up before or after a workout," said Lance O'Pry, Dallas/Fort Worth regional developer for Massage Envy clinics, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. It's easier to reach your fitness goals with the help of massage, which increases your range of motion, reduces muscle fatigue and helps prevent injury.&nbsp;</p><p>Massage can help maintain flexibility and range of motion by working muscles, connective tissue, tendons and ligaments. It also stimulates production and retention of natural lubricants between connective tissue fibers. It is not often that people associate a massage therapy program with fitness -- but they should for an optimal wellness/fitness program. Ever wonder why most professional teams have massage therapists on staff for their athletes? It is not for relaxation - it is for maximizing the athletes' performance. Athletes who train know their bodies well.&nbsp;</p><p>1.	Toxins and flexibility: After a good workout, a good game, or run, your body has toxins that are embedded within the muscle fibers. A sports massage helps release these toxins thus creating more blood circulation through the muscular system. Not only does increased blood circulation help the athlete perform at their optimal level, a Massage Envy sports massage will increase flexibility creating better results.&nbsp;</p><p>2.	Helps Prevent Injury: Many runners complain of cramps. Cramps are caused by tight muscles not getting enough oxygen. A well trained sports massage therapist at Massage Envy will loosen the runners' tight muscles thus reducing the risk of cramping and injury.&nbsp;</p><p>3.	Healing: When you work out with weights, the weight tears the muscle (this is one of the reasons you are sore the next day). When your body is healing itself (from the tear) pain is often accompanied by the process. One way to help speed up the healing process is a Massage Envy sports massage. This therapy is a type of deep tissue massage that generally focuses on the area of interest for the athlete receiving the massage. It helps speed recovery and repair muscle damage as well as releasing and breaking the knots/adhesions within the muscle. Athletes find this massage not only therapeutic but also mandatory to their fitness regime.&nbsp;</p><p>4.	Boosts Performance: Many athletes work the same muscles over and over thus leading to knots and chronic muscle tension. A regular sports massage therapy program will reduce the athlete's inflammation and help to eliminate scar tissue. The focus is on the deepest layers of muscle tissue, tendons, and fascia (the protective layer surrounding muscles, bones and joints). When the athletes muscles are taken care of, the athlete will perform at their best. Massage Envy offers a variety of massages from relaxation to a sports massage.&nbsp;</p><p>A sports massage is geared toward athletes of every shape size and kind - from the professional athlete to the weekend runner. The massage therapist focuses on particular troublesome areas and to the athlete's sport. This type of massage is growing very quickly in popularity as a useful companion to a balanced training routine. Some athletes use the sports massage prior to an event to loosen muscles to gain maximum performance during training or after a race or event to prevent soreness and help heal the muscles. Athletes have discovered that specially designed massage promotes flexibility, removes fatigue, improves endurance, helps prevent injuries, and prepares them to compete at their absolute best. Massage Envy clinics offer weeknight and weekend hours, so you can rejuvenate on your own schedule.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. <p>Dallas, Texas -- June 1, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Your skin is the largest single part of your body, so it makes sense to keep it clean, moist and healthy. "Massage promotes skin health by improving blood circulation and removing toxins," said CG Funk, vice president of industry relations and product development for Massage Envy Limited, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. That rosy, warm look and feel you get after a massage is a sign of improved blood flow, which brings nutrients and carries away waste products. The stress-relief benefits of massage also can show on your skin. You can also put your best face forward with this summer skin routine:&nbsp;</p><p>1.	Keep It Clean. Start with a cleaning routine. Summer's more humid air helps skin stay hydrated. But with the weather, skin can switch over from dry to oily. Lighter liquid cleansers are better in summer. Summer's heat can lead to perspiration. Sweat contains proteins that need to be washed away so they don't clog your pores. A mild exfoliant is okay, but stay away from cleansers that are too abrasive.&nbsp;</p><p>2. Keep It Moist. Showering can dry out your skin, but applying moisturizer right out of the shower or bath helps to lock in water molecules. For super-soft skin, many people find that the oils and lotions used during regular massage leave their skin feeling well hydrated all over.&nbsp;</p><p>3. Keep It Fresh. To keep your skin looking fresh and clear, alpha hydroxyl creams and lotions or retinol creams can help exfoliate the skin and clean out the pores. Because these products remove the outer layer of skin, they make you more sensitive to the sun, so protect yourself from those rays.</p><p>4.	Keep It Safe. The sun's rays are strongest in summer. Sun protection is very important. Use a broad-spectrum, SPF [sun protection factor] 15 or greater sunscreen that blocks both UVA and UVB rays. Sunscreen is a third line of defense- first is staying indoors when the sun is at its strongest, from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., and then using clothing and hats to block the rays.&nbsp;</p><p>Massage Envy states the long term effects of massage therapy are much more than just skin deep. Better circulation is part of the chain reaction that happens in the body as a result of receiving massage therapy on a regular basis. Improved circulation is just one more benefit of massage therapy. Combined with a balanced diet and regular exercise, massage can be the key to leading a healthier lifestyle. Improved Circulation Benefits include: 	Enhances blood flow 	Moves waste away from muscles and internal organs 	Lowers blood pressure 	Improves body function&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. <p>Dallas, Texas -- June 11, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- With so much to do, it's easy to neglect your health goals each day. "By adding these easy tasks to the top of your daily to-do list, you'll be making your way to optimal health step-by-step," said CG Funk, vice president of industry relations and product development for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the United States.&nbsp;</p><p>1. Eat right, right away. Breakfast, the most important meal of the day, will jump-start your metabolism, give you immediate energy and help you burn more calories. With all meals, think about food as a rainbow: the more color, the better. Think about eating sweet potatoes instead of white and deep green romaine lettuce over iceberg for starters.&nbsp;</p><p>2. Get off the couch. Some 70 percent of American adults don't get enough physical activity to provide health benefits. The American Heart Association recommends 30 to 40 minutes of vigorous exercise three to five days a week. "Exercise is one of the best things you can do to live longer and better," said Ms. Funk of Massage Envy. Benefits include reduced risk of heart attack and depression, increased late-day energy, improved sleep habits, lower weight and improved self-esteem.&nbsp;</p><p>3. Kick the habit. Smoking causes 440,000 premature deaths each year. Don't be one of them. The benefits of stopping smoking are extraordinary. Simply put, you'll add years to your life.&nbsp;</p><p>4. Laugh. Laughter lowers your blood pressure, increases blood flow to your heart and pumps more oxygen into the blood. A strong sense of humor may even help protect you against a heart attack, according to a study by cardiologists.&nbsp;</p><p>5. Go to bed early. Adequate restful sleep, just like diet and exercise, is critical to good health. According to the National Institutes of Health, healthy adults need an average of eight hours each night.&nbsp;</p><p>6. Regular massage therapy. Massage can also contribute to healthy living. In addition to relieving stress and encouraging relaxation, regular massage therapy can improve circulation, lower blood pressure, improve flexibility and even strengthen the immune system, all of which can positively contribute to a healthy lifestyle.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39 - a 40 percent savings - a $65 value. Memberships are available for $49 per month and include a one-hour massage session. Members may also enjoy unlimited additional one-hour massage sessions at the $39 member rate. <p>Dallas, Texas -- June 16, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- You probably had more than your share of indoor workouts in the past few months. But with summer in full swing, working out in the great outdoors is a great way to change up your routine. Explore the Area. Plenty of cities and towns have nearby parks and recreation areas that offer bike paths, walking/ hiking paths or other opportunities for outdoor exercise. "Look at your environment and determine what kinds of activities you can do," says CG Funk, vice president of industry relations and product development for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. Some parks even have workout equipment for doing exercises like pull-ups and step-ups, says Funk. If the park in your neighborhood isn't fully equipped get creative. Use the jungle gym to do various exercises like pull-ups. Just climbing around on a jungle gym is good exercise. Don't overlook the resources at local schools over the summer. "Run up and down the bleachers, use the track for running laps and the grassy areas for stretching; ," Funk says. Stay Home. If you have even a small yard, you can create your own outdoor gym.&nbsp;</p><p>A medicine ball, some exercise bands and a jump rope are all you need to put you through the paces of a good, all around workout. Go Beyond the Basics. Biking, swimming and tennis provide a great workout. But you can also find other kinds of summer fun. If you golf, skip the cart and walk briskly from hole to hole. Or carry your own clubs. Or, how about a nice sailboat ride? Participating in sailing the boat is vigorous exercise. If walking is your thing, look for places to stop and do some body-weight exercises. Use a ledge or bench for step-ups, or do some push-ups in the park. You can find plenty of other opportunities for physical activity, from planting flowers to washing your car- it all adds up.&nbsp;</p><p>Most important, don't waste a moment of the season. Massage can also contribute to healthy living. In addition to relieving stress and encouraging relaxation, regular massage therapy can improve circulation, lower blood pressure, improve flexibility and even strengthen the immune system, all of which can positively contribute to overall fitness.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. Memberships are available for $49 per month and include a one-hour massage session. Members may also enjoy unlimited additional one-hour massage sessions at the $39 member rate. Log on to <a href="http://www.massageenvy.com" title="Link: http://www.massageenvy.com">www.massageenvy.com</a> to find the nearest Massage Envy clinic. "When you become a Massage Envy DFW follower on Twitter or a Massage Envy DFW fan on Facebook, you're eligible to win everyday throughout the whole contest." The contest ends July 24th. <p><b>EPK AVAILABLE AT: </b><a href="https://www.dropbox.com/sh/9xpl5exa4ec1t78/AAAqRAQb9je8tVnMwtAkDa8Va?dl=0"><b>https://www.dropbox.com/sh/9xpl5exa4ec1t78/AAAqRAQb9je8tVnMwtAkDa8Va?dl=0</b></a><b></b></p><p><b>&nbsp;</b>PALO DURO, TX July 7, 2015--The 50th Anniversary TEXAS Alumni Reunion Committee has announced <i>Reunion Night</i>, as part of the two-day event for the cast, crew, and company members who have served, produced and performed for millions of patrons from around the world. <i>Reunion Night, </i>an event over a year in the making, will take place at the Pioneer Amphitheatre in Palo Duro Canyon State Park on Saturday, July 18th 2015.</p><p>Hundreds of former company members are attending. In fact, many of the alumni from the very early days are returning for the first time, says Former Executive Director and Producer of the show, Bill Anderson, who is working closely with the Reunion Committee. &nbsp;It is reported that hotel rooms in the greater Canyon, Texas area are already sold out for the weekend of July 17 and 18.&nbsp;</p><p>Gene Vaughn Morrison, Chairman of the Reunion Committee, and says, Millions of fans from around the world have come to see TEXAS, the Official Play of the State of Texas. Now, we are thrilled to host this once-in-a-lifetime gathering of some of the most dynamic people who have shaped 50 years of this legendary show!</p><p>Morrison, who has been involved with TEXAS since its inception 50 years ago, continues, Our original founder, Margaret Harper, is rejoicing from the best seat in the heavens.&nbsp; Her dream has lasted 50 years, through incredible times and unimaginable hardships. But just like the early pioneers of the Panhandle of Texas the show portrays, the show has persevered.</p><p>A long-running show like TEXAS is not without its passionate and notable alumni. Former cast member Ron DeVoe reflects, Appearing in the TEXAS Musical Drama was actually a life changing moment for me and many of those cast members from previous decades. The reliance of every member of the cast and crew on each other instilled responsibility, teamwork and comradery.&nbsp; While some performers from TEXAS have gone on to perform on Broadway, the MET, with premier dance companies, regional theaters and on TV and in film, countless other TEXAS Exes continually demonstrate their talents in business, education, in churches and in respective communities.</p><p>TEXAS Outdoor Musical is written by Pulitzer Prize winner Paul Green and tells the timeless story of the early settlers of the Panhandle of Texas through song, dance, and special effects while being performed in the unmatched beauty of a natural amphitheater in the picturesque Palo Duro Canyon State Park.&nbsp;</p><p>The shows success has been felt worldwide.&nbsp; Every performance, we honor each audience member who traveled the furthest by presenting them with a replica chow call triangle. In our 50 years, it always been received by a patron from a country other than the United States.&nbsp; This show is a world-wide phenomenon nobody ever expected, says Mr. Morrison.&nbsp;</p><p>###</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>For Media Passes and Interview requests, please contact:</p><p>Gene Vaughan Morrison <a>gvm@t-anchor.net</a></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>For Electronic Press Kit and additional materials, please contact:</p><p>Dana Cobb</p><p>TrizCom PR </p><p>972-955-9747</p><p>dana@trizcom.com</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>                                                        </p><p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Dallas, Texas -- June 25, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Therapists from Dallas-Fort Worth Massage Envy clinics will provide free chair massages at the 2009 Celebrate Freedom Concert on Saturday, June 27th. Any donations received for the massages will benefit Susan G. Komen for the Cure.&nbsp;</p><p>At the 2009 Celebrate Freedom Concert, held at Southfork Ranch, Massage Envy's Pavilion, called, "Chilla Villa," will be staffed by 25 therapists offering free chair massages 11am to 5pm. The first 400 guests to "Chilla Villa" will also receive free bottled of water.&nbsp;</p><p>Launched in 1991, Celebrate Freedom is the largest Christian concert in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, and attracts more than 100,000 people. The concert will be held at the Southfork Ranch in Plano, Texas. "Come early with your chairs and blankets, get a free massage in the only air conditioned pavilion on site, and enjoy music all day," said Lance O'Pry, regional developer for Massage Envy clinics, the largest provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "We are very pleased that all donations at the Massage Envy Chilavilla pavilion will go to Susan G. Komen for the Cure."&nbsp;</p><p>At Celebrate Freedom, Massage Envy expects to perform 1000 massages. This will be a record for DFW Massage Envy clinics -- the most massages ever given at a single event. If this milestone is reached at the 2009 Celebrate Freedom concert, a lucky guest will win a one-year membership to Massage Envy. <p>Dallas, Texas -- July 1, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank" title="Link: http://www.myprgenie.com/">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- If the gloomy economic climate is dragging your morale lower than the Dow Jones Industrial Average, you're not alone. Being optimistic in such a bleak economy may seem like a lost cause, but adopting a more upbeat attitude has its health benefits and is a skill that can be learned through practice.&nbsp;</p><p>Here are a few tips on how to get more pleasure out of life, regardless of your circumstances:&nbsp;</p><p><ul><li>Have an attitude of gratitude. It's one of the easiest and most effective paths to a happier life. It's no coincidence that giving thanks is a foundation of prayer in every religion and culture. Showing gratitude will also make other people feel better about themselves and their situations. If you're stuck on what exactly to be grateful for, take a few seconds before you get out of bed each morning to value the potential in each new day. Tell yourself, "I'm grateful to be here." That thought will improve how you treat yourself and others.&nbsp;</li></ul><p>Take a break. Help yourself be more upbeat by scheduling a break in your routine. Have lunch with a friend at your favorite bistro or take a stroll through the farmers market for fresh strawberries. "A lot of our clients will put a massage on their calendars a week ahead of time, just to have something to look forward to," says Lance O'Pry, Dallas/Fort Worth Regional Developer for Massage Envy clinics, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "Schedulers reap a twofold benefit," he notes. "They get a rush of happiness anticipating the enjoyable event, and they then savor the activity as it happens."&nbsp;</p><p>Help yourself by helping others. Connecting with those who benefit from your effort is a powerful mood booster. There's always someone out there who needs a little help, and helping them out will only help you out. Volunteer at a local pet shelter, library, school or soup kitchen. Ask your community center if you can aid homebound senior citizens by driving them on errands or by just visiting. Fostering personal connections is a powerful antidote to the self-absorption that can overwhelm a person during tough time. There are enough depressing things going on in the world, but even when times are tough, we can create a more upbeat reality for ourselves. Your optimism will be equally infectious. Massage can help you feel better physically and mentally.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. Memberships are available for $49 per month and include a one-hour massage session. Members may also enjoy unlimited additional one-hour massage sessions at the $39 member rate. <p>Dallas, Texas -- July 6, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Reflexology, a popular alternative therapy, promotes relaxation, improves circulation, reduces pain, and encourages overall healing. Reflexology is the application of massage techniques and stretching to the feet and hands," says CG Funk, Vice President of Product Development for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. The theory behind reflexology is that there are "reflex points" on the feet and hands that relate to structures throughout the body - muscles, bones, organs and glands. By stimulating these reflex points through massage techniques, the benefits can be felt throughout the body.&nbsp;</p><p>Reflexology techniques can help reduce pain and discomfort from stress and stress-related conditions inlcuding: 	Tension headaches  Arthritis 	Insomnia 	Sports injuries 	PMS 	Digestive problems, constipation 	Back pain "Reflexology is great by itself or as part of a full-body massage," Funk says. "It's a good idea to book an extra half-hour for your next massage so you can enjoy the added benefits of reflexology." Receiving reflexology shouldn't be painful. If you feel discomfort, be sure to tell the therapist to reduce pressure and work within your comfort zone. Some areas on your feet and hands may be tender, and the therapist may spend extra time on these points.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. <p>Dallas, Texas -- July 10, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Summer means letting your feet see the light of day in those comfy-but flimsy-flip-flops. Summer also means your feet will begin to protest the lack of support your favorite flip-flops offer. "Reflexology is a great way to heal your heels," said CG Funk, Vice President of Product Development for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "When you go in for your next massage, ask your therapist to pay special attention to your feet. Regular massages keep the feet supple, flexible and in top shape."&nbsp;</p><p>The American Podiatric Medical Association offers these tips on keeping your feet pain-free: Do daily gentle calf stretches for 20 to 30 seconds on each leg. While barefoot, lean forward toward a wall with one foot forward and one foot back.  Wear comfortable, supportive shoes when you anticipate a long day of walking or standing. 	Replace your shoes regularly. 	Avoid walking barefoot on hard or uneven surfaces. 	Break in new shoes before walking in them for long distances.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. <p>Dallas, Texas -- July 15, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Sure, you look forward to your regular massage, but massages have more benefits than you probably realize. "Regular massage keeps the body working at optimal levels," says CG Funk, Vice President of Product Development for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "It helps to keep people well-physically and emotionally."&nbsp;</p><p>Here are eight ways massage can benefit your body and mind:&nbsp;</p><p>1. Fight Fibromyalgia Symptoms. Fibromyalgia is a chronic condition characterized by muscle pain, fatigue and tenderness. Symptoms can be brought on or worsened by stress and lack of sleep. Massage has helps relieve stress and alleviates muscle pain, discomfort and spasms in fibromyalgia patients. The National Fibromyalgia Association reports that about 40 percent of sufferers have used massage in their treatment plans.&nbsp;</p><p>2. Ease Surgical Effects. After surgery, massage can help get you back on your feet by increasing circulation, relaxing muscles, and improving joint movement and flexibility. Massage promotes tissue regeneration and reduces post-surgical adhesions and swelling.&nbsp;</p><p>3. Improve Your Mood. The relaxing qualities of massage have been shown to help treat anxiety and depression. A review by the Touch Research Institute at the University of Miami School of Medicine, found that massage lowered the body's level of cortisol, a stress hormone, by as much as 53%. Massage is also said to increase the "feel-good" hormones, serotonin and dopamine.&nbsp;</p><p>4. Relieve Headaches. Migraine headaches are often triggered or worsened by stress and poor sleep. In the Annals of Behavioral Medicine, researchers found that people who received massages had higher quality sleeping habits and fewer migraines than people who didn't receive massages. These positive effects even lasted up to three weeks after their massage therapy ended.&nbsp;</p><p>5. Lower Blood Pressure. A study in the journal, Biological Research for Nursing, found that people who had at least three, 10-minute back massages per week lowered their blood pressure more than people who had spent the same amount of time just relaxing.&nbsp;</p><p>6. Increase Flexibility. Massage can help you maintain flexibility and your range of motion by working the muscles, connective tissues, tendons and ligaments, and by stimulating natural lubricants between the connective tissue fibers.&nbsp;</p><p>7. Alleviate Back Pain. A study in the Annals of Internal Medicine found that massage therapy was more effective at relieving back pain than other therapies such as acupuncture and spinal modification. It even appeared to reduce the use of painkillers by 36%.&nbsp;</p><p>8. Curb Carpal Tunnel. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is a painful condition in which the median nerve that connects the forearm and hand becomes pinched at the wrist. Symptoms include burning, tingling or numbness. Treatments usually consist of medication, wrist braces, and surgery. A study from the Journal of Bodywork and Movement reported that carpal tunnel patients receiving regular massage had less pain, reduced symptoms and improved grip-strength.&nbsp;</p><p>Massage Envy therapists are trained in trigger point, deep tissue, and reflexology techniques, as well as cranial sacral therapy. Talk to your therapist about the medical conditions that are affecting you to find out if massage can help. "Massage has many benefits including the promotion of relaxation," says Funk. "And, for those that receive massage on a regular basis, try a style of massage that's new to you, such as a hot stone therapy, cranial sacral therapy or Reflexology at a Massage Envy clinic."&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. Memberships are available for $49 per month and include a one-hour massage session. Members may also enjoy unlimited additional one-hour massage sessions at the $39 member rate. Log on to <a href="http://www.massageenvy.com">www.massageenvy.com</a> to find the nearest Massage Envy clinic. There are 25 Massage Envy locations throughout the Metroplex and another three are scheduled to open soon. All are open seven days per week. ###&nbsp;</p><p>Massage Envy Limited, LLC is a national franchise of massage therapy clinics dedicated to providing professional and affordable therapeutic massage services to consumers with busy lifestyles at convenient times and locations. Founded in 2002, Massage Envy has opened 500 clinics in 38 states in just over five years, with 300 more franchises currently under development from coast to coast and 25 locations in the Dallas/Fort Worth Metroplex. For more information about Massage Envy, visit the website at <a href="http://www.MassageEnvy.com">www.MassageEnvy.com</a>.&nbsp;</p><p>*Not all types of massage available at all clinics.&nbsp;</p><p>Massage Envy Dallas/Fort Worth Locations <a href="http://www.MassageEnvy.com">www.MassageEnvy.com</a> Prestonwood - 5225 Belt Line Rd., Suite 250, Addison, TX 75254 (972) 388-5500 Allen - 816 W. <p>Dallas, Texas -- Aug 5, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- There's nothing better than a vacation, but without the right planning -- a refreshing vacation can easily turn into a stressful vacation. The wrong vacation can turn out to be just as draining as the work environment the vacation was intended to escape. "It's important that people take the stress out of their vacations," says Lance O'Pry, DFW regional developer for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "Too many people try to cram too much stuff into a vacation and wind up exhausting themselves. You've got to take it easy."&nbsp;</p><p>Here are some things you can do to make sure you come back to reality refreshed: 	Start off right -- Decide on the right vacation. If it's a family vacation, get a feel for what everybody wants to do.&nbsp;</p><p>	Build a realistic schedule -- You can't see everything, so don't exhaust yourself trying. Going out of your way to spend a few minutes at every tourist spot is going to wear you out.&nbsp;</p><p>	Rest -- Get some sleep before you take off and try to get sleep every night of your vacation. 	Be healthy -- Always be clean, especially when traveling outside of the country. Don't let a cold ruin your vacation!&nbsp;</p><p>	Free-up time -- Print out your boarding pass ahead of time, pack the car the night before, and do whatever you can to avoid lines and give yourself more time to relax.&nbsp;</p><p> Unwind -- Schedule a massage for the day you return home and give yourself some time to unwind before you restart. You can enjoy the reciprocal benefits of massage anywhere at any of Massage Envy's nationwide locations. With over 500 Massage Envy locations and another 300 set to be established in the next few years, so you'll have no trouble unwinding from a vacation or even starting a vacation.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. Memberships are available for $49 per month and include a one-hour massage session. Members may also enjoy unlimited additional one-hour massage sessions at the $39 member rate. Log on to <a href="http://www.massageenvy.com">www.massageenvy.com</a> to find the nearest Massage Envy clinic. There are 26 Massage Envy locations throughout the Dallas/Fort Worth Metroplex and 500 nationwide. All are open seven days per week. <p>Dallas, Texas -- August 11, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Massage Envy proudly announces the launch of the nationwide Massage for the Cure initiative with Susan G. Komen for the Cure. The effort will generate breast cancer awareness and raise funds for education, screening and treatment of breast cancer while also providing people with the health benefits of massage therapy.&nbsp;</p><p>Massage Envy's Massage for the Cure event will take place nationwide Tuesday, September 15, 2009. During this one-day event, Massage Envy clinics will offer $35 one-hour therapeutic massage sessions -- with $10 going directly to local Susan G. Komen for the Cure chapters. Additional donations will also be accepted from now until September 15, 2009. "Nationally, our goal is to raise $500,000 for Susan G. Komen for the Cure," says Lance O'Pry, Dallas Fort Worth regional developer for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "All of our 26 Dallas Fort Worth based owners, staff and therapists are looking forward to Massage for the Cure and the opportunity to give back to the community that has allowed us to thrive during a period of economic hardship for many people. And, this event is even more special for us here in Dallas Fort Worth since Susan G. Komen for the Cure is headquartered in Dallas."&nbsp;</p><p>All donations will stay within the Susan G. Komen local chapters, benefiting breast cancer awareness in Massage Envy communities. Massage for the Cure event details are available at <a href="http://www.MassageEnvy.com">www.MassageEnvy.com</a>. Appointments and reservations for the Massage for the Cure event can be made beginning August 15, 2009 at any Massage Envy clinic in the nation. To find the closest Massage Envy go to <a href="http://www.massageenvy.com">www.massageenvy.com</a>.&nbsp;</p><p>Since Massage for the Cure's inception in 2005, Massage Envy has raised over $800,000 to support breast cancer research for regional chapters of Susan G. Komen for the Cure. Susan G. Komen for the Cure funds breast cancer education, screening and treatment initiatives. This year alone, more than 180,000 women and men in the United States will be diagnosed with breast cancer and more than 40,000 will lose their lives to the disease. A woman is diagnosed with breast cancer every three minutes and the disease claims another life every 13 minutes.&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. Memberships are available for $49 per month and include a one-hour massage session. Members may also enjoy unlimited additional one-hour massage sessions at the $39 member rate. Log on to <a href="http://www.massageenvy.com">www.massageenvy.com</a> to find the nearest Massage Envy clinic. There are 26 Massage Envy locations throughout the Dallas Fort Worth Metroplex and 500 nationwide. All are open seven days per week. Follow Massage Envy DFW on Facebook - <a href="http://www.facebook.com/MassageDFW">www.facebook.com/MassageDFW</a> and Twitter - <a href="http://www.twitter.com/MassageEnvyDFW">www.twitter.com/MassageEnvyDFW</a>. ###&nbsp;</p><p>About Massage for the Cure Massage for the Cure is an annual, one-day event hosted by Massage Envy(R) and benefiting Susan G. Komen for the Cure(R), a global leader in the movement to end breast cancer. Since the event's inception in 2005, Massage Envy has raised over $800,000 for Susan G. Komen for the Cure with 100% of the proceeds being used for education, screening and treatment programs in the community. Now in its fifth year, Massage for the Cure will be held on September 15, 2009 at an estimated 590 Massage Envy clinics across the United States. To book your appointment or for more information, please visit: MassageEnvy.com.&nbsp;</p><p>Massage Envy Limited, LLC is a national franchise of massage therapy clinics dedicated to providing professional and affordable therapeutic massage services to consumers with busy lifestyles at convenient times and locations. Founded in 2002, Massage Envy has opened 500 clinics in 38 states in just over five years, with 300 more franchises currently under development from coast to coast and 26 locations in the Dallas/Fort Worth Metroplex. <p>Dallas, Texas -- Aug 17, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Jacqueline Shenkir, a mother of two, has been recognized by Massage Envy as the grand-prize winner of the "Most Amazing Mom" contest. She will receive a free, one-year membership which includes a monthly, one-hour massage session at the location of her choice. Jacqueline also received a $100 gift certificate from Calloway's Nursery as a part of this Mother's Day giveaway. To participate, contestants visited <a href="http://www.MostAmazingMom.com" title="Link: http://www.MostAmazingMom.com">www.MostAmazingMom.com</a> and submitted entries of 250 words or less, detailing why the mom in their life is so amazing. The contest was open to Dallas/Fort Worth moms. In the winning entry, Shenkir's husband wrote (on behalf of her five year old son), "She is always thinking of others before herself and has the biggest heart a mom could have." (Shenkir's nomination entry is on Massage Envy's Facebook page at <a href="http://www.Facebook.com/MassageDFW." title="Link: http://www.Facebook.com/MassageDFW.">www.Facebook.com/MassageDFW.</a>) "There are thousands of wonderful moms in the Dallas/Fort Worth area," said Lance O'Pry, Dallas/Fort Worth regional developer for Massage Envy, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "With so many amazing moms, it was hard to pick just one." Along with the grand-prize winner, five runner-up moms received a free, one-hour massage session and a $20 gift certificate to Calloway's Nursery. "The 'Most Amazing Mom' contest was a great success," said O'Pry. "Ms. Shenkir really deserves this membership. I know she is going to love her massage sessions."&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. <p>Dallas, Texas -- August 24, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Jennifer Smith and Jason Michaels met at the Massage Envy clinic in Rowlett where they work. The rest, as the saying goes, is history. "We started getting to know each other because we had many shifts that overlapped," Jennifer said. "I was drawn to the fact that he was so nice and treated me and everyone with respect. He was also very honest and ethical, and never spoke badly of people behind their backs." "I wasn't really looking for a relationship, I was focused on my career," Jason recalls. "She was pretty, friendly and seemed like a nice person. The more I got to know her the more I realized we had a lot in common." After about two months they went on their first real date -- a great dinner and a nice evening. Both started to wonder if this could be something more. When they went to church together, "that's when I knew there was a deep connection starting to form," Jason said. "I love his smile and his laugh," Jennifer said, "He stays positive about life. He also treats me like nobody else ever has, and I can feel how much he loves me." For Jason, "I love Jennifer's eyes and her laughter. She helps me relax and stay focused on the things in life that are truly important. She has a gentle but firm way that I appreciate so much." The couple picked out a ring in June of 2008. "I was saving up all of my cash tips to pay for it," Jason recalls. "I finally got it [the ring] paid off about a year later, and was looking for the perfect moment to propose." Jason asked Jennifer's parents for their permission after he made the final payment on the ring. He proposed on the Friday before Labor Day weekend. "We went to the pond down the street from my home to relax and feed the ducks," Jennifer remembers. "He was standing there and turned and asked, 'how much do you love me?' Then before I knew it he got down on one knee and pulled out a box with a ring in it and put it on my finger. I was so excited that all I said was 'Jason,' and gave him a big hug. He asked if that was a yes and I just nodded my head and started to cry." "I caught her off guard because I had told her that I couldn't pay off the ring till late September," Jason said. "I wanted the proposal to be a surprise. I had butterflies in my stomach and was stressed, but didn't really realize it until after she said yes. Then I was finally able to breathe and relax." Jennifer and Jason were married May 16, 2009 in Bonham, Texas, at her parents' ranch house. The couple traveled to San Antonio by train for their honeymoon along the River Walk. Rick and April Klics, owners of the Massage Envy clinic in Rowlett, gave the newlyweds the trip as a wedding gift. "The Klics are awesome people," Jennifer said. Jennifer describes their relationship as blissful. "Jason is a great guy and I am so happy I found him. I went looking for a job, and instead I found a career and a life," she said. "She's fun to be around, and is my best friend," Jason says of Jennifer. "I hope it stays this way forever."&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39. Memberships are available for $49 per month and include a one-hour massage session. Members may also enjoy unlimited additional one-hour massage sessions at the $39 member rate. <p>Dallas, Texas -- Aug 27, 2009 / (<a href="http://www.myprgenie.com/" target="_blank">http://www.myprgenie.com</a>) -- Bruce McGovern, owner of four Massage Envy clinics throughout the Dallas/Fort Worth area, has recently been recognized as Massage Envy's "Franchisee of the Year." This recognition notes McGovern's financial success, his handling of multiple franchises, and his activity in effective regional advertising campaigns. "There are over 500 Massage Envy clinics nationwide. Mr. McGovern's leadership stood out as the best of the best. He consistently displays excellence in customer service, superb staffing skills and financial success," said Lance O'Pry, Dallas/Fort Worth regional developer for Massage Envy clinics, the leading provider of massage therapy in the U.S. "He is always contributing ideas and works hard to enhance the Massage Envy brand." McGovern's DFW clinics are located at the Old Town Shopping Center, Preston Parker Crossing Shopping Center, Preston Trail Crossing Shopping Center, and the Prestonwood Town Center which he just opened in August of 2008. McGovern's clinics have more than 5,700 members and over 130 employees. "We currently have openings for another 25 licensed massage therapists," said McGovern. "At the rate we're growing we'll be at 200 employees by the end of the year." Combined, McGovern's clinics perform more than 6,700 massages every month. Recently, his Old Town Shopping Center clinic set a Massage Envy record for most massages in one month with 3,237 massages. "My Old Town location was the first Massage Envy clinic to open in the Dallas/Fort Worth area. When I decided to open it, I knew I wanted to be a part of Massage Envy. Our members enjoy the endless therapeutic and stress relieving benefits of massage therapy as often as they like at a fraction of the typical massage price," said McGovern. McGovern also attributes his success to his employees. He states that most of his therapists have more than 5 years of professional experience. "In fact, some of our massage therapists have over 20 years of experience." It's McGovern's attention to the details in customer service, personal attention, marketing, vendor relationships and employee training that has earned McGovern so much success and the new recognition of Massage Envy's Franchisee of the Year award. Additionally, McGovern invests in advertising and expanding awareness of Massage Envy.&nbsp;</p><p>"In 2008, the Dallas/Fort Worth Massage Envy owners pooled our marketing and advertising dollars together and hired The Barber Shop Marketing. The Barber Shop Marketing has advised us to advertise and participate in promotions, cross promotions and public relations this past year when some small businesses have been cutting back. We are seeing great results with this partnership, including new leads, first time visitors and overall sales." When asked what makes him a success, McGovern states, "Don't try to reinvent the wheel. Stick to the basics and make sure that you hire good people that take care of your clients. When you're in a customer service business, like Massage Envy, your customer service is only as good as your weakest link. We are very good at customer service."&nbsp;</p><p>At Massage Envy, an introductory one-hour massage session (a 50-minute massage and time for consultation and dressing) is just $39.
