<div><p>Watch this miraculous story unfold here:</p><br><p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yTIZGA32D9A" target="_blank"><img width="500" alt="videopng" src="http://s3.amazonaws.com/mprgenieproduction/binaries/121188/video-png" height="281" title="Image: http://s3.amazonaws.com/mprgenieproduction/binaries/121188/video-png"></a>&nbsp; </p><br><p>We would so appreciate your willingness to spread the word about this story to help an amazing organization that is giving hope to families whose little ones are in the hospital for severe medical conditions. Feel free to share this video and story on your social media or blog pages.</p><br><p>When Stephanie and Brett Parker discovered they were going to appear on the hit show, Shark Tank, they knew their lives would change, but they never imagined the experience would also change other lives as well. The Parkers are the founders of <a href="http://www.SleepingBaby.com">www.SleepingBaby.com</a> and inventors of the award-winning Zipadee-Zip sleep garment for children and infants. Their own amazing story of building a million-dollar brand from only $700 in savings caught the attention of Shark Tank producers and the Parkers were selected to appear on the premiere of the 2014/2015 Shark Tank season. When the Parkers were featured on Shark Tank, they shared the devastating loss of their own child and how their Sleeping Baby customers helped them heal in a unique way. To the Parkers surprise, they were flooded with support from around the globe, but an email from expecting mother, Kelly Blumenthal, stood out above the rest. </p><br><p>Kelly wrote Stephanie and conveyed how devastated she was when she discovered she was pregnant with a boy who had little to no chance at life due to potentially terminal heart defects. The Blumenthal family had to make plans to terminate the pregnancy based on the recommendation from doctors who conveyed the severity of the babys condition and his inevitable fate. However, after watching Stephanie share her heart and story of loss on Shark Tank, Kelly was renewed with a sense of purpose and drive to see her little one survive and gave him a chance at life.</p><br><p>Kelly wrote, I saw you on Shark Tank and all of a sudden, I was just filled with strength, validation and purpose. Hearing you and seeing you say it right in front of me made my heart stop. What am I doing?! I am going to full term with Finn because I believe in him and I believe there is a higher power and a bigger reason for all of this. I need to have more faith and stop being scared. I WILL enjoy this pregnancy and the time I have with Finn. I will be braver by loving with reckless abandonment. Knowing what may or may not happen does not change how much love I have for him. THANK YOU for bringing me peace and for reminding me to cherish and love and to not be scared because everything truly DOES happen for a reason."</p><br><p><img width="300" alt="kelly1png" src="http://s3.amazonaws.com/mprgenieproduction/binaries/121188/kelly1-png" height="306"></p><br><p>Stephanie shared Kellys story on the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.facebook.com/pages/Zipadeezip-Slumber-Sacks-wwwzipadeezipcom/140978145992706?fref=ts" target="_blank">Zipadee-Zip Facebook page</a>&nbsp;and their Sleeping Baby fans surrounded the family in an overwhelming supply of prayers and support during the pregnancy. The result was nothing short of miraculous. Baby Finn was born on January 2nd 2015. Finn means 'little warrior' and, true to his name, he began to fight! Finn has had a heart surgery and multiple other surgeries but he continues to improve and has truly beaten all odds and is alive and well and recently headed home from the hospital! He is full of life and happiness and has affected more lives than anyone ever thought possible. Kelly made the most of her time in the hospital with Finn and went out of her way to help the families in the hospital and in her community that are going through similar struggles. &nbsp;</p><br><p>During Finns extended hospital stay, the Parkers frequently heard about how grateful the Blumenthals were for the support they received from the Ronald McDonald House. The Ronald McDonald House (RMH) makes it possible for families like Finns to stay close to their little ones during some of the most difficult days of their little lives. Inspired by Finns strength and the incredible support that the RMH was to the family, Stephanie Parker, creator of the Zipadee-Zip, designed the Finn print to help raise money for this amazing organization and family! Ten percent of sales will go to help support the RMH and one dollar from each sale will also go to help pay the Blumenthal familys mounting hospital bills! The Finn Zipadee-Zip and the Finn Flying Squirrel Toddler PJ will also be available to purchase for donation. Kelly will personally deliver any donated item to families in need. &nbsp;</p><br><p>Stephanie Parker recently paid a surprise visit to baby Finn in the hospital to deliver the very first Finn Zipadee-Zip and Flying Squirrel PJ in person! The Blumenthals couldnt have been more thrilled to finally meet each other in person for the first time!</p><br><p><img width="400" alt="image1png" src="http://s3.amazonaws.com/mprgenieproduction/binaries/121188/image1-png" height="266" title="Image: http://s3.amazonaws.com/mprgenieproduction/binaries/121188/image1-png"></p><br><p>Our Sleeping Baby business is so much bigger than just the Zipadee-Zip, says Stephanie, who marvels at how their little sleep invention has done so much more than improve sleep. </p><br><p>This is what its all about, she says, helping families in a big picture kind of way! We feel like this business has been such an incredible gift from God and it is a great honor to be able to help others however we can! I hope people are inspired by this story to focus on the incredible amount of light that can come as a result of lifes darkest moments. I would encourage people to not be afraid of sharing their struggles because you never know who it might impact.</p><br><p><img width="192" alt="finn1png" src="http://s3.amazonaws.com/mprgenieproduction/binaries/121188/finn1-png" height="275">&nbsp; &nbsp;<img width="183" alt="finn2png" src="http://s3.amazonaws.com/mprgenieproduction/binaries/121188/finn2-png" height="275">&nbsp; &nbsp;<img width="207" alt="finn3png" src="http://s3.amazonaws.com/mprgenieproduction/binaries/121188/finn3-png" height="275"></p><br><p>Order the Limited Edition Finn Zipadee-Zip for the Ronald McDonald House Charities here (SIZES 3M-24M): &nbsp;<a href="http://www.sleepingbaby.com/products/the-finn-zipadee-zip" target="_blank">http://www.sleepingbaby.com/products/the-finn-zipadee-zip</a>&nbsp;</p><br><p>Order the Limited Edition Finn Flying Squirrel PJ for the Ronald McDonald House Charities here (SIZES 24M-5T):&nbsp;<a href="http://www.sleepingbaby.com/products/the-finn-flying-squirrel" target="_blank">http://www.sleepingbaby.com/products/the-finn-flying-squirrel</a></p><br><p>For more information and to keep updated on Finns progress visit&nbsp;<a href="https://www.facebook.com/prayersforbabyfinn" target="_blank">https://www.facebook.com/prayersforbabyfinn</a>.</p><br><p>Note to the media:&nbsp;To schedule an interview with Stephanie and Brett, contact Giselle Diaz at&nbsp;<a href="mailto:%20pr@sleepingbaby.com" target="_blank">pr@sleepingbaby.com</a>&nbsp;and CC Stephanie at&nbsp;<a href="mailto:Stephanie@sleepingbaby.com" target="_blank">Stephanie@sleepingbaby.com</a>&nbsp;or call 914-325-9786.</p><br><p>###</p><div><br></div></div>
<b></b><b></b><p><u>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE</u></p><p>Contact: Lisa Dion, thehazeplaypress@gmail.com</p><p><b>An estimated 400,000 rapes are currently being ignored at the hands of local law enforcement in the United States.</b></p><p><b>One woman wrote a tragicomic play to call attention to her 2.5 year ignored rape and rape evidence in enlightened San Francisco, CA</b></p><p><b>THE HAZE</b></p><p><b>A SOLO PLAY WRITTEN AND PERFORMED BY HEATHER MARLOWE</b></p><p><b>ONE NIGHT EXCLUSIVE ENGAGEMENT</b></p><p><b>in Memphis, Tennessee</b></p><p><b>Presented by the Theater Department&nbsp;</b><b>at Rhodes College</b></p><p><b>September 3rd, 7:30pm</b></p><p><b>McCoy Theatre</b></p><p><b>2000 North Parkway</b></p><p><b>Memphis, TN 38112 </b></p><p><b>August 18th, 2015, Memphis, TN: <i></i></b><i><a href="http://www.theatrebayarea.org/news/201595/Breaking-Through-The-Haze.htm" target="_blank">THE HAZE</a></i><b><i>, </i></b>a provocative solo show by writer and performer Heather Marlowe&nbsp;will tour to Rhodes College University to perform a one night engagement at McCoy Theatre.</p><p>An enthralling, sharp-witted, and autobiographical tragicomedy about the aftermath of being drugged and raped while attending San Franciscos annual Bay to Breakers event, <i><b></b>THE HAZE<b></b> </i>has generated local and national attention for its critique about how rape cases are mishandled even in liberal, progressive cities like San Francisco, CA.</p><p><i>THE HAZE</i> comes to Memphis at a moment when the city -- in both facing its 12,000 rape kit backlog and a <a href="http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/28732595/dozens-more-women-join-untested-rape-kits-lawsuit" target="_blank">related class action lawsuit by over two dozen rape victims</a> -- has chosen to allocate resources to launch a crisis management campaign called NO MORE. <a href="http://www.judgedoyel.com/domestic-violence/the-memphis-rape-kit-backlog-victims-oppressors-the-mayor-and-enablers-jhf-no-more/" target="_blank">NO MORE</a> gained notoriety when the entity was hired by the NFL during the infamous Ray Rice debacle. &nbsp;</p><p><b>ABOUT <i>THE HAZE:</i></b><br></p><p><b><i></i><i></i></b><i>THE HAZE</i><b><i></i><i></i></b><i> </i>began its development in 2012 and has received workshops in San Francisco and New York. <b><i></i></b><i>THE HAZE</i><b><i>&nbsp;</i></b>was a 2013-14 recipient of The Yerba Buena Center for the Arts grant in San Francisco. The Haze had a 12 date run at the Costume Shop at American Conservatory Theater in September, 2014 and has since toured to Michigan State University and University of Southern California.</p><p><b><i></i></b><i>THE HAZE</i><b><i></i></b><i> </i>has been featured several times on local and national media. This coverage along with Marlowes performances resulted in the San Francisco Police Department auditing and releasing the numbers of their several thousand rape kit backlog. <b><i></i></b><i>THE HAZE</i><b><i></i></b>&nbsp;is further is credited with San Francisco Police Department expediting and processing 753 of its ignored rape kits, however, due to the citys 2015 crime lab scandal that exposed potential irregularities in the criminal evidence of thousands of cases, this progress remains in the balance.</p><p><b>ABOUT THE WRITER AND PERFORMER:</b></p><p><b>Heather Marlowe (Performer/Playwright)</b> has been on stage as an actress/performer, dancer, and musician since 2007. She has studied theater and performance with Kristin Linklater, Gabrielle Roth, and at Berkeley Repertory and American Conservatory Theater. Her work has been most recently seen at University of Southern California, Michigan State University, Porchlight Storytelling Series, W. Kamau Bells Solo Performance Workshop, and Boxcar Theatre. As a violinist and vocalist she has performed with San Francisco based bands <i>Thee Landlords</i> and <i>Winchester Revival</i>. Heather is currently working on a mockumentary. </p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>                                                                                       </p><p>###</p>
<p>Benedictine College in Atchison, Kan., has earned recognition for its status as an "All Steinway" School.</p><p>In May, 17 new Steinway pianos were delivered, part of an overall plan to enhance the music department. More pianos were delivered through the summer, with the final three, including a concert grand, arriving on Monday.</p><div><p>Now every piano on the campus, from classrooms to rehearsal rooms to the recital hall and performance venues, is a Steinway.</p></div><div><p>Steinway &amp; Sons is the top piano manufacturer in the world, said Stephen D. Minnis, president of Benedictine College. Their pianos, made by hand in New York, define excellence. Being designated an All-Steinway School demonstrates a commitment to the arts and a commitment to excellence."</p></div><div><p>A total of 172 colleges and universities have been designated as All-Steinway Schools. Missouri Western State University also has received All Steinway status.</p></div>
<div><br></div><div><div>The renowned instruments are created by a highly skilled team at a factory in Hamburg</div><div><div><img alt="Chief voicer Wiebke Wunstorf fine-tuning a Steinway before it leaves the factory" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/f2e50b07-637e-436e-a29b-cf5e65c30db7.img" title="Image: http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/f2e50b07-637e-436e-a29b-cf5e65c30db7.img">©Steinway &amp; Sons<p>Chief voicer Wiebke Wunstorf fine-tuning a Steinway before it leaves the factory</p></div>T<p>here is nothing to be improved. Now, thats not a phrase to strike a chord in many boardrooms in this age of restless innovation, efficiency and customer service. But, as Sabine Höpermann continues, making Steinway grand pianos is a perfect art. So why change it?</p><div><div><ul><li><a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F182826ec-26ea-11e5-bd83-71cb60e8f08c.html&amp;text=The%20key%20to%20perfection%3A%20how%20a%20Steinway%20piano%20is%20made%20-%20FT.com&amp;original_referer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F182826ec-26ea-11e5-bd83-71cb60e8f08c.html&amp;related=fttheworld&amp;via=FT"></a></li><li><a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F182826ec-26ea-11e5-bd83-71cb60e8f08c.html&amp;t=The%20key%20to%20perfection%3A%20how%20a%20Steinway%20piano%20is%20made%20-%20FT.com+|+House%20%26%20Home"></a></li><li><a href="https://plus.google.com/share?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F182826ec-26ea-11e5-bd83-71cb60e8f08c.html"></a></li><li><a href="http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&amp;url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F182826ec-26ea-11e5-bd83-71cb60e8f08c.html&amp;title=The%20key%20to%20perfection%3A%20how%20a%20Steinway%20piano%20is%20made%20-%20FT.com+|+House%20%26%20Home&amp;summary=The+renowned+instruments+are+created+by+a+highly+skilled+team+at+a+factory+in+Hamburg&amp;source=Financial%20Times"></a></li></ul></div><div><div><h3>More</h3></div><h4>IN HOUSE &amp; HOME</h4><ul><li><a href="http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f8b7b74c-3b5b-11e5-8613-07d16aad2152.html">Naturist dilemma laid bare</a></li><li><a href="http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/adbffc44-35df-11e5-bdbb-35e55cbae175.html">Strong alms tactics to deal with beggars</a></li><li><a href="http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d55fe870-3078-11e5-91ac-a5e17d9b4cff.html">Too fat for first class</a></li><li><a href="http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/69133ffe-364b-11e5-b05b-b01debd57852.html">Englands finest parks and gardens</a></li></ul></div><div><h3><a href="http://www.ft.com/nbe?firstft=Y">Sign up now</a></h3><div><a href="http://www.ft.com/nbe"><img alt="firstFT" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/8290489e-64f2-11e4-ab2d-00144feabdc0.img"></a></div><p>FirstFT is our new essential daily email briefing of the best stories from across the web</p></div></div><p>Höpermann is guiding me through the wood stores of the Steinway piano factory in an unremarkable industrial area of Hamburg, Germany, en route to meeting some very special artisans, including the first artisanal ear in this series. The company was founded by Heinrich Engelhard Steinweg, who fled to New York after the European revolutions of 1848-9. Having once built a piano in his kitchen, he and his sons worked in American piano factories, understanding each part in detail before combining their skills to make pianos of intense technical refinement. On March 5 1853, having already completed 482 models, Steinway &amp; Sons was founded.</p><p>A Hamburg factory was opened in 1880 to cope with the European demand for what became renowned as the best concert piano, without the cost of shipping them from New York. The two factories still duplicate manufacturing processes, following what are now 127 patents.</p><p>We still make every piano from outside to inside, Höpermann says. The process starts with the choice of timbers: spruce, maple and mahogany. Thickly sawn boards are stacked for a couple of years to allow them to dehumidify, and then sent to a trockenkammer  a drying room  to bake at 70C for up to four weeks, reducing their humidity to 6 per cent. The stabilised slabs of maple and mahogany are then wheeled into a resin-scented workshop to be cut into thin sheets and glued as veneered plywood. Mahogany is used on the faces and centre (rarer woods feature on the finest editions), layers of maple set between, to a thickness of a few inches. This wet, ligneous sandwich, perhaps 10ft to 15ft long  and 1.5ft in width  is bent and clamped in the shape of a great harp, which will be a grand pianos outer case called the rim, in length between 155cm and 274cm, according to the model. Though the rim will have dried in just a few hours, the glue reintroduces humidity to the wood, which needs clamping and controlled storage for 100 days.</p><div><img alt="Heinrich Steinweg who founded the Steinway company in 1853" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/94242b5e-2b60-11e5-8613-e7aedbb7bdb7.img">©Steinway &amp; Sons<p>Heinrich Steinweg, who founded the company in 1853</p></div><p>Then a spruce frame braces the base of the rim and supports the wooden soundboard, which will resonate beneath the strings. The rigorous process of timber selection has by now eliminated 55 per cent of the mahogany and maple and 80 per cent of the spruce, all of which gets pulped for Steinways unusually fragrant eco-boiler.</p><p>The rim is now a case. Even before being sprayed with black polyester resin buffed to a mirror finish 0.5mm thick, it receives a cast-iron frame, which has the job of bracing 20 tonnes of tension from all the tightened strings. The frame is made by OS Kelly, an American foundry owned by Steinway. It arrives roughly finished awaiting smoothing and spray-painting in deep gold, with hand-finished lettering.</p><p>The strings are made in-house by Damien Kolanck, 17 years a string-maker. It was my dream always, to work for Steinway, he says. His workshop is stacked with rolls of steel and copper wires, which he winds into coils with precision. How much string do you make a year? I ask. He frowns, not having made the calculation. It turns out to be 80km (49 miles), which the factorys annual output of 1,400 pianos gobbles up.</p><div><ul><li><img width="600" alt="Steinway piano soundboard" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/bdc0e63a-d664-4eea-a6f7-4d06bbc732dc.img" height="338" title="Image: http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/bdc0e63a-d664-4eea-a6f7-4d06bbc732dc.img"><div>Inside a Steinway piano<div>©Steinway &amp; Sons</div></div></li><li><img alt="making a Steinway piano" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/de8dc613-f114-418e-8b96-95b32686a523.img" title="Image httpimft-staticcomcontentimagesde8dc613-f114-418e-8b96-95b32686a523img"><div>Most of the tasks that go into making a piano are still done by hand<div>©Steinway &amp; Sons</div></div></li><li><div>Shaping tools for the pianos<div>©Steinway &amp; Sons</div></div></li><li><div>Shaping tools, many of which have not changed for decades<div>©Steinway &amp; Sons</div></div></li><li><div>Individual pieces are glued by hand<div>©Steinway &amp; Sons</div></div></li><li><div>Craftsmen at the Hamburg factory fit the rim, made of up to 20 solid, hardwood layers<div>©Steinway &amp; Sons</div></div></li><li><div>Chief voicer Wiebke Wunstorf fine-tuning a Steinway before it leaves the factory<div>©Steinway &amp; Sons</div></div></li><li><div>Heinrich Steinweg, who founded the company in 1853<div>©Steinway &amp; Sons</div></div></li><li><div>Russian composer and pianist Sergei Rachmaninov with his granddaughter, in a postcard he sent to the company to thank them for his piano<div>©Steinway &amp; Sons</div></div></li></ul></div><div><ul><li><img width="114" alt="" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/c0046d8a-f478-4699-bc0f-6b27c5537aff.img" height="64"><div></div></li><li><img width="114" alt="" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/c689c158-f399-4c8f-b4ea-e2398fa33f29.img" height="64"></li><li><img width="114" alt="" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/35a0283f-10ec-4b06-8700-80f5cb64e7c7.img" height="64"></li><li><img width="114" alt="" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/8c0328bb-cf3b-44c7-973a-05d4c258639b.img" height="64"></li><li><img width="114" alt="" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/c243860a-a484-4d6a-bd43-394da6f0a503.img" height="64"></li><li><img width="114" alt="" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/def88032-18bd-4ee6-89ba-8437825e142f.img" height="64"></li><li><img width="114" alt="" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/dd4d027f-1427-4386-9dbf-b10420b2fe98.img" height="64"></li><li><img width="114" alt="" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/866f9f86-85e2-49dd-9321-4c5703d29a8f.img" height="64"></li><li><img width="114" alt="" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/bfbc137f-bc41-4992-b94d-afcb0688d6d9.img" height="64"></li></ul><div>Next Thumbnails</div></div><p>Next, the keyboard is assembled. Sanna Rastas is one of half a dozen keyboard regulators. She came to Hamburg from Finland for a three-year apprenticeship at Steinway, learning how to adjust the complex mechanism of 88 keys, each with a wooden arm to lever up the felt-clad hammers that strike the strings with a subtle responsiveness. She weighs each, and adjusts them as necessary, using a mirror to see inside the mechanism. Sometimes a small flame is waved under the levers to make adjustments in the wood cells. Each key affects the next  getting the balance right takes three days. Given this understanding of the instrument, I presume she must play the piano.</p><p>No, I dont. But I will one day.</p><div>A&nbsp;Steinway is so well-made that, we know when a customer picks one, we will never see them&nbsp;again<div><a>Tweet&nbsp;this quote</a></div></div><p>Its a response I hear many times. Höpermann tells me she doesnt need to play to appreciate the piano as an object. In this quasi-monastic factory every artisan knows their role, with a log book proudly signed for each completed step of the process. And if few play the piano, the staff all revere their instruments. They are bound for the worlds great concert halls, into the hands of the finest interpreters who will embolden, intrigue and break the hearts of audiences in their thousands.</p><p>Different pianos suit the style of different players. Here, we reach the stage of tuning and finding character, two different things. The latter is the job of Wiebke Wunstorf, chief voicer.</p><p>Every instrument has tones that are not right, she says. Listen. She presses three keys  one has the faintest rasp. Its sharp. She pulls out the keyboard and jabs a three-pronged hand-tool into a felt hammer to loosen the fabric, and slides the keyboard back in. No, still off. And again she jabs and smoothes. Perfect. The words she chooses to describe what she seeks are clear, powerful, long notes, so that the piano should sing, with a variety of colour. But no one knows exactly what I mean by this. No machine can replicate her ear, which optimises the distinctive character that is innate in every piano.</p><div><img alt="making a Steinway piano" src="http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/af1c851e-2b60-11e5-8613-e7aedbb7bdb7.img" title="Image httpimft-staticcomcontentimagesaf1c851e-2b60-11e5-8613-e7aedbb7bdb7img">©Steinway &amp; Sons<p>Individual pieces are glued by hand</p></div><p>Since being the first female apprentice, Wunstorf has been at Steinway for 36 years. This dedication is not unusual. In 2014, 425 staff had served 25 years; 85 had worked for 40 years. One has stuck with Steinway for 60 years.</p><p>Throughout this production line of amazing crafts, I hadnt heard about customer service. Presumably maintenance is an issue? Höpermann shrugs. Of course, everything needs to be looked after. But a Steinway is so well made, we know that when a customer has chosen their piano from our saleroom, well never see them again.</p><h2>Noteworthy milestone</h2><p>Steinway &amp; Sons unveiled the companys 600,000th piano, The Fibonacci, at Masterpiece London on June 24 2015. The piano, created by renowned wood-designer Frank Pollard, features the iconic Fibonacci spiral on the veneer and is made entirely from natural Macassar ebony. It will be a prestigious addition to the previous milestone models: the 100,000th Steinway &amp; Sons piano is part of the permanent collection at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington DC, while the 300,000th piano resides in the White Houses East Room.</p><p>Photographs: Steinway &amp; Sons</p></div></div>
Jeffrey Biegel is one of the busiest and most versatile pianists around. A Steinway Artist, he is both fiery champion of the classical repertoire and top pick among today's classical composers to debut their work. Jeffrey also maintains an active recording schedule -- three albums are being released this summer. The creation stories behind the recordings suggest the force of Destiny. For sure, one of them includes the intervention of an honest-to-God angel. The first album debuted last week -- Symphonic Arrangement: Suite for Flute and Jazz Piano. "I've loved Claude Bolling's suite my whole life," said Jeffrey. "I've also had this crazy idea that it would sound great with orchestra." Enter composer/arranger Steve Barta.<br>Jeffrey Biegel. Courtesy of the artistIn 2008, I was playing with the Colorado Springs Philharmonic and got together with Steve Barta. I mentioned my idea about adding orchestra to Bolling's Suite. Steve has had the same idea since long back. 'You're the jazz guy,' I said, 'why don't you do it?' He agreed. There was no commissioning fee, nothing. But we had to get Claude Bolling's permission. 'Do what you want,' he replied, 'but do not change the original score. The suite has been played around with before. Don't do anything but the original. But you can add to it.' So, that's what Steve did. He also single handedly raised all the money to get the project done.Renowned flutist Hubert Laws was secured for the recording, also Brazilian drummer Michael Shapiro and bassist Mike Valerio. Illustrator Roger Huyssen -- whose cover for the 1975 LP is itself a collector's item -- tweaked his original design into an intriguing new vision. The original recording pairs Claude Bolling on piano with flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal. It is pure magic. It stayed on Billboard's Top 40 charts for nearly ten years.<br>Covers for 1975 and 2015 LP and CD. Courtesy of the artist.Back then the idea was to just make it a jazz combo piece. It's like what Vince Guaraldi was doing all those years with the 'Peanuts' music - it was a small group. Most of the jazz that was written was not with symphony orchestra. It was small ensembles. The only jazz that was really written with symphony orchestra was Gershwin's Concerto in F. Also, Duke Ellington had a small orchestra for his New World a-Comin', then came Copland's Clarinet Concerto, and Lalo Schifrin's Piano Concerto no. 2 -- a huge jazz concerto. There wasn't a lot of symphonic jazz with soloist. Bolling's was a combo piece -- a suite for flute and jazz piano with a drummer and a bass. That's all he needed. It took all these years until Steve and I were eye-to-eye and shared a common idea that gave it birth. Luckily, Bolling said, 'Sure, go for it.' What's great is that it's going to be available as a vinyl LP, a CD and digital download. Not only are people excited about the recording and the premiere, but there is interest among the flutists in the world to play it. I will do the world premiere in November with the South Shore Symphony on Long Island. The conductor is Scott Jackson Wiley and they're bringing in Hubert Laws. My son Evan is a member of the orchestra in the percussion section.<br>Courtesy of Entertainment One Music/ENTOn August 7, eOne Music will release Volume 2 of Mozart: The Complete Sonatas For Piano. It has been sitting in the queue for the past five years, the entire body of work having been recorded before 2010. Volume 1 was released in 2009 on the Koch label -- which was then bought out by eOne Music, a primary division of Entertainment One. Susan Napodano DelGiorno produced the entire set of recordings. Susan and Jeffrey collaborated on his 2007 solo album, Classical Carols -- 21 tracks of familiar Christmas carols exquisitely arranged by Carolyne Taylor. For the Mozart project -- a prime component in Jeffrey's m.o. was to pump new life into the repeats, some of which the composer had not written out. Jeffrey already knew he could rely on Susan's discerning ear -- not only for the structure of his ornamentations, but for pace and continuity.Susan has impeccable taste. She knows what's going to sound well to the listener. When you're in the recording studio, part of you thinks, 'This is going to be forever --&nbsp;after I'm long gone.' You want the recording to be a certain way. So, you're really putting your trust in the hands of the producer and the engineer. You want them to listen with the same ears as you -- before you play a note. You want them to hear and feel what you're doing, to play along with you. If there is something you intended to do, but it didn't quite come out that way -- they will be sensitive to that. That is a really great engineer or producer. I want the listener to feel that the ornamentation I've added in the repeats is a result of what the music says to me, rather than just me adding ribbons and bows to what is already there. Throughout the entire recording process, I kept coming back to a quote from my teacher, Adele Marcus -- 'Don't do anything to the music. Let the music do something to you.' The thing I'm most careful about is not to allow any recording to become so sterile and so clean to the point that it lacks emotional adrenalin.<br>Jeffrey Biegel and Lucas Richman. Courtesy of the artistsOn September 1, Albany Records releases Lucas Richman's Concerto for Piano and Orchestra: In Truth. Richman leads the Pittsburgh Symphony in this sumptuous work dedicated to Jeffrey Biegel. The concerto was first presented by the Knoxville Symphony Orchestra in October 2013 during Lucas Richman's tenure as Musical Director and with Jeffrey at the piano. The adventure of it all borders on the stuff of a medieval Miracle Play. Lucas wanted to write a piano concerto for me. He said, 'Probably for the first time in your life, you won't have to raise the money for the commission. I want to write it.' I looked at him and said, 'God bless you! It's the first time anybody ever said that to me.' He decided he would write this concerto and whatever he could get as a grant, he got. It was very minimal. This was a labor of love.The three movements of Richman's concerto, In Truth, are titled: To One's Self, To One's World, To One's Spirit. Using a musical cryptogram -- taking the notes of the scale (A-G) and assigning them to the letters of the alphabet (r = D, x = C) -- the composer formed melodic lines based on the word Truth (F D G F A ) and it's Hebrew equivalent, Emet (E F E F). The words -- now a series of memorable notes -- were then coupled, separated, reversed, turned up one side and twisted down the other. All the while, Richman remains grounded in two sacred texts:"Strengthen the bond between your inner feeling and The One who watches over you."<br>"The Lord is near to all who called him -- to all who called him in truth."The end result is a sweeping work that is cinematic in scope, its three movements transcending into a guided uber meditation, with the pianist standing-in for us all -- confessing, in truth. It's like being in front of the burning bush. The radiance is awesome, you are compelled to surrender.A few weeks after the premier in Knoxville, Lucas calls me. 'You're not going to believe this. Someone from the audience approached me and said -- You have to record that concerto.' Lucas tells him he would love to, but it's very expensive to make a recording. How much? Like, a hundred thousand dollars? And the guy says -- OK.' Lucas then tells me we'll be recording it with the Pittsburgh Symphony. That was the payback for his writing such a brilliantly beautiful new concerto. Lucas didn't do it for what he might get paid. He did it because he wanted to.The recording is a live concert. It was a special added concert, free to subscribers and donors. We rehearsed, had a dress rehearsal, then the performance. The engineers were only allowed to use material from the dress rehearsal and the performance. Then a patch session after and I recorded the cadenza separately without the orchestra. I couldn't be happier. Albany Records has wonderful engineers -- Elizabeth Ostrow and The Sound/Mirror recording team -- top recording engineers in the country. Liz did a beautiful job of editing. It sounds like a million bucks.<br>Lucas Richman and Jeffrey Biegel. Courtesy of the artists.Click here to stay in touch: Jeffrey Biegel
Shen Lu invokes water imagery throughout these selections from his recital program blending Chinese folk music with more traditional classical fare by Ravel and Rachmaninov and ending with Tan Duns ode to his childhood in Hunan, Eight Memories in Watercolor<br><br>Distinguished pianist and 2014 Hilton Head International Piano Competition jurist John OConor, declared that gold prize winner "Shen Lus interpretations have great depth, his technique seems effortless, and he communicates wonderfully with his audience." Shens prize includes this collaboration with Steinway &amp; Sons  a debut recording from an exceptional young artist. The Steinway &amp; Sons label releases Shen Lus Watercolor on August 11, 2015.<br><br>Based on Shens award-winning recital program, water imagery flows throughout the albums selections. Watercolor opens with Chen Peixuns arrangement of a 1930s Chinese folk song Autumn Moon on a Calm Lake (Lü Wencheng); a gentle melody driven downstream through the constant movement of broken arpeggios working in concert with rippling textures. The calmness is broken by Maurice Ravels masterwork Miroirs with its five movements each dedicated to a fellow member of the French avant-garde artist group, Les Apaches.<br><br>The eight pieces of Rachmaninovs Etudes Tableaux, Op. 33, among the last pieces written in the composer-soloist tradition, are a study in musical moods  "picture studies" of the highest order, running the gamut of human expression and serving as musical evocations of external visual stimuli.<br><br> <br><br> The album concludes with Hunan-born Tan Duns Eight Memories in Watercolor, conceived by the composer when he left Hunan to study at the Central Conservatory of Music in Beijing. Homesick and longing to savor the folk songs and memories of his childhood in the era of Chinas burgeoning Cultural Revolution, this first solo piano work by Tan Dun presents a diary of longing and features four of his favorite childhood folk songs.<br><br>A native of Jiangsu, China, Shen Lu has performed concerts at Beijings Central Conservatory Music Hall, Weill Recital Hall and Carnegie Hall in New York, Jordan Hall in Boston, Severance Hall in Cleveland, The Kennedy Center in Washington DC, The County Museum of Art in Los Angeles, the Seymour Centre in Sydney, and the National Concert Hall in Dublin. He was a prize-winner at the 59th Wideman, the 4th Campillos, the 2nd Florida, and the 25th Ferrol International Piano Competitions, and won best French music prize for Ravels Miroirs at the 2015 Dublin International Piano Competition. He earned his Bachelors Degree at the Central Conservatory of Music in Beijing under Wu Ying, and his Masters and Graduate Diploma from the New England Conservatory in Boston under Alexander Korsantia. Mr. Shens other teachers included Li Siying, Huang Tiandong, Chen Zihua, and his father Shen Guofu. He is currently studying with HaeSun Paik at the Cleveland Institute of Music for his Artist Diploma Degree.<br><br>About Steinway &amp; Sons label<br><br> The Steinway &amp; Sons music label was founded in 2010 and has produced many phenomenal albums since its inception. Recordings on the Steinway &amp; Sons record label can be purchased through ArkivMusic.com as well as Amazon, iTunes and other fine retailers around the globe. This collaboration under the umbrella of the historic Steinway &amp; Sons is a perfect vessel for producing the finest quality recordings by some of the most talented pianists in the world.<br><br>About Steinway &amp; Sons<br><br> Since its founding in New York in 1853, Steinway &amp; Sons has been considered the world's premier piano manufacturer. Known for their exceptional craftsmanship, Steinway &amp; Sons pianos are built in one of two company-owned and operated factories: Astoria, New York and Hamburg, Germany. Steinway &amp; Sons pianos are still constructed primarily by hand, using many of the techniques developed over 160 years ago. Today, Steinway &amp; Sons also offers the Boston and Essex piano lines, Listen, a magazine for music and culture lovers, and the Steinway &amp; Sons record label. For more information, visit <a href="http://www.steinway.com">www.steinway.com</a>.<br><br>Press Contact:<br><br> Anthony Gilroy<br><br> Steinway &amp; Sons<br><br> .(JavaScript must be enabled to view this email address)<br><br> (718) 204-3116
Renowned Designer Frank Pollaro Creates "The Fibonacci," A Masterpiece That Celebrates The Art of Handcraftsmanship<br><br>Steinway &amp; Sons, manufacturer of the worlds finest pianos, today unveiled the companys 600,000th piano, stunningly designed by master artisan, Frank Pollaro. Handcrafted using natural Macassar ebony, the end result is a feat of artistry, engineering and precision that celebrates this milestone for Steinway &amp; Sons and demonstrates the companys ongoing commitment to uncompromising craftsmanship.<br><br>Named "The Fibonacci," the pianos veneer features the iconic Fibonacci spiral made entirely from six individual logs of Macassar Ebony, creating a fluid design that represents the geometric harmony found in nature. The lines of The Fibonacci spiral on the top of the pianos lid are projected down to its unique curved base. Synthetic ivory inlay adds a breathtaking effect to the design, which also features unique patinated bronze details. In the end, over 6,000 hours of work over a four-year period were devoted to the creation of The Fibonacci, from design to finish. The superior craftsmanship of the pianos exterior is matched only by the unparalleled craftsmanship that is at the very core of all Steinway &amp; Sons pianos.<br><br>According to Frank Pollaro, "Designing Steinway &amp; Sons 600,000th piano was an honor and a challenge. To me, knowing that this piano would become part of history meant that it had to be more than just a beautiful design, but also needed to visually convey a deeper message." Pollaro added, "As I considered the number 600,000, the Fibonacci spiral came to mind. The way in which it continues to grow but stay true to its form is very much like Steinway &amp; Sons over these many years. Combining the universal languages of music and mathematics suddenly made perfect sense."<br><br>"Steinway &amp; Sons has a long tradition of world-class craftsmanship, so as we began planning the 600,000th piano, it quickly became apparent that Frank Pollaro was the artist we needed for creative design and perfect execution. His ability to create unforgettable images through woodwork demonstrates artistry at the highest level, something that spoke to the very core of what this company is all about," stated Darren Marshall, Chief Marketing Officer of Steinway &amp; Sons. Adding, "The Fibonacci spiral is a representation of perfect proportions and natural beauty. Without a doubt, Frank captured those qualities in this piano, creating a work of art for the eyes and the ears."<br><br>The Fibonacci is destined to become an important piece of cultural history, taking its place of honor amongst previous milestone models that the company has created. The 100,000th was originally given to the United States White House and is now part of the permanent collection at the Smithsonian Institute in Washington D.C., while the 300,000 piano currently resides in the East Room of the White House.<br><br>In April The Fibonacci was previewed during a special VIP reception at Steinway &amp; Sons new showroom in Beverly Hills, where the internationally celebrated Steinway Artist, Lang Lang, had the honor of being the first artist to perform on the piano. This June The Fibonacci will travel to the United Kingdom, where it will be showcased at the 2015 Masterpiece London art fair.<br><br>The Fibonacci is a Steinway &amp; Sons Model D piano, nine foot concert grand, priced at $2.4 million. In addition to the original 600,000th version, Steinway &amp; Sons will create up to six exclusive, limited edition Model B pianos (610.5") inspired by the same design.<br><br>For more information about The Fibonacci, please contact Laura Seele at +1 (646)356-3960<br><br>About Frank Pollaro<br><br> As a young man, Frank Pollaro became interested in the master works of furniture designer Jacques-Emile Ruhlmann. He fell in love with the way Ruhlmann used ivory as an embellishment against rich, dark wood backgrounds. Fascinated by the natural colors and textures of exotic woods, he began to collect solid wood and veneer from all corners of the world, a passion that he has continued for more than 30 years. His collection currently contains over 80 species and the largest collection of rare woods in private hands.<br><br>Twenty-seven years after founding Pollaro Custom Furniture, Franks work continues to win critical acclaim from leading collectors, designers and architects, who consider a Pollaro piece to be the crown jewel of their interiors. Additionally, his furniture has won numerous awards for both design and craftsmanship. Today, Frank and his team are considered the finest furniture makers in the world. Capable of replicating skills of a century ago, they are also masters of cutting edge materials and techniques.<br><br>In addition to the pursuit of challenging commissions, Frank also actively preserves his craft through teaching at leading furniture making programs throughout the country. For more information, visit <a href="http://www.pollaro.com">www.pollaro.com</a>.<br><br>About Steinway &amp; Sons<br><br> Since its founding in New York in 1853, Steinway &amp; Sons has been considered the world's premier piano manufacturer. Known for their exceptional craftsmanship, Steinway &amp; Sons pianos are built in one of two company-owned and operated factories: Astoria, New York and Hamburg, Germany. Steinway &amp; Sons pianos are still constructed primarily by hand, using many of the techniques developed over 160 years ago. Today, Steinway &amp; Sons also offers the Boston and Essex piano lines, Listen, a magazine for music and culture lovers, and the Steinway &amp; Sons record label. For more information, visit <a href="http://www.steinway.com">www.steinway.com</a>.<br><br>Press Contact:<br><br> Stephen Millikin<br><br> Steinway &amp; Sons<br><br> .(JavaScript must be enabled to view this email address)<br><br> (646) 356-3980
Many organizers asked me&nbsp;how we built an engaging startup community at CoInvent. The answer can always be simplified and broken down to two parts  people (team) and technology. In this post, Im going to focus on the latter part  technology  a.k.a. social platforms or content management tools. If you have attended a CoInvent event in the past, you either registered on Meetup or Eventbrite. In addition, Mailchimp is our choice for sending newsletter and group email messages. So&nbsp;I will&nbsp;focus on the pros and cons of each of these platforms below.<br><br>According to Meetup.com, Meetup is the worlds largest network of local groups. Meetup makes it easy for anyone to organize a local group or find one of the thousands already meeting up face-to-face.<br><br>The CoInvent concept was practically founded as a small Meetup group in May, 2009. Over the past 6 years, we were able to build&nbsp;one of the largest startup/entrepreneur Meetup groups in the world.<br><br>Meetup.com is&nbsp;one of the original event management software tools. It revolutionized the way people organize events. It enables organizers to create groups and host events based on specific interests and hobbies. Every group on Meetup is closely connected to each other. Members can join as many groups as they wish. If&nbsp;people talk about your events positively, your Meetup group can grow real fast. Meetups ecosystem is well developed in big cities&nbsp;and metropolitan areas.<br><br>1). Meetup.com doesnt disclose members email info to group organizers even though they belong to their groups. And there is no way for&nbsp;organizers to collect that info either<br><br>2). Meetup&nbsp;groups are&nbsp;good for organizing local events as in one particular region or area. If you have a New York group but want to hold an event in Boston, you have no choice but have to start another&nbsp;Meetup group<br><br>3). Meetup can also be considered as a ticketing platform. Sadly, it doesnt let organizers add multiple tickets with different tiers of pricing<br><br>4). Although Meetup has been around for more than 10 years, its not uncommon for you to see the fail-whale sign from time to time. I vividly remember that Meetup suffered a DDoS attack on March 2nd, 2013, and had a hard time staying up for an entire week. For organizers who solely rely on the Meetup platform to host events, its really bad news if one of their events experiences&nbsp;these downtimes too<br><br>5). There isnt a way to turn off the comment feature for Meetup events. When someone posts a comment, it automatically gets delivered to every attendees email inbox. I think Meetup should make the comment feature optional in the future so organizers can turn it off for the group if they deem it necessary. Personally, Id much prefer to have a conversation with our group members on Twitter or our Facebook page<br><br>Eventbrite is a global marketplace for live experiences that allows people to find and create events.<br><br>We integrate the Eventbrite platform to the CoInvent website. Its considered the official registration tool for our non-Meetup crowd.<br><br>Eventbrite seems to be the perfect choice for event organizers these days. It seems to understand the business its in and doesnt have a lot of distractions other than its ticketing features. For me, what makes Eventbrite unique and useful is its ability to integrate with our own website and the fact that event hosts can put out several types of tickets at the same time.<br><br>Compared to Meetup.com, Eventbrite doesnt have the community aspect. But you can also consider that as a pro if you prefer its simplicity. Also at this moment, it seems that Eventbrite is very heavy on business and tech events. Not many sports and concert events can be found there.<br><br>MailChimp is an email marketing service for users to send email newsletters, manage subscriber lists, and track campaign performance.<br><br>We use Mailchimp to send our newsletter, local event alerts, and special announcements almost every week. All our non-Meetup contacts are stored in our Mailchimp database. Without Mailchimp, we wouldnt be able to communicate with our subscribers and most of our members.<br><br>1). Mailchimp has clear guidelines on how to conduct email marketing. Make sure all your contacts are opt-in emails. Otherwise, your newsletters or messages can be easily flagged&nbsp;as spam. This killer feature leaves no room for spammers<br><br>2). The data analytics tool that Mailchimp provides gives marketers all types of real-time metrics  open rates, click rates, subscriber demographics, click map, bounce rates, opt-out rates, etc. This in turn helps campaigners get a better understanding of their audience<br><br>3). Mailchimp lets you add an opt-in form to your website or link it to an url. This is a great branding feature. For example, CoInvents newsletter subscription link is&nbsp;<a href="http://www.GetCoInvent.com">www.GetCoInvent.com</a><br><br>1). Mailchimp can get pretty&nbsp;expensive once you reach a critical mass&nbsp;for your subscribers  usually start with 30,000 subscribers. You can view its pricing here<br><br>2).&nbsp;Certain&nbsp;email servers&nbsp;flag&nbsp;Mailchimp emails as spam (even though its legit). An example is qq emails. Ive contacted Mailchimp about this as we have some readers in China, but it doesnt seem that Mailchimp has a solution for this at this moment<br><br>Needless to say, different combinations of different social networking platforms will generate different results for growing your business. There are other content management tools to help you build a personal/consumer brand, such as WordPress, Twitter, LinkedIn, YouTube, and Mightybell. No matter what tools to choose, its imperative to keep it simple. No organizations have the resources to do them all. So choose cautiously. And only choose those you understand. Also keep in mind that building an audience takes time.&nbsp;Patience is a virtue.
<p><b>Dallas-Based AccelSPINE Named to Inc. 5000 List</b></p><p><b>Medical Device Company Receives National Recognition for 132% Growth</b></p><p>DALLAS, TEXAS (August 20, 2015) Inc. magazine has named Dallas-based AccelSPINE® to its prestigious Inc. 5000 list, an exclusive ranking of the nations fastest-growing private companies. This year the medical device manufacturer and designer is ranked 2,752 nationwide, with a 132 percent growth over a three-year period. According to the magazine, the 2015 honorees represent the most competitive crop in the lists history.</p><p>"The story of this years Inc. 5000 is the story of great leadership. In an incredibly competitive business landscape, it takes something extraordinary to take your company to the top, said Inc. President and Editor-in-Chief Eric Schurenberg. You have to remember that the average company on the Inc. 5000 grew nearly six-fold since 2012. Business owners dont achieve that kind of success by accident."</p><p>Started in 1982 to recognize the nations most successful private companies, the list has become the hallmark of entrepreneurial success. Companies such as Yelp, Pandora, Timberland, Dell, Dominos Pizza, LinkedIn, Zillow and many other well-known names gained early exposure as members of the Inc. 5000.</p><p>The 2015 Inc. 5000 list is ranked according to percentage of revenue growth when comparing 2011 to 2014. To qualify, companies must have been founded and generating revenue by March 31, 2011. In addition, they had to meet strict revenue minimums and be U.S.-based, privately held, for profit and independent as of Dec. 31, 2014. The 5,000 fastest-growing candidates were named to the list. Complete results, including company profiles and an interactive, searchable database of the winners, can be found online at <a href="http://www.inc.co">www.inc.co</a>m/inc5000.</p><p>Being recognized by such a prestigious publication is a tremendous honor. Inc. Magazine is one of the nations leading business publications, and we are grateful to be included, said Daniel Chon, president and CEO of AccelSPINE.</p><p>Founded in 1979 and acquired in 2005 by Mansueto Ventures, Inc. is the only major brand dedicated exclusively to owners and managers of growing private companies, with the aim to deliver real solutions for today's innovative company builders. Like the companies it recognizes, Inc. also has experienced great growth. The monthly audience reach for the brand has grown significantly from 2,000,000 in 2010 to over 13,000,000 today. In addition, it was the winner of the National Magazine Award for General Excellence in both 2014 and 2012. For more information, visit <a href="http://www.inc.com">www.inc.com</a>.</p><p>AccelSPINE® is a nationally recognized medical device company headquartered in Dallas, Texas. The company designs, develops and manufactures spinal implants and instruments tailored to fit the unique needs of surgeons and patients. For more information, call 800-713-9489 or visit <a href="http://www.accelspine.com/" title="Link: http://www.accelspine.com/">www.accelspine.com</a>.</p>
<p>With the Internet came many new advertising opportunities. Popup, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adobe_Flash">Flash</a>, banner, Popunder, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advergaming">advergaming</a>,  and email advertisements (all of which are often unwanted or spam in  the case of email) are now commonplace. Particularly since the rise of  "entertaining" advertising, some people may like an advertisement enough  to wish to watch it later or show a friend.[<i><a title="Link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed">citation needed</a></i>]  In general, the advertising community has not yet made this easy,  although some have used the Internet to widely distribute their ads to  anyone willing to see or hear them. In the last three-quarters of 2009  mobile and internet advertising grew by 18% and 9% respectively. Older  media advertising saw declines: ?10.1% (TV), ?11.7% (radio), ?14.8%  (magazines) and ?18.7% (newspapers).[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed">citation needed</a></i>]</p><br>
Uber isnt happy with&nbsp;its competitors in China. The U.S. ride-sharing Goliath has spoken out for the first time about being blocked on WeChat, Chinas hugely popular mobile messaging platform&nbsp;which is run by Tencent, an investor in Uber rival Didi Kuaidi.<br><br>Emil Michael, the Uber exec who found himself in hot water after making comments about journalists last year, lamented the freezing of Ubers WeChat account to Bloomberg. Uber had a range of accounts set up on WeChat  which is arguably more&nbsp;important for customer relations in China than&nbsp;a Facebook Page is in the West&nbsp; but things began to change following&nbsp;the billion dollar merger between Didi Dache and Kuaidi Dache in February.<br><br>From then on is when you start to see a deterioration in the competitive environment, and it hit a crescendo where our [WeChat] accounts actually got shut off in March, Michael said to Bloomberg.<br><br>We contacted Uber and Tencent for comment, but neither company provided a response. (Well update if and when they do.)<br><br>The first sign of a block&nbsp;did indeed come in March of this year, when Ubers official account was removed, apparently due to&nbsp;violating rules.&nbsp;WeChat then reportedly scrubbed out all mentions&nbsp;of Uber from the services search feature&nbsp;in July to further hide the service from users. Couple this&nbsp;with a recent investment in Didi Kuaidi from Chinas sovereign wealth fund, and you have all the ingredients for Tech Outrage.<br><br>Even though Uber claims over a million rides per day in China, which it said will overtake its U.S. business, the company believes the WeChat block is curtailing its potential.&nbsp;Its easy to see how this situation frustrates Uber  which, by the way, is currently raising funding for its China business; Bloomberg said Michael is leading that charge  since WeChat has such a huge following in China, where the majority of its 500 million-plus active users are thought to be based.<br><br>But lets not feign surprise. This is life on the internet, and life in China.<br><br>Tencent uses WeChat to further a lot of its goals. For example, JD.com  the rival to Alibaba that Tencent invested in  is integrated with the service to allow WeChat users to place orders from inside the app. Didi Dache and Kuaidi Daches services&nbsp;still exist separately despite the merger, and the former is also baked into WeChat so you can order a taxi in seconds without ever leaving the app.<br><br>Tencent has also, to its credit, added lots of other utility and convenience-centric services to WeChat, so you can pay your bills and do other daily tasks more easily. But, on the business side,&nbsp;its&nbsp;investors would be concerned if the service was managed in such a way that rivals were profiting from it at their own expense.<br><br>Uber should know better. When you use someone elses platform, youre subject to their rules and, at times, their decisions.<br><br>It wasnt so long ago that Facebook would cut access to its platform for a range of social services that competed with it some way, shape or form. Heck, Twitter stills does it,&nbsp;as the team at Meerkat, a rival to Twitters Periscope live-streaming app, can attest to.<br><br>What makes Uber feel this situation is so different?<br><br>Maybe, as I wrote last year, its the arrogance that comes with being a $40 billion company frequently referred to as disruptive.<br><br>Uber is used to knocking down barriers as part of its&nbsp;determined push to change the world (using its vision of whats best)  but all too often that rampant enthusiasm manifests itself in ugly scenarios, such as Michaels comments about media, the tracking of users and other things that bubbled up last year when I argued&nbsp;that the companys moral compass was corrupted and in need of a reset.<br><br>In this case, Uber isnt harming anyone, but it looks foolish and desperate and perhaps even&nbsp;hypercritical, too.<br><br>Uber has its own power relationship in China, courtesy of search giant Baidu which made a strategic investment in the U.S. firm&nbsp;in early 2015.<br><br>One of the fruits of that coming-together is that Uber is the taxi-app of choice in Baidu Maps, Chinas largest consumer maps app, while Uber enjoys prime positioning within other Baidu services, which include Chinas top search engine.<br><br>The maps arrangement is&nbsp;similar to that which Uber enjoys with Google in the West  is that really all that different to Tencents position on WeChat?<br><br>Either way, Michael said he believes that Tencent will change its tune once it becomes apparent that Uber isnt going anywhere.<br><br>I think as we continue to succeed, and its clear were in this for the long haul  weve got Chinese investors behind us; weve got partnerships with cities; were spending money in the local economy; local investors have an interest in our success  then well get into more of a détente mode,&nbsp;he told Bloomberg.<br><br>Good luck. Tencents WeChat-related feuds&nbsp;with rivals like Alibaba, Qihoo 360 and others have never entered détente mode.<br><br>Beyond the issues at hand, Michaels comments&nbsp;falsely paint Uber as a total outsider in China. Thats convenient in this case, where things dont suit, but it does a disservice to the companys localization efforts which  despite some arguments&nbsp;otherwise&nbsp; are actually impressive in China and across Asia. Yes, Uber is an American company, but it has adapted to local markets in a far better manner than the latest running of Emil Michaels mouth would have you believe.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 24, 2015 /PRNewswire/ --&nbsp;Procrastinators can still make it to the head of the class on back-to-school shopping savings, especially with book and textbook purchases. As families and college students turn to the No. 1 most powerful "back-to-school" retail brand1 Barnes  Noble, they can earn 5% back on all purchases in-store and online by using the Barnes  Noble MasterCard, issued by Barclaycard.<br><br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  When buying college textbooks, the 5% back on Barnes  Noble purchases adds up fast. According to The College Board2, the average cost for books and supplies last year was $1,225 at public colleges and $1,244 at private colleges. Based on that spending, using the Barnes  Noble MasterCard for those purchases at Barnes  Noble campus stores or at BN.com could provide $60 in immediate savings on one year's books. Over the course of four years, a full-time undergraduate student could have a total savings of nearly $250, simply by using their Barnes  Noble MasterCard when getting school books and supplies.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  "Barnes  Noble is the perfect back-to-school destination for families and students buying school supplies, from books to science and math products, and so much more," said Jaime Carey, chief operating officer at Barnes  Noble. "No other retailer can match the carefully curated selection Barnes  Noble offers students of all ages throughout the school year."<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  The Barnes  Noble MasterCard is the only card that gives you 5% back on all Barnes  Noble purchases in-store, online and at one of its 724 campus stores nationwide. The credit card has no annual fee and offers other benefits such as a $25 Barnes  Noble gift card after the first purchase and an additional $25 gift card for every 2,500 points earned. <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  "The Barnes  Noble MasterCard is an ideal card for parents of school-age children or college students spending a significant amount of money on textbooks and books for school," said Jennifer Brown, assistant vice president of retail partnerships at Barclaycard US. The expanded features will include earning 2 points for every $1 spent at restaurants and the ability to earn 12 months of Barnes  Noble Membership after spending $7,500 per year on eligible purchases. The expanded benefits will be available to new cardmembers starting Sept. 2, and Nov. 15 for existing cardmembers.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  Benefits exclusive to the Barnes  Noble MasterCard<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																																		<br>5% back at Barnes  Noble when you use your card at any Barnes  Noble store and online at BN.com <br>Earn a $25 Barnes  Noble gift card after your first purchase <br>New! The Company operates 648 Barnes  Noble bookstores in 50 states, and one of the Web's premier e-commerce sites, BN.com. The Nook Digital business offers a lineup of popular NOOK® tablets and eReaders and an expansive collection of digital reading and entertainment content through the NOOK Store®. The NOOK Store features more than 4 million digital books in the US and UK, plus periodicals, comics, apps, movies and TV shows, and offers the ability to enjoy content across a wide array of popular devices through Free NOOK Reading Apps available for Android, iOS® and Windows®.<br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  About Barclaycard&nbsp;USHeadquartered in Wilmington, Del., Barclaycard US is the fastest-growing top 10 U.S. credit card issuer. The company creates customized, co-branded credit card programs for some of the nation's most successful travel, entertainment, retail, affinity and financial institutions. The business also issues its own Barclaycard branded credit cards:&nbsp;Barclaycard Ring, Barclaycard Rewards, and the&nbsp;Barclaycard Arrival&nbsp;product series.&nbsp;For more information on Barclaycard please visit&nbsp;BarclaycardUS.com.<br><br><br><br><br>__________________________<br><br><br><br>1 Tenet Partners study of the Top 20 Most powerful "back-to-school" retail brands. Tenet Partners is a leading brand innovation and marketing firm, and its annual study of approximately 10,000 consumers and business decision-makers found that Barnes  Noble has the highest familiarity (degree of awareness) and favorability (positive perception) scores among leading back-to-school retailers.<br><br><br><br>2 The College Board's Trends in College Pricing Report, <a href="http://trends.collegeboard.org/sites/default/files/2014-trends-college-pricing-final-web.pdf">http://trends.collegeboard.org/sites/default/files/2014-trends-college-pricing-final-web.pdf</a> (Student Budgets, 2014-15; p. 12)<br><br><br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  Photo - <a href="http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnh/20150821/260292">http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnh/20150821/260292</a> <br><br> 					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									  &nbsp;<br><br>  					  					 			   		  	 		  			   																																									 			   		  	 		  			   										<br>										 										SOURCE  Barclaycard US
<p>The <b>beaver</b> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genus">genus</a> <i><b>Castor</b></i>) is a primarily <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nocturnal_animal">nocturnal</a>, large, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semiaquatic">semiaquatic</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rodent">rodent</a>. <i>Castor</i> includes two <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extant_taxon">extant</a> species, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_American_beaver">North American beaver</a> <i>(Castor canadensis)</i> (native to North America) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurasian_beaver">Eurasian beaver</a> <i>(Castor fiber)</i> (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurasia">Eurasia</a>).<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaver#cite_note-MSW3-1">[1]</a> Beavers are known for building dams, canals, and lodges (homes). They are the second-largest rodent in the world (after the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capybara">capybara</a>).  Their colonies create one or more dams to provide still, deep water to  protect against predators, and to float food and building material. The  North American beaver population was once more than 60 million, but as  of 1988 was 612 million. This population decline is the result of  extensive hunting for fur, for glands used as medicine and perfume, and  because the beavers' harvesting of trees and flooding of waterways may  interfere with other land uses.<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaver#cite_note-MotW5-2">[2]</a></p><br>
