<p>Study shows 82% of customer experience professionals want more education</p><p>PHILADELPHIA, PA  December 1, 2015  After more than a decade of writing and speaking about the values of customer experience in the retail, hospitality, financial and health care industries, Mohamed Latib, Ph.D., is launching CX University, the first comprehensive, online curriculum to teach the elements of customer experience.</p><p>The difference between a great executive and an exceptional one is a disposition to learn, says Latib, who has over 35 years of corporate higher education experience curating programs to improve individual and companywide performance.</p><p>Latib said that surveys he and others have conducted influenced him to use his expertise to create an education program that is affordable, easily accessible, and universally applicable across all industries.&nbsp; The content has been expertly designed for rapid learning so that participants can quickly start using their newfound knowledge to assure a positive customer experience.</p><p>CX University will be the premier center for customer experience education, training, and contemporary knowledge, Latib said. The companys learn anywhere and anytime model features teaching concepts that are immediately applicable. Its not just about what to learn, how to learn, when to learn, and why to learn  it is also about action learning, building relevance through immediate application.</p><p>Diane Magers, a member of CXUs Thought Leader Faculty group observes, The clarity of how to launch, accelerate, and find the rewards of customer engagement are the hallmark of this dynamic curriculum. Wherever you are in your journey, you need someone beside you. CXU is there both now and in the future as you grow your skills and your CX acumen.</p><p>To learn more about CX University or to register for the program leading to professional certification, go to <a href="http://www.cxuniversity.com" target="_blank">www.cxuniversity.com</a>.</p><p>For more information, contact:</p><p>Mohamed Latib, PhD</p><p>mlatib@cxuniversity.com</p><p>610-730-5967</p>
<p>                   </p><p><i>Purrrfect Presents For Purchase Benefit Homeless Animals</i></p><p><b>What:</b> </p><p>Starting Black Friday, <a href="http://www.operationkindness.org/opk/"><b>Operation Kindness</b></a> will have animals available for adoption at Galleria Dallas. </p><p>Who:</p><p>Operation Kindness, the original and largest no-kill animal shelter in North Texas</p><p>When:</p><p>Black Friday, November 27, 2015 through Christmas Eve, Thursday, December 24,2015</p><p>Monday-Saturday 11 a.m.  7 p.m. and Sundays, 12 p.m.  6 p.m.</p><p>Where:</p><p>Operation Kindness Holiday Adoption Center, located near Banana Republic on Level 1 of Galleria Dallas  13350 Dallas Parkway in Dallas, Texas 75240.</p><p>Details:</p><p>During Operation Kindness Holiday Adoption Days at the Galleria, shoppers can interact with adoptable dogs and cats, learn about volunteer opportunities, adopt a furry friend or shop for unique gifts that benefit Operation Kindness including: </p><p>·&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  <b>Happy Tails Society memberships</b>  Give the gift of life all year long by helping to cover the cost of medical care, shelter and food. Recipients will receive a Happy Tails Society decal, holiday card and a monthly e-newsletter featuring a Happy Tale of how their membership is making a difference. Starting at $19 a month, this gift is tax-deductible for the purchaser.</p><p>·&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  <b>Prepaid adoption gift certificates for a dog or cat with accompanying food bowl and accessories</b>. Each gift certificate costs $200 and is valid for 90 days after the initial purchase to ensure the perfect pet is available. If the perfect pet is not available or the recipient does not wish to adopt an animal the gift certificate can be refunded. </p><p>&nbsp;<b>About</b> <b>Operation Kindness</b></p><p>Founded in 1976, Operation Kindness is the original and largest no-kill shelter in North Texas.<b> </b>Its mission is to care for homeless cats and dogs in a no-kill environment until each is adopted into responsible homes and to advocate humane values and behavior. Operation Kindness has saved nearly 80,000 animals since its inception. The shelter assists more than 5,000 dogs and cats each year, caring for an average of 300 animals daily with another 100-150 animals in foster homes.</p><p>Join Operation Kindness in their mission to care for homeless animals by becoming a member of the Happy Tails Society. This group of dedicated friends provides a monthly gift to help pay for medical care, medicine, food, shelter, nurturing and behavior training the pets need to have a second chance at life. Learn more about Operation Kindness at <a href="http://www.OperationKindness.org" title="Link: http://www.OperationKindness.org">http://www.OperationKindness.org</a> or on Facebook (<a href="http://www.facebook.com/pages/Operation-Kindness/30251945822">www.facebook.com/pages/Operation-Kindness/30251945822</a>).</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>###</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><b>Contact:</b></p><p>Katie Hill-Mudd</p><p>TrizCom PR</p><p>Katie@TrizCom.com</p><p>Office: 972-247-1369</p><p>                                                                              </p><p>Cell: 214-676-4254</p>
<p>DALLAS, TEXAS (November 25, 2015) A bright future is ahead for North Texas-based <a href="http://www.soulmans.com/">Soulmans Bar-B-Que</a>. Its 40-plus-year-old brand is seeing booming growth surpassing 500 percent during the last eight years. Currently with fifteen established restaurants, 11 have emerged in the last eight years under the leadership of Brett Randle, CEO of Soulmans Bar-B-Que.</p><p>With plans to continue expansion, Randle explains what makes Soulmans so successful and why this growth is possible.</p><p>                                                    As a team we are passionately committed to keeping things true and simple. &nbsp; Our future growth depends on a daily focus on what makes our restaurants successful--great food, great service and clean environment in which to enjoy it. Preserving our heritage is vital to us at Soulman's.  As a 41 year old brand, we try hard to stay away from trendiness.  We are a traditional Texas Bar-B-Que house. We do things the accepted way, the right way, and were resolved to continue that through our growth, says Randle.</p><p>This classic style of barbecue enables Soulmans to pursue continued growth with four more restaurant locations anticipated to open.</p><p>In 2008, we had four locations and weve grown to 15. We have 16, 17, 18 and 19 already on the way for 2016, adds Randle.</p><p>And this growth has nothing to do with luck. In a commodity market that relies on fluctuating meat prices, Soulmans has been able to adjust to these market changes and come out on top. When beef prices soared last year, Soulmans strategized to provide the best, affordable and tasty options for their customers.</p><p>2014 was a challenging year with regard to Cost of Goods.  Specifically, brisket prices sky-rocketed to unprecedented levels very quickly.  Considering Brisket makes up approximately 35% of Soulman's food spend, a near 100% increase in a matter of months was potentially catastrophic.  However, our team rose to the challenge. &nbsp; We introduced more efficient products, re-negotiated food deals and created new menu items that would sway our product mix away from brisket. Overall the plan was a great success, Randle says.</p><p>Compared to the national average of restaurant growth, Soulmans is a standout establishment. According to the <a href="https://www.restaurant.org/Downloads/PDFs/News-Research/research/ForecastExecSummary2015-FINAL.pdf">National Restaurant Associations 2015 Executive Summary</a>, restaurant-and-foodservice sales are projected to top $709 billion, up 3.8 percent from 2014. In comparison to similar markets, Soulmans percentage of growth shines.</p><p>Restaurantnews.com shares the 2013 <a href="http://www.restaurantnews.com/restaurant-chain-growth-report-52813/">Restaurant Chain Growth Report</a>, which compares Soulmans growth in 2013 with other restaurants with fewer than 20 units. Compared with other lunch and dinner restaurants like El Taco Tote based in El Paso, TX which has experienced a 15 percent growth, Soulmans increased their business by 22 percent in 2013.</p><p><b>About Soulmans Bar-B-Que<br> </b>For more than 40 years, Soulman's&nbsp;Bar-B-Que has satisfied the hardest to please barbecue loversTexans! Their selections of meats are cooked low and slow over hickory in a time-honored tradition: beef brisket, ham, hot links, sausage, turkey, chicken, pulled pork and, the crowd favorite, ribs. Ranch House Beans and Spicy Cream Corn are among the delicious homemade sides.</p><p>Soulmans currently owns and operates 15 North and East Texas locations in Cedar Hill, Dallas, Forney, Garland, Greenville, Hurst, Lancaster, Mesquite, Quinlan, Rockwall (2), Royse City, Terrell, Van and Allen. To learn more about Soulmans Bar-B-Que, visit them online at <a href="http://www.soulmans.com/">http://www.soulmans.com</a> or on Facebook at <a href="https://www.facebook.com/soulmansbbq">https://www.facebook.com/soulmansbbq</a>.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>###</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><b>Media Contact:</b></p><p>Dana Cobb</p><p>TrizCom PR</p><p><a href="mailto:Dana@TrizCom.com">Dana@TrizCom.com</a></p><p>O: 972-247-1369</p><p>                                                        </p><p>C: 972- 955-9747</p>

<p><i>Industrys First 24/5 Precious Metals Trading app Is Even More Powerful</i></p><p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; ADDISON, TX (December 1, 2015)  The buying, selling and trading of precious metals just became even more powerful and convenient. Using leading edge technology, Dillon Gage Metals has launched a Web application for FizTrade.com, providing dealers with tools far beyond basic trading. The revolutionary Web app provides a custom trading experience along with business management tools, all via Android and Apple phones and tablets. &nbsp;<br></p><p>The launch of FizTrades mobile application comes at an opportune time for Dillon Gage Metals dealer network. According to the latest industry research, more consumers now get their digital information from mobile devices versus desktops in a ratio of approximately 60-40 percent. </p><p>Another recent study shows that consumers expectation of a streamlined experience is quickly rising. The FizTrade mobile application enables our dealers to provide the best possible experience to help meet their clients expectations. &nbsp;</p><p>Whether youre at home, on vacation or otherwise disconnected from your computer or place of business, FizTrade dealers can now access all features of their account on their smartphone, said Terry Hanlon, president of Dillon Gage Metals. The launch of the FizTrade app goes hand-in-hand with our continued commitment to provide the very latest in technology for our global clients, giving dealers the power to conduct their business.</p><p>Dealers who leverage the new FizTrade app will be able to:</p><p>	Access current market spot pricing and charts</p><p>	View the full product catalog with the dealers Dillon Gage Metals pricing</p><p>	Set quantity price levels and product pricing for retail customers</p><p>	Access detailed personal history of all previous trades with Dillon Gage Metals</p><p>	Track shipments via carrier tracking numbers</p><p>	Provide personalized shipping instructions for drop-shipping to customers</p><p>	View account balances</p><p>	Set target price alerts for gold, silver, platinum and palladium</p><p>This is just the beginning. In the next release of FizTrade mobile, we will provide white labeled mobile for our dealers to relay to their customers, says John Humphrey, executive vice president of the Digital Metals Division. Imagine being able to deploy real-time mobile e-commerce to your client base from a white labeled solution! This levels the playing field for small to midsized dealers.</p><p>In addition to the mobile application, FizTrade.com has undergone key enhancements to their website landing page, designed to deliver critical industry-related information as quickly as possible. On a single page, clients are now provided with a snapshot of all features related to precious metals trading with an emphasis on the most recent spot prices and information available. In addition, FizTrade.com has highlighted their series of quick and easy video tutorials, designed to foster understanding and ease of use. </p><p>FizTrade.com is the worlds leading precious metals trading and technology services platform. To access the FizTrade mobile web application, account holders can simply launch m.FizTrade.com. For more information, please visit FizTrade.com or call (800) 375-4653.</p><p># # #</p><p><b>About Dillon Gage Metals</b></p><p>Dillon Gage Inc. of Dallas (DillonGage.com), founded in 1976, companies include:</p><p>	Dillon Gage Metals (<a href="http://www.DillonGage.com/Metals">www.DillonGage.com/Metals</a>), one of the worlds largest precious metals wholesale trading firms. The firm is an authorized purchaser for all major world mints and maintains inventory in over 20 countries around the world. 800-375-4653</p><p>	FizTrade Online Trading (<a href="http://www.FizTrade.com">www.FizTrade.com</a>) offers real-time bid/ask trading platform for gold, silver, platinum and palladium. 800-375-4653</p><p>	Digital Metals (<a href="http://www.DigitalMetals.com">www.DigitalMetals.com</a>) delivers advanced tools and technologies that enable market participants to be more successful in their businesses. Digital Metals offers cloud-based solutions for the physical precious metals marketplace built upon the Digital Metals Platform. 866-494-3577 </p><p>	Dillon Gage Refining (<a href="http://www.dillongage.com/refining/why-dg">www.dillongage.com/refining/why-dg</a>), professional assayers and refiners of precious metal scrap, from low grade to karat scrap. Stone removal services and diamond experts on staff. 888-436-3489</p><p>	International Depository Services Group with locations in Delaware, USA (<a href="http://www.ids-delaware.com">www.ids-delaware.com</a>; 888-322-2431), and Ontario, Canada (<a href="http://www.idsofcanada.com">www.idsofcanada.com</a>; 855-362-2431), offers secure, efficient and insured precious metals and certified coin depositories that focus of custom business logistics solutions which include storage, fulfillment, inventory managements and many other value added services. </p><p><br></p><p><b>Contact:</b></p><p>Jeffrey Cheatham</p><p>Senior Account Manager</p><p>TrizCom PR</p><p>(972) 247-1369</p><p>jeffc@trizcom.com</p><div><br></div>
<p><b>What:</b> Santa is coming to town for pet photos at <a href="http://www.operationkindness.org/opk/"><b>Operation Kindness</b></a> Kindness Klubhouse!&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </p><p><b>Who:</b> Operation Kindness, the original and largest no-kill animal shelter in North Texas</p><p><b>When: </b>Dec. 5-6 and Dec. 12- 13, from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. No appointment necessary.</p><p><b>Where: </b>Kindness Klubhouse, 13394 Preston Road, Dallas, TX 75240</p><p><b>Details:</b> Pet parents can bring their dogs and cats and whole family to sit on Santas lap and pose for photos. A helper will snap 10-15 photos per session. &nbsp;Pet parents can choose to have their favorite photo framed in a 4x6 format for $10, or receive a 4x6 framed photo and a thumb drive with all of the photos for $25. These photos make great holiday cards and all proceeds benefit <b>Operation Kindness.</b></p><p><b>About</b> <b>Operation Kindness</b></p><p>Founded in 1976, Operation Kindness is the original and largest no-kill shelter in North Texas.<b> </b>Its mission is to care for homeless cats and dogs in a no-kill environment until each is adopted into responsible homes and to advocate humane values and behavior. Operation Kindness has saved nearly 80,000 animals since its inception. The shelter assists more than 5,000 dogs and cats each year, caring for an average of 300 animals daily with another 100-150 animals in foster homes.</p><p>Join Operation Kindness in their mission to care for homeless animals by becoming a member of the Happy Tails Society. This group of dedicated friends provides a monthly gift to help pay for medical care, medicine, food, shelter, nurturing and behavior training the pets need to have a second chance at life. Learn more about Operation Kindness at <a href="http://www.OperationKindness.org">http://www.OperationKindness.org</a> or on Facebook (<a href="http://www.facebook.com/pages/Operation-Kindness/30251945822">www.facebook.com/pages/Operation-Kindness/30251945822</a>).</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>###</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><b>Contact:</b></p><p>Katie Hill-Mudd</p><p>TrizCom PR</p><p>Katie@TrizCom.com</p><p>Office: 972-247-1369</p><p>                                                             </p><p>Cell: 214-676-4254<a></a></p>
<p>'Tis the season: Lines, lines everywhere. But shoppers are getting better at putting that down time to good use, studies show, by shopping online with their phones. <a href="http://www.socialcentiv.com/">SocialCentiv</a>, whose software helps companies find customers on Twitter, has some holiday marketing tips to help marketers maximize their e-commerce and mobile campaigns, and ring up more jingle.<br></p><p>Ad spending is an area where retail marketers need to catch up: They play Scrooge with dollars designated for mobile e-commerce campaigns, while favoring traditional marketing.<br></p><p>Retail sales in the U.S. in the November and December holiday season should clock in at $885.7 billion, up 5.7 percent over the same period in 2014, according to <a href="http://www.emarketer.com/Article/Happy-Holiday-Season-Expected-Retailers/1012898">eMarketer</a>. E-commerce should account for 9 percent of total U.S. retail sales in this holiday season, up from 8.3 percent in 2014, eMarketer forecasts.</p><p>Some of the biggest change in retail shopping is coming from consumers increasing willingness to buy via mobile devices like smartphones. By the end of 2016, one out of every four dollars that retailers generate through e-commerce will originate on a mobile device, eMarketer projects.</p><p>Yet recent data suggests that many companies have yet to shift enough of their marketing efforts to the Internet, especially the mobile arena, according to Bernard Perrine, co-founder and CEO of SocialCentiv.<br></p><p>In 2014, of every hour that U.S. consumers spent watching, listening to or reading media like television, radio, print publications or the Internet, they spent more than 14 minutes on mobile devices, Perrine says. But a recent Kleiner Perkins <a href="http://www.kpcb.com/blog/2015-internet-trends">report</a> shows that only 8 percent of U.S. advertising spending last year went toward ad platforms like smartphones and tablets.</p><p>The Kleiner Perkins data show that U.S. advertisers were pouring too much money into media like print and television in 2014, because their audiences had shifted toward wireless devices, Perrine notes.</p><p>That is an opportunity for marketers who know how to capitalize.</p><p><b>Four points to success</b><br></p><p>There are four basic elements to maximizing a companys marketing efforts online and on mobile, according to Jason Dove, SVP of sales and marketing at SocialCentiv:</p><p></p><ul><li><b>Set goals.</b> As <a href="https://www.ometria.com/blog/ecommerce-marketing-strategy-blueprint">Ometria</a> has noted, companies must know what theyre looking to achieve in a campaign and have a reliable measuring stick to help determine when theyve hit the mark, Dove says.<br></li><li><b>Know thy customer</b>. This means doing in-depth research on demographic questions like age and income, along with learning where a businesss clientele hang out in cyberspace and what devices they use when they visit.<br></li><li><b>Attract and convert</b>. A strong understanding of who buys a companys products or services, and why they purchase, will inform the methods the business uses to spur interest in prospective customers, Dove explains. Its important to optimize Web pages to increase the odds of transactions getting done, with Ometria suggesting steps such as replacing carousel images with static ones on the home page.<br></li><li><b>Measure and adjust</b>. Every business is unique, as is every campaign it runs to bring in new customers. It is important to keep close tabs on the results of every marketing push, and to make changes as things proceed to get the best bang for the corporate buck, Dove adds.<br></li></ul><p></p><p><b></b></p><p><b></b></p><p><b></b></p><p><b>Follow up, personalize</b><br></p><p>With consumers being bombarded with dozens or hundreds of marketing messages daily, marketers must go the extra mile to ensure their pitches are relevant to individuals in their target market. The stronger the emotional connection an individual feels with a brand, the better the chances he or she will buy, Dove says.</p><p>And since even the most loyal customers cant respond to every marketing outreach, companies are well served by following up to help ensure their message gets heard. Research <a href="http://www.adweek.com/socialtimes/mobile-marketing-and-the-future-of-e-commerce/626602">suggests</a> that selective persistence can boost response rates, but the key is to avoid overdoing it.<br></p><p>E-commerce and mobile marketing are full of nuances, many of which can help make or break a sale, Perrine adds. This is why companies can benefit from getting outside expertise on the ins and outs of this emerging endeavor.<br></p><p>A strong marketing partner can help make the cash register chime, he says. And during the holidays in particular, that is music to a CEOs ears.<br></p><p><b>About SocialCentiv</b></p><p>SocialCentiv is a full-service Twitter marketing company that helps companies find new customers on Twitter with their patented software. Using a business keywords and geographic location, SocialCentiv combs Twitter in real time looking for relevant Tweets that express an intent to purchase a product or service. The business can @ reply directly back to potential customers with a customized, personal message and a discount or offer to get them in the door. For example, @JaneDoe Tweets about being really hungry for pizza. A local pizza parlor finds her Tweet using SocialCentiv, and Tweets directly back with a personal message and a coupon for free salad and soda with her pizza at lunch. SocialCentiv has a 34 percent average click through rate, and some industries  like restaurants, hotels and sports marketing  have much higher averages.</p><p>Since May 2013, SocialCentiv has received $12 million in funding. For more information, go to <a href="http://www.socialcentiv.com/">www.SocialCentiv.com</a>, like us on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/socialcentiv">Facebook</a> and follow us on<a href="https://twitter.com/SocialCentiv"> Twitter</a>.<br></p><p># # #<br></p><p>For more information, contact Karen Carrera, TrizCom, 972-207-1935, <a href="mailto:karen@trizcom.com">karen@trizcom.com</a> or @kjcarrera.<br></p>
<p><a href="http://farmstarliving.com/home.php">Farm Star Living</a>, a national lifestyle brand promoting the farm to everything movement, is proud to announce their revamped lifestyle and healthy living outlet. Created and based in Atlanta, Farm Star Living also offers the first mobile app showcasing Farm to Table restaurants and Farms all across the country that are open for fun  searchable by location, name, or by proximity to you. </p><p>The new user-friendly, mobile responsive design and revamped content sections include:</p><ul>  <li><b>Features </b>- Monthly Farm feature stories with farm subjects      completely reimagined</li>  <li><b>Farm Stars</b>- Lifestyle      interviews with farmers </li>  <li><b>Food Health</b> - More than 50 items and their unique health      benefits, nutrition info, trivia &amp; more</li>  <li><b>Recipes</b> - Healthy recipes with produce and good-for-you food      items</li>  <li><b>Moms On-the-Go</b>! - Geared towards Moms who are busy, busy,      busy! Healthy snacks &amp; sips, easy meal solutions, videos, kid-friendly      recipes and food articles, not to mention a fun Kids Zone, Farm Star      Living provides extra focus on healthy food solutions for time-starved      Moms.</li>  <li><b>A-Z Farm Food</b> guide providing health, nutrition information,      and fun facts on more than 100 fruits, nuts, seeds, and vegetables.</li>  <li><b>Videos </b>- Quick and easy healthy recipes using farm-fresh food      ingredients</li>  <li><b>Visit / Find A Farm</b> - Search hundreds of farms across the USA      by location, even unique activity such as pumpkin patches, hayrides or      berry picking, or type of farm </li>  <li><b>Dining Guide</b> - Farm to Table restaurants in every major city      across the USA, searchable by location, map, amenities, types of cuisine </li> </ul><p>In 2009, Founder (and Atlanta resident) Mary Blackmon left her 20+-year career in publishing and internet media in NYC and LA in order to take over her family farm. <i>I was sitting in the middle of one of my rice fields one afternoon as the sun was setting, realizing how inspired I was by everything mostly the farmers passion and devotion to what has too often been seen as a thankless job. I realized that I wanted to create a lifestyle that others could easily embrace  if only for an afternoon or weekend, and, if so, lives would be enriched and empowered in new, meaningful ways. I wanted to connect farmers and non-farmers in a way that would be entertaining, relatable, and positive for everyone.</i> Most recently known as the founder of Spa Addicts, Atlanta resident Blackmon has spoken at conferences domestically and internationally, been quoted in dozens of newspapers and magazines including <b>O Oprah Magazine, Women's Health, Cosmopolitan, The New York Times</b>, etc. and featured on TV including <b>Extra TV, TV Guide, ABC News,</b> and countless others. She has been a featured columnist for <b>iVillage.com</b> and <b>Skin Inc.</b></p><p>                             For more information about Farm Star Living, please visit: <a href="http://ctt.marketwire.com/?release=1132529&amp;id=4424692&amp;type=1&amp;url=http%3a%2f%2fwww.farmstarliving.com%2f" title="Link: http://ctt.marketwire.com/?release=1132529&amp;id=4424692&amp;type=1&amp;url=http%3a%2f%2fwww.farmstarliving.com%2f">www.farmstarliving.com</a>, download the Free Farm Star Living App, and become a fan via: <a href="https://www.facebook.com/FarmStarLiving" title="Link: https://www.facebook.com/FarmStarLiving">https://www.facebook.com/FarmStarLiving</a> and on Twitter @FarmStarLiving.&nbsp; &nbsp; <br></p>
<p>Dec. 2, 2015  Santa Barbara, Calif.  <a href="http://www.impactradius.com/">Impact Radius</a>, the most comprehensive digital marketing platform, today announced it has acquired the Clearsaleing marketing attribution business from eBay Enterprise. This acquisition significantly expands Impact Radius portfolio of industry-leading media tracking and analytics products.<br></p><p>Impact Radius will leverage Clearsaleings pioneering experience in scientific media attribution, incorporating algorithmic technology into their Media Manager product. This includes data visualization and artificial intelligence capabilities that provide the Big Data insights brands and agencies need to increase their return on their ad spend. With Impact Radius Media Manager centralized data hub, marketers can deep-dive into key metrics to better track, analyze, and optimize their advertising campaigns for increased ROI.</p><p>"The digital advertising landscape is constantly evolving, leaving advertisers with the challenge of maximizing their media investments in real time," said Per Pettersen, Chairman and CEO of Impact Radius. "They need sophisticated cross-channel and cross-device tracking as well as statistical modeling and analytics. This acquisition means our customers will have access to these solutions as well as an exceptionally experienced team. Adding Clearsaleings innovative attribution and purchase path technology to our Media Manager platform gives customers the ability to turn data into actionable insights with immediate bottom-line impact.</p><p> </p><p>For a demo of the Impact Radius platform and more information on the comprehensive product suite, please visit <a href="http://www.impactradius.com">www.impactradius.com</a>.</p><p><b>About Impact Radius</b></p><p>Impact Radius digital marketing platform enables significant improvement in the return on global advertising spend for brands and agencies. The company provides a fully-integrated suite of products for media attribution, performance marketing, tag management and mobile analytics. Impact Radius provides a singular view into the consumer journey, tracks cross-channel marketing efforts, and delivers Big Data insights that drive revenue growth. Impact Radius serves companies around the globe including Cabelas, Deckers, Shutterstock, and Tommy Hilfiger. Learn more at <a href="http://www.impactradius.com/">ImpactRadius.com</a>. &nbsp;</p><p><br><br></p>
<p>Pharmaceutical and Medical Device Companies find themselves in the crosshairs for major matter bet-the-farm litigation and recent research tends to suggest that such large-scale litigation is going to increase. In order to best advise our clients as they respond to this shifting landscape, DOAR conducted empirical research designed to identify the key factors that contribute to jurors perceptions of product liability and defending companies, and how juror attitudes can be altered. What may be surprising is the vigor and specificity in feedback offered by individuals  as customers and as prospective jurors.<br></p><p>A presentation of DOARs research and findings is available to corporate legal departments and the lawyers who represent them. &nbsp;Click <a href="http://www.doar.com/pharmaceutical-and-medical-device-research/" target="_blank">here</a>&nbsp;to sign up for a presentation of this research and our recommendations.<br></p>
<p><a href="http://farmstarliving.com/home.php"><b>Farm Star Living</b></a>, a national lifestyle brand promoting the farm to <i>everything</i> movement, has just launched its 2015 Holiday Gift Guide identifying many amazing holiday gifts and stocking stuffers that are sure to delight everyone on your shopping list  including yourself.&nbsp; The guide features a variety of gifts that range from conflict-free diamonds from Lafonn, stylish and eco-friendly socks from Farm to Feet, decadent chocolate truffles from San Francisco chocolatier Nuubia, luxurious organic skincare from Dori Botanicals, vegan award-winning eyeliner from Bella Reina, craft cocktail must-haves such as Reeds Ginger Beer and other specialty beverages, functional yet chic bags/backpacks from Stone &amp; Cloth, pet must-haves and more.</p><p>Furthermore, anyone can win these items through Farm Star Livings page on&nbsp;<a href="http://woobox.com/ppuzqa">Facebook</a>. Enter daily now through December 14th  and whether you want to keep them yourself or give them away is completely up to you. No purchase necessary to win.&nbsp;</p><p>We love the spirit of the holiday and felt that it is one thing to select these items, but it is another to be able to give them to our friends and supporters. So, everyone can enter to win a great present themselves! We know how hard it is to find the perfect gift / stocking stuffer and we hope we took a bit of the burden off of our Farm Star Living audience, says Mary Blackmon, Founder.</p><p>In 2009, Founder (and Atlanta resident) Mary Blackmon left her 20+-year career in publishing and internet media in NYC and LA in order to take over her family farm.&nbsp;</p><p></p><blockquote>"I was sitting in the middle of one of my rice fields one afternoon as the sun was setting, realizing how inspired I was by everything mostly the farmers passion and devotion to what has too often been seen as a thankless job. I realized that I wanted to create a lifestyle that others could easily embrace  if only for an afternoon or weekend, and, if so, lives would be enriched and empowered in new, meaningful ways. I wanted to connect farmers and non-farmers in a way that would be entertaining, relatable, and positive for everyone."</blockquote><p></p><p>&nbsp;Most recently known as the founder of Spa Addicts, Atlanta resident Blackmon has spoken at conferences domestically and internationally, been quoted in dozens of newspapers and magazines including <b>O Oprah Magazine, Women's Health, Cosmopolitan, The New York Times</b>, etc. and featured on TV including <b>Extra TV, TV Guide, ABC News,</b> and countless others. She has been a featured columnist for <b>iVillage.com</b> and <b>Skin Inc.</b><b>&nbsp;</b></p><p>For more information about Farm Star Living, please visit: <a href="http://ctt.marketwire.com/?release=1132529&amp;id=4424692&amp;type=1&amp;url=http%3a%2f%2fwww.farmstarliving.com%2f">www.farmstarliving.com</a>, download the Free Farm Star Living App, and become a fan via: <a href="https://www.facebook.com/FarmStarLiving">https://www.facebook.com/FarmStarLiving</a> and on Twitter @FarmStarLiving.</p><p><br></p><p><b>MEDIA CONTACT:</b></p><p>Hannah Amick</p><p>                                                  </p><p>678.488.2909</p>
<p>A fairly complicated cocktail of rules has developed with regard to the packaging and labeling of statelegal marijuana. Why is it so complicated? In part because the subject matter is such: marijuana is lawful in some states merely for medicinal purposes, in others for adult recreation as well. In either case it may be sold simply as cannabis or as another product infused withcannabis. Making allowances for all that, though, some of the rules seem quite arbitrary, and in sum they may all be onerous to many actual or potential entrepreneurs. Indeed, one might take the cynical view that these rules serve as a back-door effort at repeal. After all, in many states such legalization as has come about has resulted from a grassroots movement and initiative/referendum, in essence from an end-run around the usual political/governing process. So (thinks the cynic), the governing class may be striking back by undermining legalization or limiting itsconsequences. That is the kind of thinking one encounters now and then in the NORML Blog. And one has to say, the burdens imposed on would-be entrepreneurs by onerous packaging rules fit all-too-nicely into this suspicion. Consider Nevada. The voters there approved of Ballot Question 9 back in November 2000. But due to bureaucratic feet-dragging of impressive proportions, the states Department of Health and Human Services did not announce its regulations until April 1, 2014, and only on July 31 of this year did the first dispensary in the state finally open itsdoors to authorized patients. Given such a long head start it may not be a surprise that Nevadas bureaucrats have developed an extensive list of rules on packaging, which may be found here: Chapter 453A. The rules provide, for example, that marijuana-infused products, whether in solid or liquid form, must be packaged in plastic which is 4 millimeters or more in thickness and must be heat-sealed without an easy-open tab, dimple, corner or flap  and that if they are in liquid form they must be sealed using a metal crown cork-style bottle cap. There are also rules on maximum unit supply (no single unit of marijuana packaging can include more than 2.5 oz. of the stuff) and there are nine required disclosures for the labeling. Yet the hypothesis that such regulations are the work of clever reactionaries might itself be too clever and inadequately charitable. Kris Krane, principal and managing partner at 4Front Advisors, a thoughtleader in the legal marijuana industry, takes a non-conspiratorial view. He says that the extensive and sometimes arbitrary regulations have come about because regulators just dont understand the issues, and there isnt a lot of precedent for them to drawon. Images, Logos, Resemblances A number of states have rules designed to prevent the newly legal industry from appealing to children, getting them hooked young. Massachusetts, for example, provides that edible marijuana infused products shall not bear a reasonable resemblance to any product available for consumption as a commercially available candy. Also, the containers shall carry no cartoons or images other than the logo of the Registered Marijuana Dispensary. | CLS Holdings Inc. Krane believes that these provisions reflect an understandable concern. Politicians, regulators, have all grown up in the environment of the war on drugs, receiving the message that pot is evil. Also, there were egregious examples of both the alcohol and tobacco industries appealing to children. Were not that far removed from Joe Camel or the Budweiserfrogs. Krane does not believe such rules are really necessary, though. A lot of players in the marijuana industry are a lot more socially conscious than their counterparts in tobacco or alcohol, although the legislators dont recognize this. And the culture has changed in terms of what is acceptable to direct to children even in the absence oflegislation. Jeff Binder, the CEO of CLS Holdings USA (OTCQB: CLSH) agrees with the various states legislatures and the general public that marijuana purchase and use must be exclusively an adult decision. "I believe marijuana should never be sold to anyone under the age of 18. As an industry standard, retailers should card buyers. All packaging should bechild-resistant." Binder also believes, though, that given that, I dont see a reason why a retailer could not appropriately use cartoons or cartoon-type images on a package. These images can very well appeal to adults, and they can convey something of the nature of theproduct. Contention in Michigan One of the difficulties with giving any comprehensive view of the patchwork of regulations state by state is the speed with which everything is changing. Thus, in using any simple tabular format one would be in a quandary as to what to say about, for example, Michigan. So let us give a non-tabular, prosaic account of recent developmentsthere. In 2008, voters passed proposal 1 with 63% of the vote, making Michigan the 13th state to legalize medical marijuana. The law (amended in certain respects in 2012) protected residents with certain qualifying medical conditions, and protected their caretakers, from prosecution for growing, possessing, or using, marijuana. As Michigan state legislator Jeff Irwin explained in an interview recently, this law was not designed to create a commercial market in the stuff, but a market did emerge, because some of the caregivers produced overages in their harvesting, reaping more than their own patients could consume, and the caregivers with surplus on their hands believed they were entitled to sell the overage to other appropriatecaregivers-patients. Two recent judicial decisions blew holes in this young market, and the legislature got to work in 2015 trying to patch those holes. As of the time that Irwin spoke with a reporter for MJINews, three bills had passed the state House of Representatives, and each awaited action by the Senate. The pending bill most relevant to the issue of product labelling and packaging is HB 4209, which creates a system of lawful cultivators, processors, and retailers for medical marijuana. With regard to the retailers, it stipulates that they shall have their entire product tested and labelled with test results regarding potency, freedom from contaminants, etc. The details of this are going to be left to the state Licensing and Regulatory Affairs Department(LARA). | CLS Holdings Inc. On the question of how he, as one of the influential supporters of the ongoing legalization process in Michigan, would regard rules banning cartoon images and the like, Irwin replied: What the proposal says is that the retailer must package the product in a way that is not intended to attract children. The details of that commitment, too, will be left toLARA. Odd Rules Then there are rules that seem to have come into existence simply by regulatory inertia. Regulators gotta regulate in much the same way that fish gottaswim. Some states, and Nevada again may serve as an example, require that labelling say something about the aroma, which in the technical language of the new industry is called the terpenoid profile. Some states, such as New Mexico, demand that labels have a use by or freeze by date for products capable of supporting the growth of infectious, toxigenic, or spoilage microorganisms. Now that rule could be grist for a conspiracy theorist. After all, adults do not need a label to inform them that dead plants, left alone for an indefinite length of time, will eventually come to change in appearance and odor. This is no truer of marijuana than it is of tobacco or lettuce. As Krane puts it, marijuana is plant matter. If you leave your marijuana cigarette sitting around unprotected for ten years it will probably look pretty gross at the end of that time. The specific expiration dates appearing in regulations and packages are totally unscientific though. What follows is a state-by-state review, with all the states that have legalized at least some possession or consumption of marijuana listed alphabetically. The discussion of each states rules and regulations is accompanied by a link to a more official and complete source of information. This précis will touch repeatedly on the themes mentioned already. | CLS Holdings Inc. Through the Alphabet ALASKA: This states successful initiative authorized the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board to go into the marijuana-regulating business, pending the development of a separate Marijuana Control Board. The board (either one) is empowered to develop labeling requirements for the products to be sold by marijuana establishments, as well as reasonable restrictions on [their] advertising and display. Detailed regulations along these lines are expected by November 24, 2015. ARIZONA: The Department of Health Services has developed rules under the 2010 Arizona Medical Marijuana Act. It has little to say about packaging or labelling issues. But in 2013, Rep. Kimberly Yee, RPhoenix, complained that some marijuana infused products were being packaged in ways that looked similar to familiar products. So the legislature passed a law restricting the packaging of such edibles to a white background with black text. CALIFORNIA: Medical marijuana has no state-law packaging rules in California, although it does have guidelines for the security and non-diversion of marijuana grown for medical use. The City and County of San Francisco, meantime, has plenty of rules: such as that an edible cannabis product that is made to resemble a typical food product (i.e. brownie, cake) must be in a properly labeled opaque (non see-through) package before it leaves the dispensary. It is kind of the City fathers to inform the stoners parenthetically of the meaning of the wordopaque. COLORADO: Colorado allows both medical and recreational marijuana, with its packaging regulations focusing on child resistance and opacity. The rules on labeling are straightforward: no false or misleading statements, labeling text at least 1/16th of an inch, in English, and labeling for edible products must include all ingredients. CONNECTICUT: Allows medical marijuana use. Label must include serial number, date dispensed, quantity, name and registration number of the patient and caregiver, name of certifying physician, and a prominently printed expiration date based on the producers recommended conditions of use and storage that can be read and understood by the ordinaryindividual. DELAWARE: Label must include the name of the strain, the batch and quantity, details indicating freedom from contamination and the level of active ingredients, and the words, This product is for medical use only, not forresale. GEORGIA: Through legislation signed in the spring of 2015, Georgia allows some seriously ill patients to possess oils containing small amounts of THC. Unfortunately, the bill does not provide for lawful in-state production or distribution, so it is not clear than many patients will actually gain access in this way. The state is considering changes to the act, but regulations about packaging and labeling still seem distant. HAWAII: Packages must be child resistant and opaque, clearly labelled with the phrase For medical use only, and contain information about the contents and potency. Separately, Hawaii makes provision for lozenges that that may be packaged such that one dose, serving, or single wrapped item contains no more than ten milligrams of THC. | CLS Holdings Inc. ILLINOIS: Under its Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act, the state has an elaborate set of labeling requirements. The label for any marijuana infused product must include all ingredients of the item, including any colors, artificial flavors, and preservatives, listed in descending order by predominance of weight, the date of manufacture, a use by date, and two distinct warnings. Buyers must be warned both that the item is not a food on the one hand and that it is intended for consumption by registered qualifying patients only on theother. LOUISIANA: Passed legislation legalizing medical marijuana in 1991, but then failed to follow up as to legal/regulatory framework. On June 29, 2015, Gov. Bobby Jindal signed Senate Bill 143 in order to create such a framework. But this too involved kicking the can forward. The law essentially mandates the creation of regulations by the Louisiana Board of Pharmacy and instructs the BoP about the groups from whom it should seek input before it does so. So no specific packaging/labelling rules exist yet. MAINE: Allows medical marijuana, and treats labeling and packaging as evidence of compliance with a law that limits possession and dispensing to 2.5 oz. per qualifyingpatient. MARYLAND: Allows medical marijuana. Requires a safety insert with all marijuana sold that will include information on methods of administering the product, potential dangers, and appropriate service or treatment for problematic usage. Also, labels require three distinct warnings: that consumption cam impair your ability to drive a car or operate machinery, that the product should be kept away from children, and that possession remains illegal under federal law. MASSACHUSETTS: Medical marijuana is lawful, with child resistant (and opaque) packaging, without images other than the registered marijuana dispensarys (the RMDs) own logo, presumably a consequence of anti-Joe-Camel sentiment. Massachusetts law creates two distinct sets of labeling regulations, one for marijuana-infused products (MIPs), and the other for marijuana as such. The two sets of rules have a lot of points in common, but only the MIPs are required to include on the label the date of product creation and a recommended use by or expiration date. Both sorts of product must contain the following statement: This product has not been analyzed or approved by the FDA. There is limited information on the side effects of using this product, and there may be associated health risks. Do not drive or operate machinery when under the influence of this product. KEEP THIS PRODUCT AWAY FROMCHILDREN. MICHIGAN: Allows for medical marijuana under the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act (that is the official spelling in Michigan, as in New York), but the state currently has no applicable packaging or labeling laws. For more information on Michigan, see the prefatory essay above. MINNESOTA: Allows medical marijuana, subject to an unusually complicated set of packaging and labeling regulations. Minnesota provides for example that the packaging must not bear a reasonable resemblance to any commercially available product and must not depict images other than the medical cannabis manufacturers business name logo. Further, the trade name must not be confusingly similar to that | CLS Holdings Inc. of any existing noncannabis product. Furthermore, the label must include: The patients registry identification number, name, and date of birth; the name and date of birth of the designated registered caregiver if applicable; the name of the patients patient or legal guardian, if listed on the registry verification; the patients address; the name and address of the manufacturer whence the cannabis came; the cannabis chemical composition; the recommended dosage; directions for use of the product; all ingredients of the product shown with common or usual names, including any colors, artificial flavors, and preservatives, listed in descending order by predominance of weight; date of manufacture and batch number; and two notices. One of the notices is to run as follows (with the caps): "Thisproducthasnotbeenanalyzedor approvedby the United States Food and Drug Administration. There is limited information on the side effects of using this product, and there may be associated health risks. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery when under the influenceofthisproduct.KEEPTHISPRODUCTOUTOF REACHOFCHILDREN. Theotheristo read: "Thismedical cannabisisfortherapeuticuseonly.Diversionofthis productis unlawfuland may resultin the revocationofthepatient'sregistration." MONTANA: Allows for medical marijuana under Initiative 148, approved by the states voters on November 2, 2004. Yes, eleven years ago. Amended on May 14, 2011 in ways that make access very limited, and forbids commercial sale. That amending statute has itself been challenged in the courts, but while the situation sorts itself out, there are no labeling or packaging rules. NEVADA: Some of its rules were discussed in the prefatory essay above. Labels must include: The name if the medical marijuana establishment and its  registration certificate number; lot number; date of harvest; date of final testing; date on which the product was packaged; cannabinoid profile and potency levels and terpenoid profile as determined by an independent testing laboratory; the expiration date; the quantity of marijuana sold. Nevada is less specific than some states about the size of the print and such matters, but it does provide that this information must be in legibleEnglish. NEW HAMPSHIRE: Leaves a large role for industry self-regulation. Its alternative treatment centers are mandated to provide a plan of their own for safe and accuratepackaging. NEW JERSEY: The Public Health Services branch of Health and Senior Services administers New Jerseys medical marijuana program. New Jersey distinguishes two sorts of Alternative Treatment Center (ATC), the dispensaries and the plant cultivation sites. The latter shall place a legible, firmly affixed label containing [certain information] on each package it sends to the former. The label must provide the name and address of the ATC-cultivation, the quantity, the date of packaging, a sequential serial number, lot number, and bar code, the cannabinoid profile, including the THC level not to exceed 10 percent, a statement of whether the marijuana is of low, medium, or high strength, a statement that it is not for resale, and a list of any ingredients other than marijuana contained in the packaging. | CLS Holdings Inc. The law also provides that the label must say, This statement has not been evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration. This product is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. NEW MEXICO: This state requires a fairly standard list of labelling items, along with a use by or freeze by date for products capable of supporting the growth of infectious, toxigenic, or spoilage microorganisms. NEW YORK: The states medical marijuana regulations provide that when an entity applies to become a registered organization, it mustsubmit: a standard operating procedure manual for all methods used from cultivation of the medical marihuana through packaging, sealing and labeling of each lot of medical marihuana product. The procedures shall include use of good agricultural practices (GAPs) and must conform to all applicable laws and rules of New York State. Standard operating procedures shall be able to be validated to demonstrate that the applicant will be able to produce and dispense consistent and reproducible medical marihuana product such that, for each form of each brand produced, there is homogeneity, absence of contamination and reproducibility of the brand profile in eachlot. OREGON: The state has allowed medical marijuana since 1998, via its Ballot Measure 67, and recreational marijuana since Election Day 2014. The latter law took effect in July 2015. Its still-temporary rules on medical marijuana involve various posters and flyers that must be in plain sight or distributed to customers of facilities. One of the required flyers may be found here. Temporary rules on recreational marijuana also rely on posters and flyers at the point of sale. Separately, they provide that containers must be child resistant, and must not be packaged in a way that is attractive to minors. RHODE ISLAND: Allows for the distribution of medical marijuana at compassion centers. Every new registered qualifying patient who registers at a compassion center is provided with a FAQ sheet designed by the Health Department that explains the limitations on the right to use medicinal marijuana under state law. The packaging of useable marijuana must inform patients of the name of the strain, batch, and quantity as well as a statement that the product is for medicinal use only and is not for resale. VERMONT: Provides for the medicinal use of marijuana within what the law describes as a bona fide health care professional-patient relationship which must in most cases have existed for at least six months before the professional may recommend the use of cannabis and qualify the patient. The product is to be labeled so as to make it clear that the state does not attest to the medicinal value of the stuff, and that it is not for resale. It shall also identify the strain of marijuana, and the weight in gram or ounce units. The strains shall reflect the properties of the plant. | CLS Holdings Inc. WASHINGTON: Allows for the use of either medicinal or recreational marijuana. The Evergreen States is unusual in providing detailed specifics about the display of a sample jar. The legislation specifies: A processor may provide a retailer free samples of usable marijuana packaged in a sample jar protected by a plastic or metal mesh screen to allow customers to smell the product before purchase. The sample jar may not contain more than three and one-half grams of usable marijuana. The sample jar and the usable marijuana within may not be sold to a customer and must be returned to the licensed processor who provided the usable marijuana and sample jar. With that kind of attention to detail it is perhaps to be expected that the legislation also specifies six distinct warnings that must be included in material provided to customers at the retail level: This product has intoxicating effects and may be habit forming; smoking is hazardous to your health; there maybe risks associated with consumption of this product; should not be used by women that are pregnant or breast feeding; for use only by adults twenty-one and older; Keep out of reach of children; marijuana can impair concentration, coordination, and judgment, do not operate a vehicle under the influence of this drug; and a statement that discloses all pesticides applied to the marijuana plants and growing medium during production andprocessing. Consumers of marijuana infused products are to receive another set of warnings, such as When eaten or swallowed, the intoxicating effects of this drug may be delayed by two or more hours. Apparently so you do not feel cheated during that period. WASHINGTON, D.C.: Our nations capital has allowed medicinal use since passage of the Marijuana for Medical Treatment Initiative of 1999. Pertinent rules on the labeling and packaging of medical marijuana were published in the DC Register on December 2,2011. These rules include a fairly standard list of what has to be on such a label: name of cultivation center, name of dispensary, quantity, cannabinoid profile, other ingredients, etc. Further, D.C. wants the label to include a list of all chemical additives, including but not limited to non-organic and organic pesticides, herbicides and fertilizers that were used in the cultivation and production of the medical marijuana. The label shall not include Any seal, flag, crest, coat of arms, or other insignia likely to mislead the qualified patient to believe that the product has been endorsed, made, or used by the District government.  In 2014, Initiative 71, supporting adult recreational use, passed with the support of close to 65% of voters. This seems not yet to have given rise to new rules as to packaging or labeling. | CLS Holdings Inc. Final Thoughts The hobbled-together sound of many of these regulations, taking them state-by-state and still more if they are considered as a whole, is inconvenient for entrepreneurs, who of course value clarity and predictability. CLS Holding has proposed that manufacturers themselves could pick up the mantle here, creating a standard for labeling that would live up to all of these requirements and that would empower consumers and ease the minds of apprehensiveoutsiders. In the words of the CEO of CLS, Jeff Binder, There will come a time when the federal government will come in to regulate, because they want to be able to tax cannabis, and they'll want to be able to control its interstate shipment. By creating industry wide standards, we're preparing for that day." Molly Poiset, an award-winning chef known for reinventing the edible, expressed a similar view in a recent e-mail exchange. She has an especial concern with the adults-only nature of marijuana-infused foods. "Child safe packaging and labeling, she said, is a critical factor in paving the way for cannabis and cannabis-infused edibles to become a trusted and respected consumer product."<br></p>
